reviews.review: One of the best parks in Tokio. Park located in north-east Tokio, worths a visit if you are nearby (Sensoji temple, National Museum).

Great park . We went on the weekend and enjoyed some sculpture and bonsai dress exhibits as well as a small market. We found the zoo in the park which was very good value for money. The pandas were great to see. Some of the animals seemed a bit sad / stressed though - personally I would have been happy to pay a bit more money and see them in bigger enclosures

Lovely park, centrally located in Tokyo. This centrally located park is impressive in itself, but the park also houses the Tokyo National Museum as well as the Zoo. As well as the usual attractions of large greened areas within this city, there is also a massive statue of a killer whale and a beautiful large water feature surrounded by flowering plants - the fountains function on the hour for 30 minutes and are well worth waiting for.

Street food galore in Japan. Want to try authentic Japanese food at very low prices? Go to Ueno Park and dine at the street food. You can even buy fresh fish for sashimi, chocolates, macha and many more.
Nice park with some beautiful temples inside. A nice park with some beautiful temples inside. The is one in the pond but also a beautiful one just of the main square. This one is beautiful with gold

Very nice prk with several shrines. The park is very large given its central location, having numerous acres of gardens, as well as several shrines and temples. The site is surrounded by the Museum and art galleries. To see the park and the galleries & museum will take a day. There is also a lot of shade if you (like me) avoid direct sunlight.

Fantastic park to stroll around. A large park in Keno and a short walk from various stations. Apart from the museums, there are lovely shady paths to stroll around, temples , statues, fountains, seats to relax on. A lovely spot.
Relax in a hot day. I've been visited the Ueno park in August, if you don't have planned your trip to Japan, go there in spring during cherry blossom.

Beautiful park. We visited on a wonderfully warm autumn day on the weekend, and there were many people having the same idea as it is such a large open space in bustling Tokyo, so easily reached from Ueno station.

Large Park but a bit old and neglected. Right beside Ueno station and most of the commercial establishment. Has a bit of a history as evidenced by the old houses previously owned by shoguns. Needs a big renovation though; it starting to be a bit dirty and smelly.

Lovely Park - Lots to Do. Spent a full day in Ueno Park as aside from walking around appreciating the beauty of nature, we visited the zoo, the Museum of Modern Art and Bentendo Temple. Good information kiosk / maps in English for any tourists considering a visit here.
Drop by. We swung-by after visiting Asakusa, grabbed lunch - tonkatsu. Plenty to look at. Some markets, lower priced goods. The park nearby is relaxing.

Bice dahlia bloom . Worth the walk to see multi-colored dahlias in bloom
Ueno has transformed. In the past; plenty of homeless. Now very bright and feels much safer

Lovely park but not a must. This park is lovely to walk through if you have some time to spare while in Tokyo or if you want a day to chill out from all the traffic etc. I would not add this park as a must do in Tokyo.They have at one section some boats to tide on in a pond. Other sections if you want you can feed birds directly from your hand. They fly down directly to eat from your hand literally. That was kinda cool.

Nothing particular to see during summer time. We visited Japan during blistering hot summer time and to be honest, Ueno Park is just a massive patch of greens where you wouldn't find yourself spend more than 1 hour under the scorching sun. But still, it's a gem for urban dwellers.
Tokyo visit not completed if you miss Ueno Park. This is a must visit place in Tokyo. In simple words, your Tokyo visit is not completed if you miss this park. As simple as that!!
Lovely and diverse area. Grand esplanade surrounded by museums, shrines, zoo, pond with boats for rent, and an avenue of cherry trees. Well served by subway and near market area.

Open space!. Very refreshing to visit a park with so many benches in the city. You could watch the world go by away from the big buildings. It was PokemonGo crazy when we visited and apparently there is some meeting point there (don't ask me, I don't play) so take care to watch out for phone zombies not looking where they are walking!

Ueno . Another must do in Tokyo , fabulous gardens ,Museums everywhere , Great Lake with paddle type boats ,zoo ,although I didn't think much of it and incredible busy on a Sunday , but very cheap to get in and see the Pandas .Little markets and food stands ,Starbucks all in the park and very easy to access from Ueno JR station park exit. Many markets in the streets on the other exit to station .
Meditative. Wonderful park with small shrine, great greenery, small Italian restaurant, nearby shopping and people watching in the middle of busy city
Popular park to stroll. This is a nice park, popular with tourists and locals. Cherry blossom season is the time to visit this park.

Great Sunday in Tokyo. Just an incredible park and beautifully maintained gardens with several sidewalk entertainers and cultural events. Spent a great Sunday just walking the park with my girl. Could not have been better and a beautiful sunny day.

A wonderful huge park with lots of activities!. It is a huge park which is very popular especially on Sundays where there are lots of families who come with children who play and run, there are museums in the park, restaurants, an area where one can watch people play baseball etc. There is a train station and metro station very close by the park.

A breadth of fresh air and quietness. Vey nice to visit this park after some of the busiests districts. Quiet (even if there is a lot of people) with several very distinct areas and buildings to view.

Peaceful place in a busy city . The park in September looked quite different from our last visit in April 2015 when cherry blossom was in full bloom. We entered from a different entrance and was impressed by the huge lily pond. A nice stroll towards the temples was relaxing. The street performer playing cello added charm to the environment. With its cultural museums, playgrounds, etc. it has a Central Park feel to it and provided a nice break from the hectic pace of sightseeing.
Peaceful, includes Tokyo National Museum. Our hotel room looked out over Ueno Park and it was pleasant to walk in. It also includes shrines and the Tokyo National Museum.

When you want to take a break from Tokyo's crowded activity . When you visit Tokyo and want to take a change of scenery, or maybe you're tired of looking to city buildings.. Why not come here?? In Ueno Park you can find temple, a lake with rent a boat and the best part is you can enter the park with no cost at all.. ITS FREE!!!! The scenery is breath taking, you can buy brealfast at convenience store and eat here in the park in front of the lake....
Very beautiful. The park was very peaceful and scenic. There is a lot to see and many places to sit and take in the beauty.
Quiet in the city. The park is a nice walk, there are plenty of interesting sights to see, the lake in the middle was huge and filled with lilies, a relaxing vista on a hot day
Beautiful . Lovely spacious, quiet space lots of people running around from office workers to tourist lots to do it just sit to gather yourself.

Very beautiful park. The park is very beautiful and the zoo was enjoyful. The thing that detracted from our visit is that some of the enclosures for the animals could have been bigger. For example the meerkat one was very pitiful to see.
But other than that it was a nice experience.
Green island in urban sea... You can easily spend a day around Ueno Park: walking around, enjoying the various museums, eating in or outside...

Lots to explore. There are many possible venues to visit within the park but we enjoyed simply strolling though parts of it, people-watching (large groups of Pokemon-Go devotees in parts!) after visiting the Tokyo Museum.
A slightly quirky highlight, however, was hiring a large pink duck paddle boat for 1/2 hour on the lake - great fun dodging the other swans!
Lovely for a wander!. Really nice place to wander for a few hours. Lots to see and lots of museums in the area. There are cafes and a nice Starbucks in the park.

Garden beauty. Ueno Park is a place of beauty. The lake/pond is filled with water lily-type plants. Amid the sea of green, pops of magnificent pink blooms rise up. It was quite hot and crowded when we visited in August, but I still recommend visiting here to experience one small example of the beauty of Tokyo.

Pokemon Go crowd. We are going to spend more time in this park because it is Hugh. Then we see many people coming for their Pokémon Go game.We really cannot understand why young and old behave like this under the influence of this game. Such a waste of time and disturb others mood for a relaxing walk!The Park should think of some rule to stop those concerned people?!

A nice place for a light and easy stroll.. I went when it's not so packed with tourists and it was pleasant enough. The pathways are wide, and the occasional local musician (playing a traditional instrument) was a nice break. There are also some historical spots in the park - just ask the locals about the meaning or significance of the attractions!

Loved the park. These grounds are beautiful a db serene. Excellent layout of the part and the feeling you get while being there is immeasurably relaxing and calming. This is a great place to decompress from the rigors of Tokyo explorations!!!

Most Amazing Park Ever . I was in Tokyo in February this year and I was shown this amazing park . My friends told me that anyone that comes to Tokyo must visit this place . I was told that park has about 15 attraction to see and I only can manage to see few of it but it makes me to see it again on my next trip to Japan . I was told by the guide that Ueno Park is about 300 acres and in it you have museums , temples, shrines , institutions and schools . The guide told me also the about 10 million people visit this park every year . That's incredible but by my experience it's so true . You have to spend a day here , come early morning , make sure you have comfortable clothes & shoes to walk around . Most importantly bottles of water ya . My recommendation to see, is the Tokyo National museum , Hanami which is viewing of the Sakura that bloom in spring .National museum of nature and science , here you get to see many animals , plants and thee surprise of dinosaurs . Ueno Zoo which I was told that is oldest zoo in Japan but it's not so big but during my time there they had the pandas but sadly I missed it . Also do visit the Ueno Toshogu Shrine , I was there and it was great. During my visit also they had this amazing flower at the park and I truly loved it . Definitely my choice of place to visit , I managed only to see 4 of the attractions but on my next visit I will definitely complete it . Cheers

Sakura Viewing. We actually went here April of last year, the dates in Tripadvisor is limited until October 2015.This place can get crowded during the Cherry Blossoms season. But, it was one hell of an experience! Others may say that I am exaggerating things, but for a nature lover like me and knows how to appreciate the beauty of nature, this is one for the books.You just take the train in the JR Yamanote line and get off at Ueno sta. follow the barrage of people walking towards one direction. You will see a walkway that has sakura trees lined up on both sides. You walk through under the roof of sakura blossoms and marvel the beauty of branches of the sakura trees bearing the sakura blossoms. Take photos all you want, nobody will even bother you. It's kind of a long walk, with people seated under the trees for their Hanami, enjoying their food, and the cool breeze of spring. You can even join the locals during their Hanami, just ask if they are ok with it (I haven't encountered any locals that would shoo you away). You can enjoy your food with them, make new friends and get tips!When tired and hungry, there is a starbucks in the premises of the park, and a burger place where they have a drink all you can soda, juice and ice tea.When you're done with your sakura viewing, you can go to the zoo which is also in the park's premises. Although, I would suggest you go there during weekdays as the lines can get really long.If you are not into zoos, you can go out of the park, walk toward your right if you are facing Ueno sta., and do some shopping!

Beautiful Park with Zoo (with Pandas). Best during Sakura / Autumn season but lovely throughout the year. Green / spacious park within the middle of the city. Helps relax, and have fun.
Very near to Ueno zoo and Museum.

Too crowded. If you want to have a nice profile photo with the long stretch of road lined by the Cherry Blossoms, this definitely is not the place for you to go. It is super crowded most specially during the sakura season. It is a really great experience seeing the trees in full bloom but one can't really appreciate it that much with loads of people on it.
Bustling, pretty, long walk.. VERY busy during blossom-viewing season (to be expected). Even a week after the blossoms (some withering away), there's still a crowd that you have to wade through.
Beautiful Park. This is a very large park with lots to see. These are a few different shrines and gardens. There were a few food stands, but it is a great place for a picnic lunch.

Beautiful park with arts. Some people might get sick of parks, but I never do. This one is a beauty. Get off at Ueno Station and wander the market street where hawkers are flogging street food and bargain clothes and shoes. Not far from here is Ueno Park, which features a giant pond with lotus as far as you can see, excellent paths for walking and is home to a zoo and museums on Japan's history. The museum is top notch with explanations in English on exhibits. We went to the park on a Sunday and there were all sorts of activities, including a fair and music festival. A few attractions within walking distance of the park too, including a historic shrine where we were lucky enough to see a traditional wedding.

A lot to do here :). With a number of museums, shrines & a zoo, this park has a lot to offer to both tourists and locals alike. I went in from the east entrance after walking 30 to 45 minutes from the Asakusa area (from Sensoji Temple to be exact) and first got to the Museum of Nature & Science on the left side (near the east entrance) where there are a number of "interesting" outdoor sculptures like that of a group of priests and that of an archer drawing his bowstring and such. I then went on to the nearby Tokyo National Museum where there's a big pond with water fountains in it at the big open area across the street from the Museum, and the inside was quite a "worthwhile" experience with great displays not only from Japan but from other countries of the world (including those from as far as Iran & Egypt). About 5 to 10 minutes south from the National Museum is a temple (likely a taisha shrine by the look of its orange-black torii gates) which is kind of a "smaller version" of Fushimi Inari Shrine in Kyoto, but yes this one has a much shorter 'tunnel' of torii gates than Fushimi Inari's sembon torii, but it was still a fun experience to go through this one (which I actually did before the sembon torii in Kyoto eight days later). Further down south from that temple and at a little uphill location is the big statue of a warrior with his dog (called Saigo Takamori, I guess that's the name of the warrior) with the nearby tomb of warriors as well. My last stop in the park was Bentendo Shrine in the middle of the lake pretty much all covered with lotus leaves (after coming down the stairs from Saigo Takamori and crossing the street); was a little disappointed since I'd expected to see a "clear lake", but the shrine despite its small size has a big orange paper lantern which is even comparable (!) to the big paper lantern at the main hall of Tokyo's most famous temple Sensoji.By subway, the best way is to take the Metro Ginza Line to Ueno Station which is just beside the southeast area of the Park; you'll be pretty much at the south entrance of the Park after coming out of the station (just keep in mind the sites in the Park that I mentioned above will be in the reverse sequence since I made my way down from the National Museum on the north side). Also near the south entrance and just across the street from the Park are plenty of eating places in narrow lanes.

Beautiful park for a stroll. We walked though Ueno Park to reach the museum. It was packed with locals enjoying street food and entertainment. We sat and enjoyed the acrobats and people watched. Busy on a weekend but worth it.

Great for a stroll around. Famous for its cherry blossoms, it is also a great Park to visit otherwise. It's massive spread makes it an easy park to stroll around and yet it has its distinctive shrines and ponds dotted around. Off course the end of the park is the famous Tokyo national museum which is also a must visit. Highly recommended park for kids and the families.

Nice walk in there! if you have time!!. really cool place as i went during the weekend and It was full of artist and people having fun and enjoying of a great afternoon. Great place and accessible. There are some good places to eat close to Ueno park, check it out also!

A typical Japanese Park. Tree-lined walkways and lily pad pond but no lawn. Try to avoid going there during holidays and weekends because it is filled with locals. If you want more than just a park, there are many museums on its grounds. However, it is one of Tokyo's most popular cherry blossom spots with more than 1000 cherry trees along the central pathway.

Big park. Ueno park is massive but really nice to visit. We were staying close and so would walk through part of it each day. There are plenty of things to see and do or its just nice to walk through.

Clean & beautiful stroll along the park. Beautiful park to enjoy a blooming sakura. Best time to go during sakura season. There's paddle boat too enjoy the view .
Travelled February 2015

Big Park, lots to see. The park is very nice with much to see and do. The park is free to enter, but not everything in the park is free. But there is so much to do in the park, from the zoo to the temples to the museums. A lot of other random statues and other neat things to see as well. Right by Ueno station as well.

Beautiful modern park area. Lots of choices for things to do here. There was some kind of performance going on when we arrived. Couldn't get close enough to see much but we did get to see the floats that were parked along the edges of the crowd. Saw the shrine, opted out of the zoo visit (even though that was the only way to get a full view of the pagoda...) Also checked out the nature and science museum and would have checked out the other museums if we'd had more time. Nice place to spend time in the city.

Huge park to explore!. Ueno park is a great place to explore, with multiple museums available and also a large zoo. But even if you're looking for a free day out there's lots of see in the park without paying any entrance fees, including a large lilypad pond, a children's play area nearby to the pond, food stalls, large open spaces and tree-lined walkways. We went on an incredibly hot day, so benefited from the shade, visited the temple, spent some time with the kids playing in the park, and then treated ourselves to ice-cold drinks in the large Starbucks in the centre of the park.

Cool zoo :) now thats a zoo!. We loved our trip to japan it was a nice experience. :) going to tokyo, tsukiji, to osaka castle to universal studios japan! :) etc. ueno park asakusa temple sensoji temple etc...

a stroll in the park. I was here during Summer. It is a bit hot and a lot of people. But no worries, if you get tired walking, you can just sit down somewhere, grab a drink, and watch people. The park is big and you won't be bored at watching people. Museums are nearby so there is a lot to do!

Nice walk and fan swan ride on the pond. Apart from Ohanami (cherry blossoms viewing) season, Ueno park is quiet and nice to walk.　At Shinobazu-no-ike pond, swan boat ride was fan thing to do, but a bit pricy.
A beautiful park. A beautiful park and great place to walk and get away from the crowds when in Tokyo. Very quiet and picturesque, which is in stark contrast to many areas in Tokyo

Nice way to experience Japan's history, culture, and food. We took a free walking tour of The Ueno Park. Being the first park we visited in Japan, we found it a great experience.The park has a bit of everything - culture, history, museums, open spaces to relax, food stalls, zoos, temples, shrinesWe learned a bit of the history of Japan as this is a historical place.We also learnt a bit of the culture by visiting a Budhist temple, and saw people praying.Apparently this a great place to see the cherry blossoms, but we missed it.A nice place to start your visit of Japan
Great Park. Large busy park with lots to see and do-contains a lake, lily pond, temple, shrines, fountains, food stalls, zoo and numerous museums. Vey close to Ueno train station. Worth a visit.
Great place to relax. We observed hundreds of locals in Sunday afternoon, strolling to catch Pokemons. Very relaxing atmosphere. Nice landscapes, especially from the bank of the lake.

Something for everyone. We visited on a hot July day, walked around the beautiful lily pond, stopped to listen to opera rehearsals at a pavillion by the lake and then headed to the national museum to cool off! Plenty of other attractions to see in the park including a zoo, Shrines, temples and pagodas and plenty of places to sit and people watch.

Nice park near the train station. I was in tokyo for a few days and decided to take a look at some parks. I went to Ueno park on a sunday and there were a lot of people there. The park was very lively with lots of attractions.
Go for the free walking tour. Our guide had so much information to tell us about the park - history, architecture, culture. The lily pond is incredible - I never knew lilies could grow so big.

Another Hachiko Dog Statue here!. So there is a hachiko memorial statue that is famous in Shibuya by the crossing, but we found out there is another one here. And in this one, the dog reunites with the owner, which is a happy ending to the very sad story. the kids were so happy to see this.

Clen and tidy. Peaceful Park near ueno station. There are temples, zoo and Museums. I suggest to take Yamanote line and get off at Uguisudani station and the walk trough Park from North to sud. At the end you can move to visit Asakusa.
Good Park with good activities and food around it. I went here today to see the Ueno area of Tokyo whee the museums are and ran into this park. Even tools swan boat ride as well on the water.

beautiful park with many attraction here. you can go for all ages, near here there is shrine, zoo for about 600 yen per adult, a little bit of museum, history and pond with rental boat for 30 minutes, can take 3 hours to explore all of this...
Peace and quiet. This is a large park which houses the zoo as well as a range of museums. There are entertainers and places to eat. It is a good spot to people watch.

A Beautiful Park with lots to do and see on a sunny afternoon in Central Tokyo near the train station. Ueno Park is easy to get to by train, and there is a train station near the entrance of the Park. We were there in April just past the full blossom sakura tree season, but there was still some cherry blossoms from the many sakura trees in the park. This park is great to take a nice walk and explore on a sunny day.There is so much to do so plan a full day there. there is the National Art Museum, a toshogu shrine and gardens, paddle boats, relaxing by the shinobazu pond and much more.

Nice!. Big park with museums, art museum with Monets, cheap ZOO was nice in rainy day. And old temple "visually" connected with another nearby old temple with stone monuments is oase in city. Take a rest in this perfect place in the middle of the pond!

A beautiful destination for a lazy day. Ueno is the perfect destination to see many things in one day. I managed to hit Ueno zoo in the morning (go when the gates open in order to see the pandas right away without a wait time) and then spent the afternoon in some of the many museums around the park.
Very good. Amazing park,huge!Should be without little kids.The zoo is very cheap and have many kinds of animals.

A concrete open space. I think westerners will have a very different idea to parks in Europe or America to what they do in Tokyo. Its all paved over with concrete, a fair few trees but not much in the realms of grassy areas to sit and so on. It wasn't much of a rest from the heat as the sun just reflects from the floor. It has a Starbucks though...
Fantastic during cherry blooming. If you can, you should wait to visit this place until cherry blooming when it is extremely nice. Otherwise it is a nice quiet park.

Beautifull, but overcrowded. The problem with Ueno park is simple. The park is beautifull, but by all the people you can hardly see the park. I was there at a sarhurday and there were just too many persons to enjoy the park.
A standard park. I don't know if we miss something but we had a walk and we didn't find anything special.. It's a pretty Park, we didn't feel the magical side..

Top Pokemon spot + great museums. It is amazing to see all of the people playing Pokemon in this park. Apparently it is one best places to go to get the high value Pokemon. The National Museum, which is in the park has a great exhibit that give you an overview of Japanese art with a good english guide book. We had a lovely lunch at the restaurant next to the museum (to the right)

Culture condensed. The amount of attractions in this park is incredible. There are museums, a zoo, temples, a lake... It is huge. Couldn't decide where to go first. If you don't want to spend any money, there is always some street artist around to entertain and benches to sit and relax.

Lovely to see the Cherry Blossom. Visited at the beginning of April and was lucky enough to catch the tail end of the cherry blossom season, which I feel might make the park a bit more lively than it is at other times of year due to the many food stalls in place (the giant corn on the cob was delicious!).There are a lot of different areas to the park and it's a pleasant break from wandering around the city.Very easy to get to using the efficient rail system, there is a stop right opposite the park.Only thing that did make me feel a bit down was the Ueno Park Zoo, but I've done a separate review for it so won't go in to too much detail.

Amazing collection of art and culture. Museums, restaurants, statues, shady trees, Peruvian musicians (sometimes) and a zoo - all located near a major transit hub - what's not to love? It gets more and more crowded as the day goes by so try and get their early. Museums open around 9:30 am.

Mini Central Park in Tokyo. Very enjoyable to walk around. Reminded me of a mini Central Park in Tokyo with the way the paths went, the fact there is a small zoo and a kids play area as well as water areas etc. Spent about 90 minutes there (was a hot day) and felt relaxed strolling around and enjoying the sights.
Nice park. Second visit of this park during summer. Lots of pokemongo players, especially near the pond. The water lilies are big & tall. Nice scenic view.
Zoo. The park has so much to it. It was well worth a visit. We went to the zoo, very reasonably priced for an adult 600 yen.
A relaxing oasis. Loved the lotus pond. We walked around the park c each night after dinner. It felt very safe and lots of people were around. Lots of pokemon go players.

Nice park. If I lived near this park I would love to spend time here enjoying the green space. As a tourist, it is just a park and not especially interesting. My husband and I only spent a few hours in Tokyo on a long layover. We took the train to Asakusa area, then walked through Ueno Park, and then to Yanaka Ginza before catching the train back to the airport. It was a nice day to see some of the real Tokyo (my first visit to Japan) and I look forward to coming back someday.

One of Tokyo's Great parks for citizen and tourist alike. A beautiful park with so much to do and so much to see.There are lakes, ponds and tree lined walkways. A temple near the entrance is a good place to get some good luck before venturing in. Vendors set up traditional food stalls on the walkway leading to the lake. Further in is a zoo, an open fountain and yet more shrines and temples. There is even a 5-story pagoda. Ueno park is also the site of several museums, the Tokyo Metro Art Museum, the National Musem of Nature and Science and the National Museum of Western Art. The park does not get overly crowded and has restroom facilities throughout.

A fun day in the park . We spent a whole day here. We walked around and stumbled across lots of different things to look at. The park is huge and beautiful. The zoo was enjoyable and great for kids and adults. The pandas are so cute and not to be missed. When you exit the train and walk to this area, you will see that it's dedicated to the panda bear! Bakeries have panda pictures in the bread and panda shaped bread. It's really cute!

Great place to see heaps. So many thing to do in one spot, museums, temples and of the zoo with the famous panda bears.Great place for kids with plenty of parks and things every were to keep them happy and entertained.A must place to visit if you have limited time and budget.Check it out, you want regret it

very large beautiful park. very beautiful park , went at the peak of sakura blossom season and it was really packed but still have an amazing time , there is a temple to visit , a traditional food market and I recommend get on a pedal / swan boat and enjoy the lake

A days visit!. You could literally spend a whole day at Ueno Park as there is a seemingly endless amount of activities to see; to name a few:
Yanaka Cemetery
Tokyo Metropolitan Museum
Tokyo Musicology Department
Tokyo Fine Arts Department
Ueno Zoo
Tokyo National Museum
The Ueno Royal Museum
The National Museum of Western Art

Pleasant place to walk around. Walking around the park is a good free activity if you want to get a little closer to nature. The large pond was completely filled with gigantic lotus blossoms and the paths are tree lined. There are roughly three divided pond areas, one of which is for paddle boat rentals. There is a temple in one area and the walkway leading up to it is lined with food vendors. Great to eat a street-food dinner there. The park is lovely in the morning so we grabbed some breakfast out of Lawson's and sat at a park bench.

Fantastic Oasis in the City. You come here over and over as there are a ton of museums off/in the park, but the park on it's own is also great. The fountains and sitting area are really nice as is the shady grass areas between the trees.And yes the cherry blossoms were fantastic.

Beautiful place for a stroll. This is a large park with several museums. It is great for a stroll, especially on the weekends when there are unique buskers. There are two subway stops, one to the north which is closer to the National Museum and one to the south. On the same visit you can do a little shopping at the department store or walk down the back streets known as the American Market.

Sunday morning. Decided to wake up early and visit Ueno Park at 5am. The sun had risen so, you'll be surprised at how many people was in the park in summer this early in the morning.This park is just behind the Ueno Station which has its own exit. It was indeed a very interesting walk for me. There was the Japanese gardens, lily pond, shrines, reflective lake, kois and tortoises, zoo, baseball park, a central park and pavillions, various statues, panda postbox, National musuem, art and western museums, and if you are interested in the long standing Japanese culture, go to the Central Park and wait for Radio Taiso Daiichi to begin. This is where everyone gathered for the national morning exercise.I did not have a moment of boredom, my only regret was I didn't get to visit the establishments in the park. I only had time to walk by and enjoy the sunrise.

More than a park. We had a few hours to kill before we left so thought we'd have a walk through the park, so glad we did. There was so much to see, a number of temples and shrines, a couple of museums, including a the national museum and art gallery. There's even a music venue.

Best time to go: sakura season. Went there in April and it was sakura season. My god, it was awesome! Loads of street food and atmosphere was amazing. A little crowded but that is to be expected. Will visit again soon

Must See. Spent an afternoon here a couple weeks ago. The park is huge and full museums and visitors. There is no way you can see everything in one trip, we never made it out of the Tokyo Art Museum complex. They had a decent (crowded) temporary exhibit on ancient Greece, it was ok but probably not worth the additional money. they also had a small collection of Egyptian artifacts including a mummy. I was beyond thrilled but I've never seen any Egyptian antiquities in person. They also had a 40-minute educational movie that went along with the exhibit. Interestingly, the video was narrated live with an actual person! Japan is notorious for similarly amazing attention to details in this city with millions of people!

Big is beautiful. Navigating this big park can be a bit tricky, but it's a haven of peace and quiet with many attractions in it and near it and some very welcome shade on hot and humid days. Whether you enjoy temples, nature or just watching people, this park offers all that and much more. Bring your own drink and food as the stalls can be limited in their offering and the Starbucks is super crowded all day.

a sanctuary. Although very civilized, Tokyo tends to be a bustling place. Ueno Park is a calm, pleasant spot in the heart of the city, The walk up the staircase entrance to the park takes you from a crowded street to a leafy oasis. Our trip was in mid-April, so we missed the height of the cherry blossom season, but there was just enough that we could easily imagine how it would be at its peak. We look forward to a return a little earlier in the spring.The park is beautiful, and there was just enough going on to make it interesting without being hectic. A couple of ambitious "street musicians" entertained on marimbas (really), and we actually heard a Disney tune.The park also provides access to some major museums.

Center of it all. Ueno Park is a sprawling open space with museums, a zoo and Ueno Station, a major hub, on its periphery. It's a good place to begin to understand Tokyo and its many options. Also a good place to jog or join in group stretching in the morning, around 7:30.
Nice park with temples. You can find many non modern sights in Tokyo, this park is one of them, easily accesible with JR pass Yamamoto line.
Nice to walk and relax. Ueno Park is a great place to walk and relax in central Tokyo. It's a pitty that it is not a little bigger. There's also a zoo in this park.

Ueno Park in Spring. We were so blessed and fortunate to be able to get the cherry blossom blooming during our visit. There was great party atmosphere around with locals having picnic under the cherry trees, which am told is a local tradition. Nearby you can also see families with their children enjoying themselves. Try to avoid weekend if you want to escape from the heavy traffic and the crowd

Beautiful in the Blossom Season.. Came here just as the Cherry Trees were blossoming. There were crowd everywhere as people were claiming areas so that their fmailes and the companies they work for could have prime spotsunder theblossoms over the course of their blooming. Worth it for the blossoms and the crowds, to see everyone partying and relaxing.Would recommend out of blossom season as well. The park is not too big that it would take too long to walk around. Nice place to come and relax out of blossom season.

One of the best parks in Tokyo. Ueno park is one of the easier parks to access in all of Tokyo. Simply take the metro to Ueno station and walk outside to access the park. There is everything here, from street performers on shamisen to temples riddled with bullet holes, to a lotus covered lake. This is a great place to spend some time and hang out in a little bubble of green. Also on offer are a number of museums and Ueno zoo (visit to see Panda)

Fabulous GIANT water lilies!. Spend a morning or afternoon walking around Ueno Park. Many locals and families spend time here so it feels authentic in some way. We enjoyed the giant waterlilies with the skyline beyond. A lovely contrast of nature with urban architecture.

Charming location not to be missed. If you come to Tokyo you can't skip Ueno, it's chsrmy garden and shrines will help you get familiar with this amazing city. Do not forget to bow when in front of the shrine and live your little wish for s healthy and happy life!

A huge & beautiful park. I was wondering around this place after my breakfast at Ichiran Ramen. This park is a lot bigger than I had anticipated. Lots of shrines, peonies garden & there is a huge lake nearby. The zoo is somewhere in there. I didn't get to explore the whole park. You will need a good couple of hours to walk the ground.

Great, educational family fun. Tokyo's version of Balboa Park. A variety of museums from which to choose--we even happened across an amazing Greek special exhibition that was very well curated. The zoo was fun for the kids -- Giant Panda and a huge variety of monkeys. Lots of restaurants nearby.

Something for everyone - family and cultural activities. No matter what the weather or whether you're travelling as a family, on your own or with others, you can spend a very enjoyable day at Ueno Park. The zoo is fun and is the home of the adorable and entertaining Giant Pandas, as well as a wide array of other animals. The Park also houses a number of first-class art galleries and museums. If you just feel like wandering, the park provides a pleasant outdoor space. Very busy at the weekend, so a bit of patience may be required. Easily accessed by rail.

Very Crowded!. Though i give it 3 stars, i think the crowds are overwhelming. Avoid weekends unless you like to be rubbing shoulders with the rest of the world. The various Museums are good places to visit.
Amazing Park. This park deserves a full day of attention. There are many sights to see and even in the rain I enjoyed the park. It's right outside of Ueno Station.

Paul with motorhome activities and beauty. Ueno park is a large green area in Tokyo with multiple shrines, status, museums, natural areas and a zoo. There is something here for everyone and it is a short walk to lower cost shipping and food. The large pond covered with Lilly passes is very impressive. Have not been able to see everything, there is just to much to do. Easily reached from there ueno jr radio station.

Large park near the Ueno Train Station. Beautiful park with the Tokyo National Museum and several other attractions too- (maybe the zoo?) Fountains, places to sit, and near the train at Ueno- and a nearby market-

Lots to see around, plus some cool entertainers. I took a tour of Ueno Park with a free guide from the tourism office (coincidentally the same guy who showed me around Asakusa) and he gave me an overview of the history of the region. There's plenty of museums around and I even saw some good entertainers in the park (such as a man drawing pictures on the ground using only wet mop).
Nice well kept park. Ueno Park is a nice well kept park with loads of museums, a pretty good zoo, some nice shrines and a boating lake.
Perfect park. A great place to picnic and see some of Tokyo's incredible museums. You can easily spend a full day here!

Can spend a whole day here. We decided to spend time at Ueno Park, one of the country's first public parks and one of its most popular. There are over 800 cherry trees in the park therefore it is especially well visited during cherry blossom season. Despite us visiting towards the end of the season the park was still quite busy and picnics were happening all around us. Although the trees were no longer in full bloom a cherry blossom 'rain' had started where the tiny flowers cascaded over you.Theres a lot to do there including the zoo and national museum

good when cherry blossom season. Nothing special if it's not cherry blossom season, just a big park.
I went there quite late (The first time I went there in April 2015), the sakura already fell out and it was raining.

Good day out, plenty to do.. Nicely set out park with shaded paths to keep out of the intense heat. Usually decent quality buskers, yesterday there were acrobats from a circus performing for free. Cafes and restaurants about and not too full.

lots of museums, zoo, a nice green space. This is a large park in Tokyo housing several museums, temple, a zoo and lots of green space. We visited the Nature and Science museum and Shinobazu pond, as well as a few of the cafes and souvenir shops, but mostly we spent time enjoying the park itself. There is a small playground a few yards from the Ueno station exit for kids. Bring insect repellent, though. It might be an urban park, but mosquitoes seem to like this place, too.
Lovin the tokyo park scene.. Nice time of year to visit in October. If you cannot go for the spring blossoms. Lots to see weddings weirdos and wannabes.

A nice park that is full of museums.. After visiting the National Museum of Nature and Science, we walked around the park and visited the small temple. We also visited the lotus ponds as well. We had a good time taking pictures and enjoy our walk in a light rain. It is probably not on every visitor's must-see list, but it is a good place to visit if you are heading to one of the museums anyway. Added bonus: there were a lot of eateries between the train/subway station and the park so you will never go hungry after a long walk in the park.
Best left till spring/summer. Wonderful place but you cant see very much when we went. Definitely has potential to be a magical place.

Great couple days with our toddler. On our first trip to Tokyo we stayed 4 nights in Ueno and 3 nights in Disneyland. Ueno Park is the reason we chose the area. We expected fast trains, skyscrapers, busy city streets so it was important to us to have green grass and to escape the big city when needed! It's not as cool or as eclectic as Central Park in New York, but it's still a huge park and garden oasis in the middle of a bustling city. We took our pram and went to the park 3 days in a row to do various activities. The zoo is amazing. Now, the enclosures are small. That's definitely not enough space for those animals. But they are nice looking and all the animals we saw, pandas included, were all on the move and doing something. They feed them in front of the windows and there's just really great viewing. The zoo was a bit spread out for a toddler - so we went on 2 days. It's cheap, totally affordable to do it a couple times. The weekdays are much better than weekends. The park also has lots of area for sitting, relaxing and people watching. We enjoyed 1 of the museums. We loved the novelty of paddling around the pond in a swan boat. My husband is 6'3, barely fit in the boat, it was just a fun hilarious thing to do for 30 minutes. Our toddler loved feeding the big Koi (i think that's the word for the huge goldfish in the river). We also enjoyed getting drinks at the starbucks in the park. Yea, so we found there was a lot to do and it was nice to have a break from the city and the trains.

a park with national museum, zoo and cherry blossoms. A smaller park as compared to the Shinjuku Gyeon National Garden, with cherry blossom trees around the park, art installations, a zoo and national museum and gallery situated within the premises. Stalls selling local crafts, wine, green tea and food were set up when we were there as it was the cherry blossom festival. Dropped by the national museum appreciating the arts and sculptures as well as interactive fortune telling with the friendly staff in the museum. Nice place to chill out if you have time to spare in Tokyo.
Amazing! . Loved all the trees and views, the temple and lakes were so nice as well.. and just a tip, walk around the streets near the park and train station they have markets and amazing food!

Lots of shade and several museums. Wonderful park. Great place to wander around on a hot day--plenty of shade. Several museums on-site. A few restaurants/cafes, but not too commercialized. Buskers here and there. Would definitely go back again.
Nice Walk. Park joins National museum, zoo plus several other places. a pleasant way to get from one site to another. Has a Starbucks in the middle for coffee addicts
Ueno Park, Tokyo. The Park is among the country's fiirst public parks established in 1873 on lands formerly belonging to the temple of Kan'ei-ji.

Beautiful setting in the middle of a huge city. Decided to walk around the park for most of the day. This place is huge and many different attractions. You could spend the entire day and still only scratch the surface. Walking around is free. Each museum or zoo cost money. Decided on the zoo for 600 yen. Very large but but a little disappointed with some of the animals habitat. Was a hot day but plenty to see both indoors and out. Next time will try one of the many museums.

A park for all seasons ! . Good for any season though weekends are seas of people which is good for people watching. you can still find a quiet spot and read a book if you can find a place to sit. within the park, there are many gardens, temples, shrines, statues of historic figures, amusement park for children and of course the lotus ponds and Ueno Zoo. It can take you an hour to walk around many parts of the park but likely half a day if you want to chill out. The best and most popular time to visit the park if you are a tourist from overseas is the short Cherry blossom in April. I came in 1st May and it was all green ! instead of sakura blossoms .

Lovely city park. We walked around the park for a while just enjoying the scene. Lots of families with kids..lively activities... But like the rest of Tokyo, respectfully quiet! Amazing all those people but really quiet.

Spectacular. Ueno park is a MUST if you go to Tokyo! I had a very hot and sunny day and it was just stunning! There are lots of places to sit and relax amongst lovely gardens and all of the museums and the zoo are there! It's also very easy to get to with a train station right at the entrance. There's also performers, artists, food, restaurants and more! Also near by is a shopping area so plenty to do if you want to do both in a day. I would recommend walking around all of it as it is so beautiful!

Beautiful. We strolled around the park for a few hours, loved the water lillies and spotting wildlife. We came across 2 playgrounds for the kids, plenty of toilets and shade. The water fountain is a great spot to sit and relax. Plenty of people around, always something to watch.
lovely green oasis. It was a very hot day but we still enjoyed walking through the park to go to the museum. Lunch in one of the park cafes was also pleasant.
Beautiful inner city park. If you need some time in the park this is a lovely choice , close to the museum and lovely to walk through. A large green oasis in a busy city.

Huge and diverse!. Ueno Park is huge and crowded, a bit like Tuileries Park in Paris. But I really liked the place, there are several museums around it (we chose the Tokyo National Museum that day), hence it is nice to first enjoy the museum visit and then have a break in the park. There are food stalls and restaurants (fast food type). Very nice!
Pretty and Touristy. As one of the precious green spaces in Tokyo, Ueno Park is lovely to walk on hot, sunny days. You will have plenty of company, as the Ueno area is popular with tourists.

Huge park, lots of variety, particularly loved Toshogu Shrine. It was a bit drizzly when we visited but we enjoyed the park anyway. We watched some guys balancing on chairs - precarious and fun then wandered round the temples and shrines. I particularly liked the rows of small red/orange torii and the golden Toshogu Shrine.
Beautiful Park. Explored on our way to the zoo. Lovely chilled out vibe, great to escape the hustle and bustle of the city.
Relaxing moment at Ueno Park. We visited the temple at Ueno park; the place was clean , very cold because it was winter when we came but it smelled of trees and crisp air.

Visit on sunday !!!. Excellent sunday atmosphere. I was curious to know what in-town Tokyo citizens are doing on a day-off. Plenty of families, with or without children are walking around this big park in Ueno, north of Tokyo. Baseball games, zoo, nenuphars lake, children around their parents and grand parents, group of chorals in the basement of auditorium, a ballet at the auditorium at 2.30pm. (¥3000 entrance), runners, so you will get a fantastic radiography of a sunny sunday in Tokyo!! Enjoy !!
Fun time in the park. After a busy day in the busy city centre, I enjoyed my break in the Ueno Park. I had fun, I enjoyed the green and this park was a cool place to be.
Good Market place. Too big a place ......... This is a good place for shopping. A few shops for Gems, but not sure how reliable they are. This is a place must be visited by all Tokyo visitors.

Pleasantly Surprised. First time my family has been to the park and enjoyed it. There is a Starbucks so you can have your caffeine fix ( if you arrive early ). Its a great place for people watching and planning your itinerary ( the park is huge and offers a lot of sights ). We focused mostly on the zoo. Great place for photos ( the viewing areas are designed so there are multiple vantage points ). Also enjoyed taking photos of the flora around the park ( too bad we missed the Sakura season ). I would recommend that you allot at least 3/4 of your day to see most of the museums. We will definitely be back.

The Best Place to feel and view Sakura Blossoms within Tokyo (Hanami Season). Experience :-"The Best Place to feel and view Sakura Blossoms within Tokyo"Widely listed as one of the most popular place within Tokyo to view Sakura Blossoms is certainly justifiable.The Trees were neatly placed and lined up one on either sides, makes for a really scenic and amazing experience. The many carnivals, various stands and crowds really enhance the entire festive seasonHave a walk through the crowds, grab some Yakitori from the various stands or just lay a mat down, have a sip of tea and admire the Sakura Blossoms. Visit some of the nearby Temple, Shrines or Museum, even the Zoo.Tips/Advice:-1) Preferred Time of Visiting? While I generally encourage people to visit an attraction early, this is probably one of the exceptions; you should preferably visit here when it is buzzing with people instead - The atmosphere and ambience just felt much better.2) Admission Fee? Park is free to enter and roam about mostly, except for some of the museums/zoo3) Location : It is just behind JR Ueno station, barely a few steps away. Apart from the Park, it is also conveniently located beside beside many Malls and EateriesWayne’s ratings (As ticked):-i) Must-GO!ii) Recommended ✔✔✔iii) Nay.. or best go as a fillerUnderstandably, my experience has been based during the Hanami Season but I figured this lovely park being free to access, can definitely still be visited at anytime as it has plenty other attractions to offer. Also, it is readily located just behind JR Ueno Station and next to many eateries and malls.PS: Thank you for reading and hope my input and photos help.

Try to visit during Hanami ( sakura blossom period). Try to visit during Hanami ( sakura blossom period) in march-april. A Must see! Also, you could visit the museums and the zoo located within the park.
Beautiful view!. I went during the first week of April when the Sakura was at full bloom so it was a great sight! Good for a long stroll along the riverside.
A Must See. While we were not there when the cherry blossoms were blooming, we could see from the number and placement of the trees it would be a spectacular sight. It's a lovely park any time.

Nice open park for a walk. Ueno park is a nice place to visit for a long walk. Cherry blossom time is amazing ( I didn´t go that time of the year) but the rest of the year you can enjoy the lake, lots of plants and a breath of fresh air inside Tokyo.

Great place for a weekend stroll. This is one of Tokyo's most accessible parks. There are many museums in the area. I found it was a great place to jog. On the weekend there were some festivals - they even had a kiddie bike race with toddler's competing on Strider bikes. Very local and very fun to watch!

Great Park for Cherry Blossoms!. We went to Ueno Park during cherry blossom season to admire the cherry blossoms. By the time we arrived around 10am, the park was already filled with tourists and residents alike – all having picnics in the park. There’s not a lot of room to maneuver around since there is so much people! But it is a great place to see and admire the cherry blossoms. There are also an abundance of food stands in the park selling your typical street fare – takoyaki, grilled squid, yakisoba, saki, beer, oden, etc. Make sure you grab something to eat from those stands because they’re really delicious! It was my first time trying oden and I wasn’t disappointed.

Beautiful Park. Park is well maintained and many trees to see. Unfortunately I went during winter hence the colors are not as vibrant as it could be like during spring or autumn. Nevertheless it was worth a visit. If you are a fan of cats, this park has plenty of cats to see ;)

So much to see!. Got off the train and went for a wander, and what a wonderful wander it was! So many lovely shrines and statues, all labelled in Japanese and English. The gardens were lovely with such an array of Japanese flora. We missed the pond as we decided to visit the zoo which had such a diverse collection of animals. We also ran out of time to visit the museum. A great way to pass time in Tokyo.

Pleasant Surprise. From Ueno Station take the Park Exit. Uneno park was across the road from the station. This is a lovely park with lots of things to see such as the zoo and museum. We enjoyed the Toshogu shrine and the 5 storied pagoda. Having spent a couple of hours walking around the park we had a rest and then walked to the Yushima Tenmangu shrine. There was a little market place there and we found a stall selling Tokoyaki octopus balls. Must admit we didn't really like them because it tasted as though the batter was still raw. We bought a choc banana for dessert from one of the stalls then walked to Ameyoko market.

Great place to watch Sakura. This park has a large area with Sakura tree on it..just make sure you find a good spot for picture. It will be more crowded on weekend with locals who love to do picnic below the sakura tree..

Terrific park. Ueno Park is full of interesting sites--shrines, temples, monuments, museums, ponds and fountains--plus lovely greenery and places to sit amidst the concrete craziness of Tokyo. And it's surrounded by shopping and restaurants. It's one if my favourite areas in Tokyo.

Maybe would be good if you're really into parks. I've seen some really nice parks in Asia, but this isn't one of them. It's very large, and has a few different areas, but the park itself isn't anything special. I don't consider the zoo or museums to be part of the park, though. Maybe they factor into some of the good reviews.
Spacious park with lots to see!. Beautiful open space park with a large temple, zoo, and five museums. We didn't have time for the museums but walked around.

Better than last time.... I have been to Japan 7 times..stay in Ueno so came to the park once again..there are alot of museums..a zoo, street musicians..It is even a good place to people watch..I strolled around, went to the Sitamachi Museum..as I have been here a number of times..I have already gone to most museums..but there are quite a few to see..and visit..even a couple of restaurants..definitely a must see if you are in Tokyo...!
Famous place for sakura festival. Easy to go to this park, you can see sakura tree around this park. BTW you need to check period of peak bloom before coming.

Museums, Zoo and Boat Rides. Ueno park is the perfect family recreational area. It is one of the largest parks in Tokyo and it has everything to offer from a zoo to water rides on the man made pond. Feel free to check out all the other festivities, buskers and amenities the park has to offer. There is even a Starbucks just in case.

Beautiful park to wander around for hours. A park full of so many things to see and do. Lots of people using the park for walks, jogging, school excursions, temples, food stalls etc.You could spend a day just wandering around the park and it is close to shops and cafes.

Peace and green in the m middle of the city!. Many of Tokyo's museums and the zoo are located in Ueno Park, and it is a wonderful place to walk around. There are several places to eat and drink, a wonderful lake where you can sail a swan boat (!), and some peaceful shrines and temples. We just missed cherry blossom but it sold have been glorious here. A visit to the Tokyo National Museum is a must.
Beautiful Gardens. Lovely place for a stroll through the gardens. Lots of school groups around. Museums, Zoo, Water gardens, Temples, Buskers something for everyone.

Beautiful when Sakura season. Visited Ueno park when cherry blossom, grateful for that. The park was so beautiful but super crowded. Enjoyed picnic under the sakura trees with locals, ate some sushi and drank some beer. Worth to visit in other seasons, would look completely different.

Fantastic enormous park. We decided to spend some time here on our last day in Japan, and we are very glad we did. Ueno Park is situated adjacent to Ueno Station. The park grounds are very large, and several hours are required if you want to visit all the attractions or sights along the way.There's a lot of hidden treasures by way of the lake, which includes turtles and birds, in addition to the standard fare such as the statues and shrines on offer. It pays to just explore, but wayfinding is difficult, as the maps are not accurate, and some of the signs are damaged, which makes navigating a bit harder than usual.
Interesting. I guess it will be more spectacular in spring time with all blooming cherry trees, but it was also interesting - like I find all parks interesting. Also has a tample of love.

Holiday . A must to visit in Tokyo. Easy to get to by train. Enjoy strolling through the peaceful gardens and temples. Good street food also and a nice statue up a few steps where the locals give you a sweet and free green tea. Would look completely different each season. Well worth a visit.

Ueno Park. The park is located close to the Ueno JR station and is spread across a large area with nice landscaping, well laid out walking paths, dense green vegetation. It houses a few shrines, the statue of Saigo Takamori , and of course the famous Ueno Zoo.
A great place to spend the day out.
Lots to do. Ueno park has lovely plants, lots to see and do. Very popular with the locals and tourists. The museum is here as well.

Peaceful, great for a stroll. Large park with several shrines, museums, a zoo, pond, and fields of lotus. I especially liked the Inari shrine and the Buddha's head (from a ststue destroyed in a quate quake nearly a century ago). Benches to sit and look at waterfowl.

Gorgeous and huge. Positively gorgeous park, and so vast. You can walk around aimlessly for hours, looking at everything from old shrines to koi fish and newer attractions. You can even take a paddle-boat ride!

Nice park. It is a reasonable sized park with many temples, the Ueno zoo and museums. If you are visiting the zoo or the museums arrive early as they start to ask people to leave 15min before closing time.It has concrete walkways and not many places to sit on the grass but it has a really nice atmosphere and a lot of tourists.

Wonderful evening . Ueno park is a v short walk (2 min) from d ueno station.. V beautiful.. V went in May.. So couldn't get d Cherry Blossoms.. Think best time in mid March.. Had a zoo and a museum.. Which v didn't visit . Instead sat on one of d benches on d park.. And had a few sandwiches n beer.. Nice relaxing place.litle

A surprise. The park is quite pretty (would be best at Sakura of course)and houses many museums. We came across an azalea bonsai exhibit/competition. Oh my word. One of our most favorite parts of our trip!

What a place.... The best time to be here is end March early May I guess. That is the cherry blossom bloom period here. I guess we missed it by an entire month. In spite of that, this park is gorgeous. It has everything for a family outing. There is a zoo inside. If you are in mood for some peddle boating, this is the place. The complex also has museums and other places for art lovers. And if nothing interests you, just walk. It's a great place for that too. I had a great time walking here. Fantastic weather and lovely surroundings.

Wonderful afternoon visit. . We made an afternoon of walking around Ueno Park and we loved it. It was totally packed with people both local and foreign. Lots of school children on trips and young couples visiting the park. We even had a very short lived game of catch when we managed to retrieve a wayward baseball for two kids. I could go on but just let me keep it short by saying you should definitely make time to visit. You have a park, a shrine, several temples, a zoo and a museum. Worth your time for sure.
Nice stroll on a nice day. Beautiful park, Very near the train station. Terrific in early April when the cherry blossoms are in bloom

Nice park next to the Ueno train station. I had a long layover at Narita airport and wanted to see some of Tokyo. I took the Skyliner train into the city and got off at the Ueno stop. The park is located right next to the train station and is a lovely way to spend some free time. There are many and varied sights and museums throughout the park. It is hard to believe you are in a major city when strolling through the park. It was a nice way to spend some time outdoors and very convenient to the train.

So beautiful during Cherry Blossom season!. I spent a lovely morning here in early April, where I enjoyed the people watching and cherry blossoms! For this season there are mats spread out under the cherry blossom trees so people can lie and enjoy the view. There is a decent selection of street food too.
Chilling day in Ueno Park.. There is a peaceful park. You can enjoy your day by walking around this park. You will enjoy the natural park. It's also has beautiful flowers and shrine.

Great park to escape from the busy city. We originally intended just to go to the National Museum within the park's grounds but once we got to the park and saw how huge it was, we had a walk and picnic in the shade of the trees. The park is littered with statues, street performers, shaded areas, fountains and a small market. This is the perfect place for a picnic or to spend a couple of hours (or longer) escaping the city. Tag this on to before or after the National Museum or another local attraction.

Lots of attractions, easily accessible. Aside from temples, gardens and shrines, Ueno Park also houses museums and a zoo. The park is close to major train stations. There are a lot of restaurants nearby too. After a visit to the National Museum of Nature and Science, we bought some food from the shops in the train station and had a picnic lunch in the park.

Big park with museums and zoo. This is a huge park that walking around it would get you lost and tired, but all worth it. Coming from or going to Narita airport, the Kensei train station is connected to it. From our hotel at Yushima you will first approach the pond, and the left perimeter will lead you to the zoo. Coming out of the zoo inside the park there are lots of museums. There were also stalls set up in a part of the park when we got there. At the main entrance of the park where there is a statue of a man walking his dog there are lots of buildings where you can have lunch or dinner.
Love the park!. Actually i love all the park in japan....hahaha...they're all very refreshing for my eyes. Came here in mid May 16 and there was no cherry blossom, but all the trees are green.
Great spot on sunday. Everyone is out and about in a Sunday and there's great food from the stalls as well as rides and most importantly for tokyo, outdoor spaces !
Lotus Covers the Shinobazu Pond. I walked in the park with my wife. Lotus covers the Shinobazu pond, making a good contrast with the cityscape.

Absolutely beautiful park with many features. I really loved Ueno Park, and I definitely recommend it to tourists visiting Japan. There are museums here, as well as a zoo, and any of these could prove to be interesting and fun for travelers as well as locals. The park is beautiful and I recommend it!

Very pretty and scenic!. Situated at an important station (a JR station point - Ueno), called Ueno, the Ueno Park is a very scenic and pretty stretch, good for walkers and photographs. Of course, the cherry blossom only adds to the gorgeousness. We went during this season in April 2016 and were mesmerised by what we saw. Around Ueno Park, there is also a lake for boating and more sighting for the cherry blossoms! Lunch was delicious at a flea market nearby topping it up with softies!
Most Famous place for sakura. The park very famous for Hanami so if you come on sakura blossom season on weekends there will full of people that drinks under sakura tree.
Good place . Lovely park. Free and clean toilets. Close to a few good attractions like the National museum. There's a baseball area where you can watch teams playing.

Take some time to relax in Ueno Park. Nice charming park. Although it seemed a small park, we strolled around and time passed by. Not an absolute must do, but we definitely enjoyed a relaxing walk.We visited the park end of April during a weekend and a big event was held, no information found on the internet.

Huge Park, accessible through Ueno Station. This is a fairly huge park, just beside Ueno station. There are a couple of temples inside and this can be inserted in your itinerary if you want to relax and just have a laid-back stroll in the park.
Great place for culture and nature. A great park with plenty of museums and shrines as well as a vibrant park scene. Highly recommended, Do not miss the National Museum.

Amazing. It was a first time that I visited there. HANAMI festival is a tradition that I want to participate.I saw a lot of Sakura in this park,I saw a friendship at there.I was appreciated that I was the one in this park.I drank some beer at there,my wife read a book.We sat for a half day at there.I hope that I will visit this park soon as soon as possible.

Beautiful park. I have been there once. At my first visit, I was amazed, Ueno Park is beautiful. There is a lake in the centre of park. I came when Sakura was blooming, I got experience doing hanami there, under the sakura trees. It was a wonderful time, sitting together wih Japanese family and having lunch there.

Very nice. A very nice park in the heart of Ueno. I went there twice, as I happened to be staying close to the park. Sunday afternoon there were a lot of people - Monday morning it was quiet.
There are many small temples and old architecture. Lots of walking space, and very clean. I recommend.

Huge place with a lot of people. Ueno Park was of course part of our park visits in Tokyo. Supposed to the the number one park with the locals especially during Sakura and on a weekend, we still wanted to see how it felt.Well, it was packed. Picnic everywhere, people chatting, smiling, playing card and other games or just walking around enjoying time off the busy city.We saw lots of cherry blossom trees and walked around the park keeping our head turning around looking at nicer trees and nicer everything.There was some waterplace pond, where people just sat and had their picnic too.All in all, it was a nice place and an even nicer experience to go there on a weekend.When walking around, we found our way down to the streets with a bridge leading to a temple at the Shinobazu Pond. All the way to the little temple, there were market stalls selling all kind of food. It's like walking around an food market with the difference, that you somehow walk on the left hand side, so there were no pushing from others.

Great escape form the hustle of the city. In a city which is almost void of green spaces Ueno park is a large green area just to the north of central Tokyo and easily accesible by the Yanomote JR line.Yes, its a public space which does mean its popular with the locals and as already mentioned its great for people watching, especially at the weekend. If you go on a Sunday the local camera clubs are all out with more equipment kit than you see in the average camera shop. they will usually hire a model in traditional dress to stand by the lakes and flower beds whilst they snap away. And they don't mind if you sneak in and take a couple of snaps along with them.There are two largeish lakes , which are good to walk round, a smattering of shrines hidden away and it is home to Tokyo Zoo and Museums. The zoo features the giant pandas!To confirm other reviewers , this is more of a municiple park, so does not have the feeling and serenity of other Japanese Garden areas, but if you want to escape the concrete density of the City for a short while, this is a good spotif you do visit during Cherry Blossom season Ueno park is a fantastic place to visit to see the Cherry trees in all their splendour.It is traditional for the Tokyo workers to have after-work Cherry Blossom parties by picnicking underneath the Cherry trees. Office managers will send the office juniors out very early in the morning with their plastic sheets to bag a spot and sit under the tree all day until the rest of the office come early evening.you should make it a pint to visit this park. Weekends are the best for the street performers and vendors. If you want a more quite experience, week days will be better.Have fun!

Fabulous cherry blossom. We went at peak cherry blossom time when it was shoulder to shoulder - mostly with locals. However the people are polite and the views stunning so well worth it. 38m in Tokyo, 25m in the whole of Australia. Have to deal with the crowds!

Congested on the Golden Week. Ueno Park is famous for its beautiful cherry blossom (Sakura) in late March to mid April. Since it was in the month of May, Sakura was no where to be seen. It has a few museums, some kiddo rides, a zoo, Starbucks, cafés and a few eateries. The whole park was filled with people. There was a book fair during my visit. It was so crowded and there were long queues for buying tickets to the attractions and to get food. Other than some roses in the water feature area, there wasn't a lot of flowers to be seen there.Besides the park, there's a huge lake on the west side, with paddle swan boats. It also had many small food stalls around that area. To me, the place is not that great if you are not into arts and museums. I personally much prefer Shinjuku Gyoen which has more class and a lot more beautiful flowers to admire!

Beautiful park, especially during cherry blossom season!. I visited Tokyo in April. In search of cherry blossoms I visited Ueno Park and was not disappointed. The park was covered with cherry blossom and looked absolutely beautiful! It's a big park and perfect to hang out and walk through.

Loverly park with great street performances. Unfortunately we were too early for the full on cherry blossoms but Ueno Park had some early blossoming trees which were surrounded by crowds of people of all ages trying to get photos of the first cherry blossoms. We were lucky to see two street performers who were of an excellent standard.

Nice walk but crowded. The park is nice, but maybe avoid on the weekend. Doesn't help that we were there during Golden Week, but on that Monday it was insane. Couldn't hardly walk through the park, which takes away from the good bits. So go midweek.
Ueno Tōshō-gū. Well-managed Peony garden open to public only during full bloom, entrance fee is about 700 yen (adult). Worth a visit if you happens to be at Ueno Park.

Sun Bathing and Picnic. I had a great time eventhough it was not a sakura season. i was there during golden week and pretty crowded but still enjoyable. There was a bazaar in the middle of the park. You can find toilet and chair easily.

Huge, lovely park with plenty of attractions!. Park is just 5 minutes walk from the subway. But if you took Japan Rail (JR), you would see the park the moment you exited the station.Ueno Park is huge and despite spending the whole day there, we didn’t get to see all of it. Just between the Science Museum and the Zoo, we didn’t even see the other half of the Zoo and didn’t cover all exhibits in the museum.We travelled in early December, and were treated to such the lovely sight of Japan's fall colours. Golden yellow and bright red and all the hues in between. Absolutely stunning. it's rather crowded even on a weekday but the park is pretty huge and there's plenty for space for everyone. Museums surround the park - so a day there can be really little time to spend there!

Big. I thought I'd see it all but I didn't because I spent too much time at the museum and at the food stalls and entertainment they had happening in the middle. I'd say give yourself more time than a few hours if you want to get more than just a brief skim over half.It's right beside the train station so it's real easy to get from and too.I need to go back again to give it a better score than just average but a park is a park and zoo is a zoo and a museum is usually just a museum but this 'Natural Science' one had Hatchi and other interesting creatures and things.

Best Moment for Hanami (Sakura Party). I went to Ueno Park for Hanami (picnic/party drink under Sakura Trees), because the park is very famous with Sakura Trees. Me and friends start Hanami from 11 am till 6 pm, we just bring our booze (drinks, chips) and sitting in our rugs.. and since11 am,, so many people keep coming and coming to the park.. yess.. it was crowded.Even the weather is pretty cold but since we talks, and laughs, and drinks.. i think i forget that it was 10-12 Celcius :p This park is perfect to catch the Sakura blooming, and very famous to do Hanami Party. I had unforgettable moment!The park closed around 8 pm.

Garden for everybody. Ueno park has so many attractions that it has something for everybody. If you love museums this is the place, you want zoo, this is the place. U want to spend time peacefully by the pond or under the tree, this is the place.We loved this park. It has many museums. We visited the National museum. Which is great.So many people were enjoying cherry blossom and having hanami parties. We spent almost half a day here and it was worth it.Must visit. Easily reachable by subway.

Great one day spot in Tokyo. Ueno has been a very popular place among locals as it has many things to do in a day. You can enjoy a nice Ueno park which contains nice walking area (good for green or cherry blossom viewing), a small zoo for kids, some small but historical shrines and a large pond nearby. Also there are several museums at the end of the park (there are some great Japanese and western exhibitions held every now and then). On the other side of the park is a shopping area. There used to be a lot of doggy market style shops with counterfeit goods etc... which was fun to look around. It has been cleaned out recently but it still has an interesting buzzy atmosphere to enjoy. Particularly it is popular for shoes with many shoe shops (knock off prices). The one I bought was slightly cheaper than online shop. If you stay in the Tokyo station / Ginza area, this Ueno area would be a great place to visit with 15-20min train ride.

Big, beautiful, busy. There was a street festival when I went - lots to do from here (3 big museums, zoo, shrine, etc). Bring cash because there are no international ATMs inside - closest one Keisei Ueno station.

Beautiful park. This park really was a surprising gem in the middle of a big city. Immensely peaceful, with many places to sit and relax, and dotted with shrines. The shrines themselves are small for the most part but pretty and appear to be nice, out of the way, places to receive blessings etc. Food places are available but were expensive and did not look particularly appealing, so we skipped them. All in all a nice diversion.

Ueno park and ueno zoo. Nice park with lots of people during the sakura season. However it does not disappoint as the view was amazing! There were also a carnival during the time we went. Great food with amazing view. An accomplishment unlocked by me and my gf! :)
Beautiful of an evening. We spent an evening here during the blossom festival and were lucky enough to picnic under one of the many blossoms. The park was breathtaking.

Great in the spring but very busy. Visited here in April for the cherry blossom, but so did everyone else. Consequently the place was heaving. Still, in nice weather the park is still beautiful and worth a visit.There are quite a few street-food vendors, some of which have tables at which you can sit at. There's various shrines to visit, some of which have an extra charge.The zoo within the park I have reviewed separately.Also next to the parks are some museums and galleries which are worth a visit.

Hanami here is slightly disappointing. I have been there several times and I like the place because of the lots of green, museums some of which I am eager to visit, good zoo, shrine etc. It's a really popular place even among locals to hang out. The only thing that made me feel disappointed was its allegedly best season, sakura. After some hours spent in the beautiful Shinjuku garden, this hanami place was a mess. Literally messy, annoyingly loud and crowded. People didn't seem to enjoy the blooming in nice mood, it was a kind of competition to get places for their friends, meh. I left quite soon despite it is said to be one of the best sakura blossom spots in the capital.
Pretty park. The area surrounding the lake was gorgeous. There are boats for rental which you can rent to pedal around the lake.

Huge Park!. Wow this park is massive! We visited the park in Autumn after the cherry blossom had bloomed. It was lovely and green very pretty. Not too crowded and enjoy some light lunch by the pond which was lovely.

Lovely for the first days of hanami.
