A PARK WITH LOTS OF INTERESTING PLACES.. We arrived by train to visit the National Museum and found ourselves in the park which I learned was Japans first public park being opened in 1873. We did not have a lot of time to see right around the place but admired the cherry trees and thought how lovely it would be there in the spring time. There are some interesting statues to admire and we loved the water show in the big pond. There are soo many museums in the immediate area it is a museum buffs paradise. Great place for a family day out/picnic, take in the zoo as well, kids would love it.We enjoyed our short time there, not long enough.

A great place to chill out in Tokyo. A great place just to get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Full of different little areas. It also contains a great zoo.Can be busy at weekends and festival days. Easy to get to by metro.

Beautiful Tokyo park. Supposedly built on grounds donated by Kaneiji Temple before the turn of last century, Ueno Park is located right next to Ueno station. Within it, there are museums, shrines and Ueno Zoo. Visited in summer and I can only imagine the sight upon visiting in spring when it is cherry blossom season.

Famous park with museum and zoo. Ueno Park (上野公園, Ueno Kōen) is a large public park next to Ueno Station in central Tokyo. The park grounds were originally part of Kaneiji Temple, which used to be one of the city's largest and wealthiest temples and a family temple of the ruling Tokugawa clan during the Edo Period. Kaneiji stood in the northeast of the capital to protect the city from evil, much like Enryakuji Temple in Kyoto.During the Boshin Civil War, which followed the Meiji Restoration in 1868, Kaneiji suffered nearly complete destruction in a battle between the victorious forces of the new Meiji government and loyalists of the overthrown shogunate. After the battle, the temple grounds were converted into one of Japan's first Western style parks and opened to the public in 1873. A statue of Saigo Takamori, one of the generals in the Battle of Ueno, stands near the park's southern entrance.Ueno Park during the cherry blossom seasonAt the southwestern end of the park lies Shinobazu Pond, one of many reminders of Kaneiji Temple's former grandeur. The pond represents Lake Biwako (in a reference to Kaneiji's model, the Enryakuji Temple of Kyoto, which overlooks Lake Biwako). On an island in the middle of the pond stands Bentendo, a temple hall dedicated to the goddess of Benten.Today Ueno Park is famous for the many museums found on its grounds, especially the Tokyo National Museum, the National Museum for Western Art, the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum and the National Science Museum. It is also home to Ueno Zoo, Japan's first zoological garden.Additionally, Ueno Park is one of Tokyo's most popular and lively cherry blossom spots with more than 1000 cherry trees lining its central pathway. The cherry blossoms are usually in bloom during late March and early April and attract large numbers of hanami (cherry blossom viewing) parties.

A beautiful park. This place is filled with museums, art galleries, exhibits and even a zoo. If you're a fan of museums and arts, this is the place for you. For everybody, its just great to stroll along the park and also good idea to have a picnic if the weather is good.
Large and Beautiful.. Such a large, beautiful, quite park in town... You must visit at least one museum around this park..
Lovely Park. We went here as a break from the busy streets and really enjoyed it. The park is also a good choice.

Nice for Sakura. Easily get to Ueno Park by subway. Subway pass is truly worth for visiting Tokyo city centre. Ueno park is really huge. I went during Sakura season and saw beautiful Sakura in different types ;) We can also lunch or picnic under the Sakura trees as locals did. Nice ambience!

Tokyo best view for spring. I really love this park! It is a huge park full with sakura trees all the way, pink here and there. So many people doing hanami (flower viewing) with their friends and family. Many tenant selling food near its shrine. You better do not sit at some empty chair if you are not buying something from it stall because the seller will upset. You can enjoy walking with your family but beware of drunkard though there were securities here and there. Very nice for sightseeing and talking pictures from dawn to dusk.
walk about. Great place to walk around and see the culture of Japan. There is a great little zoo. They have a natural science museum.

Just simply beautiful!. Ueno Park is just simply beautiful. I visited the park for the first time in October 2014 and then twice in 2015 just to see the falling leaves and cherry blossom. Lots of good places to eat close by and the most famous market is just right next to the park, You have to visit Ueno park if you go to Tokyo :)
Beautiful park. Beautiful park centrally located within walking distance from Ueno train station. Lots of people watching as well.
Nice place for a walk. It is a nice place to go for a walk on a sunny day. Plenty of things to do nearby - the zoo, museums, coffee shops.

Relaxing break from the surrounding city. Ueno Park is perfect for a stroll after lunch in one of the nearby restaurants or cafes. There are a few shrines, and if you're lucky you'll come across one of the cats (who I assume live nearby) often roaming around. Although there aren't really any green spaces for picnics or relaxing, there are plenty of benches and a large fountain to sit down and people-watch for an hour or so; in addition to a baseball court and a few museums. Ueno Zoo is also located within the park, which offers a good variety of animals for the entry fee (600 yen if I remember correctly; much cheaper than London Zoo in the UK which is less exciting). If you have half a day or even a full day to spare, I'd recommend checking the park out!

Discover the park. I came to the 上野 park without knowing what to expect. I just entered and started to move around.It was simply marvellous to see things I did not expect there. The 上野 park has a lot to surprise you. So if you like to be surprised go to the 上野 park near the station. It is worth to be seen.

Nice park for the cherry blossoms!. We were to late for the cherry blossoming this time, but I have been here before in the end of march and this place is amazing when the trees are in full blossom. Go, but try to make it end march/beginning of april.
HOT. we went on a Monday and i was sad to see that the zoo was shut :( other than that the park was really hot had lots of things to see and a really nice relaxing feeling.
Relaxing park. Beautiful for strolling and spend time. In between our busy schedules we always tried to manage some time to come here and enjoy the fresh air ...

Mainly for the locals. This park is mainly for the locals to get away from the city streets on a weekend, but as a tourist it was a nice stroll and on the sunday when we were there you could see lots of street entertainers. And a starbucks coffee by the pond in the sun was quite OK before taking the metro back into the big city.

Beautiful park, great for Sakura. Lovely park. We visited during Sakrua, so it was crazy busy, but absolutely lovely with all cherry trees. There are also a few national museums in on end of the park worth visiting if you like art and history.

Incredible Place to Start. This was my first place to visit in Tokyo and it was totally worth it. From the paddle boat ride in the Park, to the shrines and temples. Its a little slice of beauty among the hustle and bustle. Also great for people watching. Make sure to go and look at the incredibly old tree at the top. The tree grew in a circle and the view is incredibly from there.
Oldest zoo. For being the oldest zoo in Japan. it's great place to visit close to train station. Easy to walk around the zoo.

Cherry blossom heaven. We were so luck with our timing to visit this amazing city. The cherry blossom was in full bloom on our first day and it was also glorious sunshine. It was very busy but that didn't detract from the beauty of the blossoms and the way the air was filled with petals - like snow. This was a great place to see the cherry blossoms - we didn't find anywhere else that matched up to be honest. There were also plenty of cultural festivities happening in and around the park which made it feel more magical. Would not recommend this for those who get claustrophobic in crowds though as we were pretty crammed most of the time.
Beautiful piece of paradice. Bit disappoint in the Zoo but still ok, the park is beautiful and would look amazing with the blossoms out, very clean and tidy as is all of japan lots of photo moments

Great location for a relax place with awesome Cherry Blossom viewing or so call Hanami in japanese.. Although when i went all the cherry blossom is gone and it was raining but the park rank one of the best 100 cherry blossom view in Japan. Also there are many national museum in the park which has many national treasure and other exhibition available at very reasonable price.
Beautiful Park. Ueno park is really big, beautiful and peaceful park and have many museums around. Can spend 1 whole day there.

Always worth a visit. I walk through here every time I come to Japan. It's a bit of a peaceful oasis in the middle of the city. The lake has boats and swan paddle boats to try out (700Y) and if it's open (which it wasn't on this particular day, a Monday) then the zoo is also worth walking through. There is a lovely shrine in the park, and it's great for people watching.
Must see Spring. This place is a must in Spring, it's just picture perfect. I was in Japan for most of March and the Japanese people are so friendly and helpfulBazza

Too crowded on weekends to be enjoyable. We read about many things to do in Ueno Park. Maybe it was unfortunate that we went on a Saturday hoping to explore the park and the famous cherry blossoms. The place was so crowded with people. With the blue plastic mats on the grounds for picnics, it was not picturesque nor pleasant. I don't know of I will bother to go back in future.

A big park with a lot of activities within.. There are a lot of things to do in the park, which I'll list later, since you can just look it up on the map. Although there are a lot of trees, this park is more concrete pathways than natural forest. There are baseball fields, play grounds, and even what is left of a smaller amusement park rides just outside Ueno Zoo. This is definitely a good place to people watch, especially in the main courtyard, which is a huge, open concrete walkway. Students from Tokyo University walk in a line straight from their campus to the Ueno Station nearby. And there is even one of the largest Starbucks locations I saw in Japan. This park has so much in it, I found myself lost at times, trying to find the right path to the right places. For the life of me, I couldn't find Toshogu Shrine.There are several museums to keep you occupied: The National Museum, Museum of Nature and Science, Metropolitan Art Museum, and the Museum of Western Art.Toshogu Shrine and Gojoten Shrine are on the grounds, as well as Shinobazu Pond.As said, Ueno Zoo also sits within these grounds, which is one reason there are so many playgrounds here and there on the park grounds.Although on the outer-ring of Tokyo, this park is still a moderns structure. You'll be sitting on concrete more than grassy fields. This is a people watching paradise, not at the same level as Harajuku, but more organic and natural. Ameyoko Street is nearby, along with a plethora of restaurants and shops in case you find your way out of Ueno Park.

Good for relax . This park and nearby Zoo (need to buy ticket) are very good relaxing opportunity after discoveryng big and crowded city Tokyo.Many locals are visiting park and enjoying the atmosphere. Zoo is very well organized and clean with giant pandas inside.Recommended.

A calm place in a speedy city. Ueno park is a nice place for a calm break during your full day of visits in Tokyo. Relax on a bench under one of the tree's shadow, browse the few temples, take a round around the pond.A lot of animations take place during summer. While we were there there was a bonsai expo, a small market, a breakdance exhibition and a few others.

In a big city, you've gotta see their big park.... Nice park, but nothing to rave about as compared to other major parks in the world's great cities. We didn't see the zoo, but strolled around and covered most of it.

Nice park and fantastic museum(s). I only explored the Tokyo National Museum but spent a LOT of time there and loved the Japanese and other Asian art. Park itself is very pleasant and features other museums.

Best time to relax and people watch. I would recommend even just a quick stroll to this park! It's big and plenty of museums to go to! I went to both the national museum and the nature and science and both were great!
Ueno is well worth a visit for many reasons.... Great place to wander around, enjoy plant life, food, beer, exhibitions, and just enjoy the locals enjoying the park.

Sakura. Ueno park comes into its own during Sakura when thousands of Tokyoites decend en masse to revel in the blossoms. Parties go on literally until dawn with food and drink. There are also a number of incredible specimen Camellias plus the zoo, museum, and pond with paddle boats.

Nice park with several museums + activities. I came here on my own while in Tokyo for a short week trip -- I'm a huge art / history nerd, so when I saw the various museums listed, I decided Ueno would be my first start. It was a good day visit because the museums are pretty cheap by American / European standards ($5 entry usually). I went to the Western Art museum, which I enjoyed, and then the Metropolitan Museum to see a special British Museum exhibit (100 objects) -- that ticket was a bit more expensive but I wanted to see the show -- I was disappointed it was mostly in Japanese (including the audio guide) but there was some English and I still enjoyed it given my background and knowledge.I decided to skip the National Museum because I'd heard mixed reviews, so I walked around the park, visited the shrine and temple there, walked around the lake, had lunch across the street at a sushi restaurant, and came back for the Shitamachi Museum.Taken together, it was a good day that made me feel like I hit a few things I wanted to see. I went to the Senso-ji Temple at Asakusa a few days later, and since they're pretty close, I'd recommend doing both in one day. You can either take the subway a few stops from the Ueno park Yamanote line stop or just walk the 20-30 minutes over.

A big park with a wonderful pond. Ueno Park is quite big. I prefer to hang out by the Shinobazu pond (near Ueno zoo) where turtles and koi fish are. There are many benches where people just sit to hang out and do nothing. It's wonderful to have such parks in the middle of a busy, bustling city.
So much to do here!. There is so much to do at Ueno park you can easily spend a whole day here. Close to many museums, a zoo and shrines. You may also have a picnic and watch people go by.

Always something to see!. This park is very fun because there are alway kooky performers either doing magic tricks or dancing. The sights are picturesque, so even if you go just to sit and read a book, it's worth your time!

park for the tourists & the dailies. We stayed in the Ueno area, so the park was enroute most of the days. The park itself is big and beautiful, with clear sections to visit... so for those who plan ahead (like me) you can easily do a circuit to cover the main attractions easily and quickly.About the park: the park has 4 sections, the park itself (trees, walkways, etc), a national museum, a small lake (beautiful to stroll around) and the Ueno zoo (which we didn't cover). There are walking guides that you can easily download from many sites and they tell you what There is a big open space and a Starbucks to sit at. Worth just imbibing the ambiance and sipping coffee!

Nice walk. It was very nice to walk there after visiting the National Museum. It was Sunday and many Japanese families had a free time here, there were some artists dancing and singing snd atmosphere was really relaxing. If you want to quit the crowd and feel chilled, Ueno Park is a good choice in Tokyo.

Very big park. It was a very big park with a lot of temples to go to, and it's a short walk to the Metropolitan Museum. It was raining when I got there last May but I enjoyed strolling in there. Definitely bring an umbrella because the nearest konbini is near the train station which is quite a walk away.

Free guided tour of Ueno Park. We enjoyed a walk around Ueno Park with a Goodwill Guide,Jun. Great explanations as we strolled around for about 90 minutes, giving explanations of different buildings and just enough history to keep us informed. After lunch just opposite, we went back to one of the museums. The guides give them time for free and are to be congratulated on their friendly service.
A quick walk around with a friend.. It was just a quick wander around whilst meeting our friend, but it was pretty, clean and had a relaxing atmosphere.
Great place. A nice place to relax and unwind after going around the city... You can also visit the Ueno Zoo so easy to get around just use your gps or the good old tourists map ☺
Lovely Park. This is a lovely park near the Zoo and National Museum of Nature and Science. Would be great to visit when the cherry blossoms are in bloom.

So beautiful during cherry blossom, even at night!. We arrived at the park after 7pm on the cherry tree blossom week and it was so beautiful.. Making me planning to go again next year during day time.

Very pretty park. There's are a couple of much less crowded temples in the park (I went there right after Sensoji temple) so found it much more peaceful and welcoming. I missed cherry blossom season but could imagine one of the paths full of pink trees.

A must visit for Hanami season!. They have around 1000 cherry trees in the park. SO visiting there in the hanami season is a mesmerizing experience. Go with family, friends and carrry food and drinks, reserve a place to party in beautiful nature

Possibly my favourite part of our Tokyo trip. The title says it all. We did so many amazing things in Tokyo and Ueno park was definitely one of my favourites. Unfortunately we had just missed the best of the cherry blossom but still, this park is magical. If you're staying relatively close by as we were, I strongly recommend arriving early in the morning just after sunrise. The light was so beautiful on the lake. There are so many lovely things to see and do. You will need at least half a day here. The lake is lovely with herons and terrapins as well as a temple and swan boat rides. The National Museum is located here as well as the zoo which we skipped because of negative reviews. Great memories of this park.

don't miss Ueno if you are in Tokyo. Ueno is one of the most interesting places in Tokyo, with the Zoo being the highlight. It's so easy to get to with Ueno station right across the road, and the station isn't one of those confusing enormous underground ones. You come right out and cross the road and you are there.

So much to do, very pretty. Our rental apartment was across the street from Ueno Park so we walked along the path around the pond every day to get to the train station. It's a nice quiet area as you pass paddle boats and a small shrine. next to this is the Zoo where they have 2 Panda bears. The zoo is really cheap. children are $1.50. We saw the panda bears - so CUTE!! Plus they have a lot of other animals. Also in the park is a baseball field, several museums and another shrine. It's a really big park. On days my husband didn't want to go to Akihabara, we split up and he went to museums in Ueno park or watched baseball practice. One day while walking through, we were treated to watching a group do Japanese dance. It was great! Park has an opening right next to Ueno station.

Nice for a stroll and to get away from the hordes. I had a headache from the plane flight and needed an area of serenity. This filled the bill, open space, some nice water and even a Starbucks in the centre. It worked a few hours strolling and a cafe and my headache was gone!

Nothing Special but Any Park in a City the Size of Tokyo Is Refreshing. This is the largest and oldest park in Japan. There are not many parks in Tokyo, so that makes Ueno Park special. The most significant attraction would be the cherry trees during spring blossom time, but we missed that time of year. There are several museums to visit, none of which are anything special but each worth a quick look. There is also a small zoo (did not visit) and a couple of shrines, which did not impress.We found the park to be poorly maintained, and the gardening to be of poor quality. The large ponds have dirty, murky, stagnant water, so we were not attracted to them. You can rent a pedal boat and cruise around the main pond.......mainly a hit with the kids.Overall, a pleasant visit for a day or two, but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit Ueno Park.

lovely and relaxing. good for kids.there is a little amusement park, playground, big starbucks, nice lawns for picnics. Nearby there are all the major museums and Galleries. Ueno station is very big and a bit confusing, I got lost but people were nice and helped me.
An oasis in the busy city. Love the beautiful walkways, with the beautiful gardens all around. A number of years ago when we went there, enjoyed a paddle boat rental. A great place to people-watch.

Great park in the middle of the city. This park is a lovely park right in the middle of the city. It is on the jr line so is free to get to if you have a japan rail pass and just traveling on the jr lines. There is lots to see and do in the park, several museums and even a zoo.

Great way to spend a morning. Travelled here on my own. Close to station and really fell in love with the structures. Give yourself a few hours so you can stop into the zoo on your way out. Be warned, the zoo can be sad unless you ignore the inhumanity of captivity. But it's got a lot of interesting animals and not too hard on the wallet. Definitely start the day with this as it's not so much a must-do-destination but well worth stepping away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.
Very nice and big park.. The park is very suitable for families with children because there is Ueno ZOO and very nice fountain. There are also temples - Kaneiji, Kiyomizu Kannon, Toshogu.
Nice views. Park with good cherry blossom views and nice temples, good food around - I recommend Ichiran Ramen which is delicious

Popular and lively park in Tokyo. Ueno Park is a large park next to Ueno Station in Tokyo (the easiest access is provided by the station's "Park Exit"). The park's attractions are: Kiyomizu Kannon Temple, Toshogu Shrine, Bentendo Temple, Tokyo National Museum, Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum.
Full day fun. Absolutely beautiful! Temples, gardens, animals, restaurants. You can spend your entire day with your family here. Very close from the metro station, just a few minutes walk

Lovely Day in the Park. We visited on a Saturday and the park was full of delightful families. There was some sort of a festival, including food tents, which offered yakitori chicken and steak on a stick - delicious. There was a strange exhibition of traditional dancing and a child-oriented show with the big "animal/cartoon" costumed characters that the Japanese seem to love. We also visited the Japanese National Museum and saw lovely exhibits of netsuke, kimono, screens, armour, and scrolls.

Cherry Blossom and Hanami. Visited Ueno Park on April 2015. I was lucky enough to see the park with Cherry Blossom. It was just stunning! When i came, there was Hanami, a local picnic party to enjoy the park during cherry blossom period. Not only that, on the other side of the park, there were bazaar that sells local food and beer, tea drinking ceremony, and also traditional music performance. So many people come around, If you bring kids, make sure you keep an eye to them.

An oasis near Ueno station. This is a great place to relax and walk around the park. Close to Ueno station, the park has many museums, historical monuments and a zoo. On weekends there are many street performers entertaining the crowds.

An evening stroll. Our first stop after arriving in Tokyo, early evening so peaceful strolling around the park we just caught the end of cherry blossom but still a lovely park, stopped of at one shrine we saw statues a playground, a zoo and museums. We returned on Saturday morning had breakfast alfresco did some people watching old and young a great place.

Beautiful even without the cherry blossoms. We missed the cherry blossoms but the park is still lovely. So many stone lanterns, temples and if I was with children, I would go to the zoo. Several good museums there too.

Stunningly beautiful with lines of cherry blossoms. The park is absolutely beautiful when the cherry blossoms are in bloom. I'm sure even when they are not fully in bloom it still must be stunning. There are a couple of temples to visit when walking around which was an extra bonus to my husband and I. Our favorite part was just the people watching. The crowd ranged from young school kids to older adults, very family friendly and the zoo is there (which we visited also). There are also a couple of street food vendors with sticks of bbq meat, super inexpensive and tasty. If you're in the area, I highly recommend a visit!

visit in the height of sakura season. You should visit during the cherry season. You can have full hanami experience--lots of blossoms, people, and beers! Kanei-ji (Kanei Temple) charges you to enter, but it is very pretty and well maintained, so I highly recommended to take a look. It's worth for below $10. It is very similar with the one in Nikko (very famous Toshyo-gu), so it is a good substitute if you have no time to go to Nikko.

Huge park, lots to do in nearby attractions. A quick visit to the park with my family. My son found the Ueno play park and that was that soon after we entered the area but he was also riding on his scooter and running happily along these long alleyways. There are places to get food and drink - some pizza place next to the samurai statue, Starbucks next to the zoo etc. There may be some buskers near the museum so you can spend a good few hours exploring all these things.

Nice Place to Enjoy the Time. Take a walk in ueno Park give me warm feeling. I really like the atmosphere and the environment there. The place is full with the trees. And sometimes you can find the performance of street performers here. There is also lake which you can ride a boat with your friends or loved ones.

Amazing free performances!. Ueno park was by far the best attraction we went to during our trip to Japan. The park is beautifully maintained and there were many performers who were all very talented. We enjoyed the acrobatics as well as the artists who came to the park, making our trip so memorable. The park is located close to the train stations as well as museums.

Both a large Park plus the National Zoo. The Ueno Park contains a very well organized Zoo. Right near the entrance you will find the attraction that everyone heads for. The Pandas. Their exhibit is very well set up and you will get a good view of these playful animals as they play and eat. The organization of the Zoo is well planned for you to walk and be able to see all of the attractions. Access to the park and Zoo is easy as quite a few Metro an JR lines converge on the park and make it accessible from all parts of the city.

Lovely long walks. Nestling within the busy city, this park is a lovely break from routine. One can take a long walk between the trees to visit some ancient shrines tucked away in corners, or watch performers entertain onlookers in little clearings. Plenty of flowering plants, some cafes and easy access to the metro make this a beautiful park to visit.

Busy Park. A very busy park on a Sunday morning, but nevertheless a pleasnt diversion from the overall mania of Tokyo streets. Plenty of activities going on to just people watch or alternatively museums and galleries available for a cultural top up.
Nice Park. It is nice if you walk around Ueno Park in the morning or afternoon, just to enjoy the view. Or you can go to the Zoo inside the Park. And they also have Starbucks. :)

Great Park for exploring. Ueno park links on to the Ueno Zoo , and a few Museums so it is a large area plenty to see during the walk give yourself half a day if you wander into some of the buildings there are entrance fee's to some

Lovely. This is a lovely park, lots of interesting things to see (make sure you bring a map). When you're tired from all that touristy walking about go take a rowing boat out onto the lake and rest up, a lovely respite. Just beside the park is Ameya Yokocho Street Market, which is well worth a look. On one of the streets in the market there is a little open bar on a corner, stop and have a snack and watch the world go by.

A green oasis. Ueno Park is a huge 300 acre park located outside Ueno Station. Here, you can find Ueno Zoo, Tokyo National Museum and National Museum of Western Art amongst other attractions. We missed the cherry blossoms but saw the peony festival . Entrance fee was not cheap but it was worth it to admire huge blossoming peonies up close. It was also during the Golden Week and the park was filled with people. Word of advice : do not queue to buy museum tickets at the ticket booth just inside the park. After waiting for 20 minutes, we were told they only sell tickets for special exhibitions. Go to the main museum entrance and get your tickets there.
Beautiful Park Ever we have seen. We go there in April for sakura. It is really very beautiful. You can watch Japanese enjoying singing, dancing and eating together. It is called hanami.

Nice green park in Tokyo. Ueno park is just outside of the Ueno station. This park is well maintained and you can see thousands of people around on weekends.Museum, Ameyokocho, Akihabara, sumo stadium is near by attractions.This place is popular for cherry blossom and you can see and enjoy real Japanese culture by "Hanami" in the month of April during period of sakura.Autumns are also beautiful and everything turn red and yellow. This is must visit place in Tokyo.
Take a walk. This meandering park is a delight in the concrete jungle of Tokyo. Look out for the peony gardens. The cherry blossoms were delightful and overall, loved it.

A Beautiful Place.... Ueno Park is a very nice place to visit. The park is very big and it is conveniently located near the UENO Station.The park has a pond and also few temples within which can be visited.It is also in close proximity with various restaurants where you can have your breakfast post your morning walks.

Last day in Tokyo. Right across the train station. A beautiful park with lots of museums and shrines and a nice area to enjoy an afternoon. Down the street from the station there is a small outdoor market. The museums are closed on Mondays so we missed them but you can spend an entire day here.

Nice park with Panda - district good for eating and shopping.. It is somehow a touristic place but also just a park. People go there to see Pandas - unfortunately I was not able to do so, as it was too late (check hours!). One bar restaurant only. After dark not so nice to visit as there is limited amount of lamps. I like more the nearby area where you may find casinos and "play" houses and a big street market (perfect place to try untypical food or buy some clothes. A lot of small pubs and good prices for dinner. Ueno metro station nearby is good for every direction.

best spot in Autumn. I went there in Autumn. We can get here easily by subway. From the nearest station, we simply walk to the park. No entrance fee charged unless you wanna go to the zoo or museum nearby. If u r so keen about history, there are several museums in the area. I was lucky that at the time I visited the park, there was a dance performance. There were also a lot of traditional foodstalls. I wouldnt mind staying here a whole day watching some birds and enjoy the autumn

Lovely for a stroll. Really nice park in the north east of Tokyo. Has nice lake/big ponds to walk around as well as a host of museums. The park is next to the train station which is a hub as subway and JR lines available.

Another Don't-Miss Destination. Easy access by subway takes you to this beautiful park. The highlight of the part is the National Museum with a fine collection of contemporary and ancient Japanese art. Lots of restaurants in the area, so you can spend a day in the area with no problem.

A lovely park.. This is a lovely (and huge!) park.The park is located next to the Ueno station (within a 5-minute walk).It consists of several temples, a beautiful pond with huge water lillies and some paddle boats.The park also offers several museums and galleries.The park is best enjoyed during the day, as it is not that well lit after dark.

Definite must in Cherry Blossom season. I was there in the first week of April and it was THE time for seeing cherry blossoms. The park is huge and has over 8,000 trees, of which 800 are cherry blossoms. It was beautiful to wander around under the canopy of blossom trees, and when there was a slight breeze, it would "rain" blossoms. The park is also used by the locals to have picnics under the trees ... and there are also many stalls scattered throughout where you can purchase something to eat. While I myself didn't go there, people from my tour visited the zoo inside the Park and said it was actually a really good zoo and worth a visit.

A beautiful place.. This is a very beautiful place in the city center. Full of Japanese. In this place you can see ordinary Japanese. On weekends you can buy cheap and popular food, row in a boat or just sit and relax.

Beguiling Cherry Blossoms !. The family visited the park last Apriland the cherry blossoms were just mesmerizing ! They were all over the park and it feels like one is in paradise. Merry making was part of the cherry blossoms feastival and people young and old were sitting under the trees laughing, talking and enjoying the food ! Love our stay there !
Nice park but not the best in Tokyo. This was a lovely park and worth the trip if you have lots of time to spare. If you are short on time Koraku Park is much much better.

5 stars when cherry blossoms are in bloom, nice park year round. My colleagues and I visited the park for a few hours on April 2nd, which appears to be the peak day for the cherry blossoms in 2015. There were hundreds of cherry trees in bloom and 10s of thousands of people, more than I have ever seen in one place. Imagine the crowd exiting a major sporting event and it is exactly like this all day. On the paths, everyone was walking slowly looking at the people and the blossoms and taking lots of pictures. Off the path, every square inch is packed with tarps with people partying on them. Make shift tables out of boxes held their food and lots of Saki was flowing. There were also street vendors selling food and drinks, including alcohol. We went to dinner nearby and came back in the evening. The blossoms are spectacular at night lit up by strings of lanterns. The crowd was only slightly smaller, but there were less children. I took about 250 pictures while I was there and all of them could be a screen saver.
Ueno Park. A lovely large open space where you can find superb gardens 3 Museums and an excellent Zoo plus a children's amusement park all of which is just across the road from Ueno Park Station
Get your dates right. If you want to see cherry blossoms make sure you book early April. It's a big park so be prepared to walk. Wear comfy shoes.

Much to see in this historical park. During the cherry blossom period is perhaps the best time to visit this park. There are more than 8 museums and art galleries, the zoo (with panda beer), theatres and schools in this green area in the middle of Tokyo. There is a baseball ground, a beautiful pond with lotus floors, Japanese and western stile restaurants, temples and shrines. Right now it is worth visiting Toshogu shrine, which had been renovated and is now open to the public. There are homeless people here and there. They are not dangerous and live almost hidden behind the forests. It is sad to see them but they somehow belong to this park.

Take your camera and enjoy this Park..... Ueno is a large beautiful park and although I my visit was in late April just after the Cherry Blossom Festival, some of the cherry trees were still in blossom. There's so much to see, Buddhist Shrines and Pagodas, so make sure you have your camera with you. The park houses a zoo and Museum, although when I visited it was a sunny day so I did not want to waste the sunshine. You can hire a bike for 300 JPY a day or 200 JPY for 4 hours, however I was happy just walking and taking photos... One advantage about my visit in late April, (although this was not planed just luck), there were not so many visitors as during the festival.Ueno's busy suburban area also has a fantastic market, which is well worth a visit.

Amazing park. This is much more than just a park. There is so much to see. There are loads of temples and religious sights, there are a few museums, a lake, great street food and of course, Tokyo National Museum. If you're lucky to be there during the cherry blossom season, the main walking street is stunning.

Many Attractions to Take Your Eye. This is a very large park with many attractions including paddlo swans, temples, parkland and, when we were there, wonderful cherry blossoms to have you snapping away with your camera. It's adjacent to a busy suburban area with good transport, shops and places to eat and spend your money. Wonderful.

Cherry Blossom Paradise. Beautiful park, especially during Cherry Blossom season.Well maintained, clean, clear signage's, stunning views, Shrines, lake, wildlife including turtles, carps and birds make this park a must go; and the best of all...there is no entry fee!

Cherry Blossoms and So Many People. When I arrived at JR Ueno Station at 9:30am on 30th March, there were already so many people going though the Park Exit of the station. Firstly I went to see Hideyo Noguchi's bronze statute in the park. Then, I went through the tunnel of cherry blossoms among so many people. Cherry blossoms were also beautiful along Shinobazu-no-ike Pond, and there were so many people, too. Many people were having picnic lunch, that was their tradition. I felt like seeing the people more than cherry blossoms.

Beautiful place to see cherry blossums. Located right next to the JR Ueno station, the park is easily accessible and is a great place to spend a few hours walking around and seeing the beautiful cherry blossums. Excellent street food available in the area too.

my daughter loves it. the park is an ordinary park, nothing so special, but we all love it. it is only a few minutes walk from urno station. we were there on sunday when there were performances and food vendors. it was a nice place especially for your kids to play at the playground and for you just to watch your kids play. there is a zoo in the same compound. unfortunately, we didn't have time to check it out.

Spend an entire day here. It's a beautiful park with a lot of things to see. There's a zoo and a lot of different kinds of museum. You should allot at least a day to be able to see everything in the park, it's really big. We were only able to go to the zoo, and the entrance fee was worth it. They had the usual zoo animals but the place itself was beautiful and clean, even in the indoor cages.

Beautiful!!!. Visited 1st week of April with fully bloomed sakura. Awesome view!! Lots of photo taking opportunities. One can go early and have a picnic under the sakura trees. We were there for about 2~3 hours. There is a pond with activities like boat paddling, etc. We even walked all the way to The University of Tokyo which is nearby.We went back again the evening as we heard that the night view is awesome too which is 100% correct. The atmosphere is different, both equally awesome and breath taking.
Rained out and rcrowded. I had high hopes of seeing the cherry blossoms but my hopes were dashed along with thousand others due to rain. The cherry blossoms started falling early due to the rain.

Nice if there are sakura trees in bloom or shows to be seen. We went directly after the sakura seasons but saw some shows in the park and had nice snacks and sweets which were sold around the stage area.
Well worn park. A park with museums, zoo, boating lakes, shrines & temples means that it is well used & far from pristineThere are much nicer parks to visit in Tokyo

Great oasis of peace in bustling Tokyo. Set in the busy northern Tokyo area, this park is a real jewel and a place to escape from the urban life.If you want to explore all it offers you'll need at least half a day. You can easily access it by metro or JR line at the Ueno station. Best time to visit is in spring sakkura of course, the cherry blossom season.Aside from peaceful and beautiful paths with benches along the way, Ueno park offers a big pond with boats to hire, the oldest Tokyo Zoo with Pandas to meet, few shrines, National Science museum and Tokyo National museum.

Good Park in Tokyo. Located near one of the bigger station in Tokyo, Ueno Park offers not only sight but also some attractions inside. There is a temple and shrine inside, lots of cherry blossom trees and also when we visited it, there were art performers on the park. Toilet was rather dirty but despite of that it is a great place to visit, and it's free!!
Extensive park but a bit boring. Lush green (I missed the cherry blossom season) and lots of people walking..a bit boring really...and mind you, you can't walk on the grass!

Lazy Sunday's Outing!. We did what the locals do, go to Ueno Park on a nice sunny Sunday, bring a picnic, stroll around the park, enjoy a peony garden in full bloom, watch dancers and listen to musicians playing music. It was surprising to see also quite a bit of school-children in uniform enjoying this Sunday outing. The National Museum of Tokyo is also located here. The big entrance lane is lined with gorgeous cherry blossom trees. Unfortunately their prime time was passed but nevertheless they looked majestic. This is a Sunday outing one should not miss as it gives an insight in the daily lives of the locals.

The best cherry blossom park at night. During the Cherry Blossom Festival the park is illuminated with lanterns at night with many parties underneath the trees. It had a real atmosphere and buzz as many happy Japanese people drank and ate. I really wanted to join in. They sold some beers along the walk way and we walked around leisurely. It was really enjoyable and an insight into Japanese culture. And of course the flowers were beautiful.

Another beautiful park. Tokyo have lots of beautiful park, Ueno park is one of it. Especially in cherry blossom season i think everybody should come there and enjoy the atmosphere. Take a walk around and you'll forget that you're in a middle of a metropolitan city
nice sakura spot in tokyo mid area. conveniently located in a central location. visited in mid april 2015. nice place to have a stroll around.

Strange. Went to see the Cherry Blossom- plenty of it & plenty of tourists especially old ones, but not much greenery. Not a park in the European sense-too much concrete for my liking.Also has a Zoo & museums but we ran away.

Nice to go to see Sakura. I went in the Sakura season. Of course, there were lots of Sakura trees with flowers. But, there isn't much difference with some other places where Sakura can be seen, such as beside the stream nearby my apartment. I actually didn't see much difference. But, no problem with going there, as it is free of charge.

The best cherry blossom spot in Tokyo. The best spot for the cherry blossom season. I was lucky to be there during swing of the blossom. Again to go there was also idea of others so even morning mid week was completely busy. But still I enjoyed my visit on a nice sunny day to see blossom, people taking pictures and enjoying sakura blossom while having picnic. Just short walk form Uedo station.

Cherry Blossom Wonderland. We went on a gorgeous sunny day while the cherry blossoms were in full bloom (March 31, 2015). So fortunate! Thousands of excited people were having hanami parties and celebrating the season. WOW. We got caught up in the excitement of it all. There was a festive air with street vendors selling food (where we ate lunch). We also went to the Tokyo National Museum while here. Of course cherry blossoms happen a short time each year. Not sure what the park is like the rest of the year.

A full day of sites and sounds and museums. A full day of sites and sounds and museums in Ueno park pronounced "Wayno". This beautiful park is surrounded by world class museums, a shrine, a lake, and it has the best zoo in the world for $6.00 USD. Relax while walking the tree line paths to the next attraction. I go here every time I am in Tokyo. Don't miss it.
Hanami. We visited in the evening at the height of cherry blossom season. Cherry blossom party central. Very crowded. beautiful cherry trees.

Great culture center and place to relax!. Ueno Park is a huge public park close to Ueno Station in Tokyo.The park includes a lot of museums such as Tokyo National Museum, the National Museum for Western Art, the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum and the National Science Museum. It is also home to Ueno Zoo, Japan's first zoological garden.The park is also famous for cherry blossom in spring time. Among the parks there are round 10.000 trees in several varieties of sakura.Another spot in the park is Shinobazu Pond - a large natural pond that's partially covered in lotus plants.There are boats for rent in the eastern portion of the pond. Great place to visit!

Best viewed during cherry blossom season. I went to this park on two different occasions, autumn and spring. As much as I liked the view of autumn red nothing beats the view of Ueno park during hanami. Hundreds of cherry blossom trees in full bloom, especially by the lagoon. It was a breathtaking view! They also illuminate cherry blossoms at night when it's at it peak. Ueno park is conveniently located right outside of Ueno station. There's also a lot to do here from museums, shrines, Ueno zoo and even the dining options. A recommended place to visit when in Tokyo.

Not good on Monday's. I am afraid that this area like all major tourist sites throughout the world is mainly closed on a Monday. Most of the National Museums were closed. The weather did not help, being rather wet and miserable. Went to see the last remnants of the cherry blossom, had missed the timing by 2 weeks. There is a lot to see and do in this area, although on a nicer day it would have been lovely. Bigger than what I expected, got lost and took 20-30 mins to get on track.

A haven of trees and culture in a busy spot. Just go and enjoy all various museums and galleries on offer in this historic and beautiful park. The national museum at the northern end is a must and the small shrine and historic house of the shogun as well as the Eastern culture museums are also worth the time.

Gorgeous. We spent a few hours walking through Ueno Park and the cherry blossoms were stunning. I hear this place is crazy right in the middle of the Sakura season and we saw all the spaces allocated to picnic rugs - but it was wet so not too many people. Worth a trip.

Nice Park but not crucial. In the minority in this one too. Nice park, nice shrines. If you happen to catch cherry blossoms (we just missed most of them) it would be spectacular - otherwise just a nice park
Lovely sakura. We spent an afternoon there at the end of March, walking around and taking pictures. It was nice but very crowded.

more museums, temples and memorials than you can shake a stick at. This park is really really busy - there is so much going on and it has a great vibe. It has several of tokyo's major museums as well as a huge lake and a few temples and memorials. The temples are cool - but don't go out of your way. The real gems here are the museums each of which you could spend a few hours in - or if you are in a rush power walk through.

Beautiful. Beautiful when the sakuras are in full bloom. Mats are thoughtfully rolled out for visitors to picnic under the cherry blossom trees. Buy a few picnic items before heading to the park.There are a few temples within the park, do take time to visit them.

Still with some Cherry blossoms. My family loved the beautiful trees and although cherry blossoms season is almost over, we still got to see some trees in full bloom. There were a lot of people going to the park because we went on a Sunday morning. There is big Starbucks Cafe inside the park. Also the Tokyo National Museum is also located within the park.
Urban Oasis.. Ueno is a lovely park with much to offer the day tripper, museums, shrines and people watching, it is a wonderful way to pass a few hours in a serene setting.

Fun for the Sakura festivities!. We came to see the cherry blossoms and realized this is the place to be! People camp out for picnic spots, and by the time we arrived most were very jovial! Lots of drinking & gift giving was taking place. We walked around and took in the celebratory atmosphere. In one section of the park many tents selling food, beer, crafts, etc. were setup, giving it almost a christmas market vibe. Great for the Sakura festivities!

Find a Starbucks decorated with Sakura. After the Sakura road, you will find this spacious cafe with outdoor sitting, you could order a seasonal Sakura cake though can't really taste the flower but with a cup of coffee whcih's great

Beautiful during cherry blossoms. Great place to visit during cherry blossom season but does get extremely crowded, especially on weekends. Spent a couple of hours walking around finding a little temple with an amazing tree in the middle of a courtyard. There was little food markets down near the lake selling all sorts of Japanese cuisine, great to grab some snacks while walking around. The swan paddle boats were great fun, our toddler loved it!

The Cherry Blossoms were Gorgeous. We arrived in Tokyo about a week before the Cherry Blossom season peaked. Most places just had buds on their trees; but our guide recommended Ueno Park, since they were blooming earlier. Just too beautiful.

oasis in the city. lots to do here - just enjoying the greeen space, the museums, and the zoo. YOu could easily spend the entire day.one note about the zoo - free for kids under 12 - a HUGE plus.teh people watching was excellent- much better than the streets of Tokyo

Picnic under Cherry Blossom Trees (Seasonal- End March to Early April). Japanese love to picnic under those full bloomed cherry blossoms. There's also a stream of hawker stalls near the lake selling snacks and drinks that you can purchase and choose a spot under your fav tree and enjoy the view while filling up your tummy. I prefer sitting facing the lake, looking at seagulls and ducks and enjoy a skewer of grilled octopus. There were also cherry blossom trees along the lake, but what I enjoyed most was the pink cherry blossom reflection on the surface of the lake and the smell of the flower. There are also a few temples around the park. Street performers too love to perform here because it's crowded with tourists and also locals during sakura viewing season.

Dear God the crowds, the crowds..... We arrived on Tuesday 31st March 2015 - and it was hanami at it's absolute peak. Yes, the cherry blossoms are gorgeous, but there are just so many people absolutely everywhere it can be a little hard to enjoy it.The Tokyo National Museum was good - we enjoyed that and it was nice to sit down inside too. The kids were free.

Beautiful!!!!. My trip was at the cherry bloosom sooooo you can imagine. The Park it´s calm and relaxing. there are cafes and you can see some urban atractions like singers or music players. Don´t forget to eat an matcha ice cream!!
Cherry blossom just past peak. We were very lucky to get the last days of cherry blossom, beautiful park, plenty of places to eat and the national museum is located there
Sakura Bloom. Full bloom of Sakura flowers, many delicious snack stands but too many people visiting. Will come again in earlier time to avoid crowds

Stunning Hanami Experience. Ueno park was full of beautiful cherry blossoms during our visit to Tokyo. It was an absolutely breathtaking scene despite the crowds. We managed to find an empty spot beneath the trees and participated in our first Hanami! It was a perfect afternoon of bento boxes, snacks, napping and even being interviewed by a news team (talking to all the foreigners!). This will forever be a favorite memory of our time in Tokyo - just magical :-).
Cherry Blossom Park. A great park to visit during Sakura season. Lots of cherry blossoms trees - very crowded and its beautiful in the night with lanterns along the path.

Nice park. I liked that it's one of the parks which is near to a JR station and you don't have to walk so far just to get to it. It was easy to bring my 70 year old mother as it's just 2 mins from the Ueno station.The amount of sakura trees is OK, but I didn't like the construction that was going on. If you walk deeper into the park, you will see a lake and that part is nice when the sakura petals fall into the water. There's also some food stalls during April around the lake.I'd prefer visiting Shinjuku Gyoen as it is much larger and prettier.

nice park with heaps of Sakura!. Ueno park was very busy (peak Cherry Blossom season) but has heaps of Cherry Blossoms in a great picturesque setting. there is a great pond and walkways in Ueno and plenty of Sakura to see. The park has a good vibe and many Hanami-goes in bloom time - we sat for an hour or so to soak it all in! must do park especially in Sakura season

Get a free tour from the Tokyo Goodwill Guides!!. Ueno Park is beautiful on its own, but I can't recommend the Tokyo Goodwill Guide tour enough. My husband and I had a private 90-minute tour given by two knowledgeable and friendly guides that greatly enriched our experience of the park - they had all sorts of information to explain what we were seeing, as well as took us to areas we wouldn't have gone to on our own. It's completely free; if you were thinking of going to the park there's no reason not to get the tour!

Magical when the cherries blossom. We were extremely lucky to be in Tokyo and in this park on the Big day when all cherries blossomed and the weather was summer warm. It was amazing to watch thousands of happy people among these wonderful trees. A memory for life!

Too crowded. I went to enjoy Hanami with several friends at this area. I expected it would be peaceful and lovely, but it turned out to be so crowded. It's a famous park, so many foreigners come to this park.Though cherry blossoms were extremely beautiful, I couldn't enjoy it very much because there were too many people. Too many people that made me a bit dizzy at that time.

Great place to view sakura. Ueno park is one of the best place to view sakura during the Sukura season. There is no entrance fee. Sakura trees can be found all over the park. The best spot would be the one by the lake. The view of sakura trees surrounding the lake is amazing!

Cherry Blossom Season. this was probably the most social park I have been to for people watching. I stereo typed in my mind that in some ways japanese people are reserved. this park during cherry blossom season is lively. people set tarps under the trees, sing, eat and drink...I now see what cherry blossom season is all about...like any tourist attraction, expect it to be busy with both locals having a great time, and tourists alike...

Beautiful but crowds are insane. Cherry Trees in full bloom are stunning! However, it is the most popular park for Hanami (picnic under the blossoms) and it is difficult to move around (we came on a Monday morning - I can't imagine going on a Saturday or Sunday). It was a fun festival atmosphere but just too many people.
Breath taking Cherry Blossom.... We saw whole park of Cherry Blossom...so Beautful, at the end of park there were street food ...it's like a festival...we had good feast of their local street food...

Sakura blossoms in full bloom. A fun evening was spent in the park under Sakura blossoms. The lake is lovely and relaxing. A very popular with locals who want to decompress after work with a beer or two!

pretty sakura. We went there in April when the sakura was still in full bloom. It is so pretty! I am not sure I could have chance to see such nice view or not again!
the atmosphere inside is nice! there were many people going for the sakura.

Special experience with Tokyo family enjoying sprint. In spite of a cloudy and wet weather, we enjoyed seeing local families and groups of friends having picnic parties under the beautiful alleys of blossoming cherry tree. This is a very unique experience!

visit specially during cherry blossom. It's a amazing place to walk through a long tunnel of cherry blossom trees with locals having picnic celebrations. You will love to come here any time to have a long walk and enjoy the greenness around. Nearby Tokyo National museum And arts museum too. You can also go for a boating too in the nearby lake or can have a walk to enjoy the beauties around the lake. Specially you can see the lots of birds and fishes in the lake. There are some beggars at the entrance of the park. In general they don't disturb foreigners and nether harmful. If you see someone is following you, just ignore them.

Gets a 5 for cherry blossoms. April 3 the cherry blossoms were just beginning to fall, and Ueno kohen was a microcosim of the world. People from all over the world are there enjoying the fair atmosphere and beautiful trees. It was a bit wild. Kids throwing petals like snow, all kinds of fair food. Later in the evening it was clear that the alcohol had flowed freely. A bit like St. Patrick's day in Savannah.

As many people as cherry blossoms.. On my first visit to Ueno park over 30 years ago I was invited to join a group of strangers on a flower viewing picnic. Now so many people that the picnic areas are strictly controlled and the recycling service is extensive. I've learned to visit the temple and see the other sites and the accessibility is excellent - stations to park have plenty of good paths, escalators and lifts.

Cherry Blossom. Amazing walk through a long tunnel of cherry blossom trees with locals having blue blanket picnic celebrations either side. Very very busy, but well worth visiting at cherry blossom time.

Amazing sakura. One of the best part of our trip is our visit in the Ueno Park. I love how the lake is surrounded by sakura and by how it rains with with pink petals every time the wind blows. It felt like as if we were in a scene of a movie. No fees are collected when you enter the park. There are lots of food vendor before the park proper thus picnic under the sakura tree is highly recommended.
Relaxing. Overall loved the garden very relaxing atmosphereNearby Tokyo National museumAnd arts mesuem tooGood park side cafe

hanami, picnic under the sakura blooms. Loved the whole atmosphere of fun and joy on this yearly spring affair. The sakura trees were laden with the beautiful blooms, God's beautiful creation for mankinfld to appreciate and admire.

Great Park to Enjoy Lunch in Sakura Season. The park is crowded when the sakura season comes, but it's interesting to see thousands of people getting lunch in the park and participate in the lunch party itself. A lot of food stalls are available to fill your stomach during sakura season here.
A must visit when you are in Tokyo during sakura season.
Great place to view blooming of Sakura!!. Went with my family and took amazing pictures because at ueno park, they have a lane filled with cherry blossom trees.

Worth a visit!. We have been there with the family and it's a really nice way to spend and afternoon (or morning)
Just enjoy the weather and walk around the park, there is never enough of temples or parks in Japan :)

Cherry blossoms just starting. Lucky with timing to see the throngs of Japanese surge into the park to photograph the one tree in full bloom and many other buds! We also went to one of the three museums in the park. Was surprised on other visits to. See homeless people camped out there. Not sure if this is still the case.

beautiful. It is a clean and beautiful park.
But it was still to early not too many fully blossom sakura.
It will be more breathtaking a few weeks later

the cherry tree are blooming. one of the nices park in tokyo, the cherry trees are blooming in two colors - white and purple , the temple and the food street give you
the tast of tokyo

never get bored. I love this park! one of must visit place in Tokyo. especially when you visiting Ueno.place for family, couples, even for visiting alone.from Temples, restaurants, parks, museum, zoo, they had it all in one place.very close to the Ueno station, it very easy to reach out.you can visit and enjoy Ueno Park in all seasons..in spring, sakura trees there very beautiful ..

Amazing Park. We visited the park in hopes of seeing all the amazing cherry trees sadly we were about a week two early. That being said the park itself is super amazing. We took time to check out the zoo and a few museums. Loved the Star Bucks super friendly staff and a comfortable place to spend some time.

Great beauty & it's free to enjoy. We took the JR Yamanote line from Shinjuku (about 25 minutes). On a Monday at 11:30 the carriages weren't crowded. The park is easy to access from the Ueno station. As an alternate to the Shinjuku Gyoen park (closed Monday's) it was a pleasant surprise. During late March this was a wonderful park to see Cherry blossoms, whilst taking a stroll with my lovely partner. There are lockers, wheelchairs, public toilets, eateries and gift shops available. The Ueno Zoo was closed this day, as was the National Museum of Western Art. As a runner this would be a great location for exercise. Take your time and enjoy the atmosphere of the park.

Beautiful oasis in big city. This is a great park for walking and running. It is also very popular during Cherry blossom time when families picnic under the trees and on the walkways around the gardens. Great atmosphere with food stalls and entertainment during blossom time on weekends. A must see when you are in Ueno.
Wait for the blossom. This is just like many other parks in Tokyo well organized, clean and widely set up, with Museums, a Zoo and temples it is worth while visiting

Big beautiful park, peaceful place, glad to visit.. We visit Ueno Park on March, 2nd before cherry blossom but lucky us that some are blossoming and we can saw & took a photo.The Park is big & had many things to do. You can have a coffee break at a Unique Starbucks in the park. So chill & relax. Walk along the trees and there is small temple & shrine inside a park where you can spend half day or whole day (we spend only half day because our next plan was going to Ameyoko Market which just few minutes walk from Ueno Park)
one of the best parks. An absolutely lovely park, easy to find, the JR station is right next to it and the zoo is there too.
Sakura!!. The park is very beautiful and is huge!! The Sakura trees are all over the place, very nice to seat and talk and drink coffee, I love it!

Nice park must visit. able to spend whole day in this area. Museums and outdoor activities available.Currently some hall of the science center closed for renovation. please take note if you planning your visit to science center.
Lovely Cherryblossom. I was there during the cherryblossom season and the views were just great. It's like you see on the movies.

A huge place looks chaotic but people are friendly!. We went to this place via the very good transport system of Tokyo through the subway and we were amazed at the crowds! Lots of people of all ages, yet they are very friendly and not noisy! The views are great- modern sculptures combined with traditional Japanese gardens and trees, shrubs, flowering plants, etec. We love the sakuras/cherry blossoms of course! We shall be back for sure when the boys finish their studies! We feel so at home and safe in this place- actually anywhere in Japan, we felt so secure! Even inside the trains, the people don't talk very loud, they don't use their mobile phone in a way to disturb others, It is a very civilised place!Ueno Zoo is here too, do visit it, it is charming!

Worth most of day. Ueno Park is a great mix of many smaller sites that can occupy most of a day. It's nicely laid out with good walking paths, and it's a very pleasant escape from the typical views of the city.In the park are multiple museums, the Ueno Zoo, a cafe, a temple, and other spots to sit and people watch.I particularly enjoyed seeing part of a Buddhist worship ceremony, visiting the Tokyo National Museum and eating lunch at the cafe near the zoo.
You can spend whole day here.. Big park where you can spend whole day.Sakura trees are attracted the visitors in March.There are Zoo,temples inside this park.

Nice park to visit and relax. After walking around in Ginza, Shinjuku, or around Ueno's electronic stores, it is nice to visit and relax here. Plenty of options to relax or sightseeing, lots of ice cream parlors and food. Luckily we have a local friend who speaks Japanese (he's been there for a while) so it was more enjoyable for us. Next time I will visit in April, the sakura will be blooming and more beautiful.

Great place to see Momiji. Great place to see the Autumn foliage , and also a great place to visit during Sakura. Must be very busy during Hanami Sakura. Flea markets are also set up during weekends. Interesting spread of good from the different regions of Japan can be seen in the market.

Beatiful when the cherries are blooming. You can't miss this park, if you are visiting the National museum, but don't rush through it quickly, take some time to relax and breath some fresh air in the middle of the city. We were visiting at the end of the cherry viewing, but still there were some blooming trees, so I can only imagine, how gorgeous it is in the middle of bloom.
A beautiful park. Nice trees / perfect weather in Fall season You can go for a walk with an amazing red and yellow leaves around you Very nice

Chillin'. My first time visiting Japan, This is my first destination in the first morning in Tokyo. In February, there still be a Winter in Japan, so there is no "Sakura" to see , not much crowd. But the park is remain for a beautiful place anyway. The park is open in the early morning, Meanwhile, most of the other places are open around 10.00am. So I would suggest to take a stroll here get some nice air before going to somewhere else. They also have museums and zoo to visit as well.

Lots to see in a beautiful setting. We found a lot to see and do inside Ueno park, which is really beautiful throughout the year! we visited in winter so there were no cherry blossoms. but still thought the park was great. Shitamachi museum is great for a look into Japanest life in the 1800s and beyond, and at only Y300 a person (less for students) it's a nice short tour and small upstairs to explore if museums arent really your thing.The Black and Gold Shrine is a must!
Quiet place to relax. Relax and unwind in the greens. Went on a weekday, and there was hardly anybody, but it was still a great place to picnic or just hang out and have a breather.
Great for cherry blossoms. We walked around the park and were able to take in the beautiful cherry blossoms. Very relaxing strolling through the park.

Lots to do and see. Enjoyed wandering through the park and imagining the cherry blossom. We visited the Tokyo National Museum and ate lunch there. Its free if you are over 70 (not me, but worth knowing). Lo

A local cultural experience. I lived in Tokyo for several years, and often passed through the park on-route to the Zoo. The park is very much an interesting blend of locals and tourists, it has an amazing display of cherry blossom in the spring, and has several museums on the station side of the park, there is always an interesting display of something happening be it musicians or just local characters and its a great place to just chill and watch it all happen.

Toshogu Shrine is the Best Thing Here. This is a nice park -- I am sure it is even nicer in spring and summer -- in a busy area. Toshogu Shrine is like a little jewel -- a fascinating place to spend 1/2 hour. If you are only in Japan for a few days and cannot make it to Nikko, the Ueno Toshogu will suffice.

Wasn't so good in winter. It was an ordinary aprk. Might be beautiful during cherry blossom. But when i visited in Jan it was dry. But i could get to see many birds in the lake. Dried lotus stems were full of the lake. I am sure in spring and summer when they blossom it will add all the beauty.

Lots of life, and a pretty setting. We enjoyed wandering through this park, grabbing some pizza for lunch and watching the local residents enjoy their weekend. There are temples and gardens hidden away down paths and buskers and showmen along the avenues.

Pleasant park to spend an hour or so. You have to stroll through Ueno Park to get to Tokyo National Museum (an absolute must-see!), so you'll end up seeing Ueno Park regardless ;)The park is a pleasant place to aimlessly stroll for an hour or so. Be sure to get to Toshogu Shrine ... small but truly beautiful with sparkling new gold and nestled in a gorgeous garden/forested setting.Be sure to slow down and watch some of the buskers ... saw an amazingly talented juggler. And for something "different", stop by the Starbucks. Starbucks, you say?!?! No, seriously. You'll be utterly blown away by the amazingly polite, pleasant, proactive Japanese service with a smile. And its outdoor terrace overlooks the main pedestrian artery of the park so the people-watching is perfect.Breeze to get to by alighting at Ueno Station on the JR Yamanote Line.

Great but in need of grass. Great park overall.Very beautiful during the Cherry Blossom season.From time to time you can see performers in the park as well.It is a rather large park featuring a pond and row boats as well.A definite must on any Tokyo trip list.

Relaxing and scenic park. We went to Ueno Park during winter and it was very beautiful - part of the lake had frozen over and the lotus flowers had all dried up. It was very relaxing for an afternoon walk with plenty to do nearby, including a few shrines and temples and some great paddle-boat swans! Highly recommended for a relaxing afternoon.

Unimpressive but pleasant.. The park itself is unimpressive (though in the spring when the sakura is in bloom it'd be lovely) but there are a lot of things to do here- like a couple small shrines, a Starbucks, some museums, even a zoo. Nothing stood out as spectacular here but it was overall pleasant.

nice relaxing park. Had some time before airplane so strolled park. Very nice, clean, relaxing. There were lots history and free lance artists everywhere. It is in close proximity to train station and ueno shopping market

Congregation of museums. I visited the park twice. Once for a jog, another time to visit the nearby museums. Perhaps it was winter, but the Park feels very "tired" and did not show much energy or vibrancy. The sights were also average, such that it wasn't a particularly fun jog. The Shitamachi Museum in the vicinity is definitely worth a visit, as it shows me how the Japanese used to live. The free guide at the Museum was very enthusiastic about her job. Kudos to her. As for the National Museum, the experience was average.
Nice view of lake and lotus. If i visited it again, i really want try to jogging there. I love the view arround the lake with so much lotus. And also, good pedestrian.

Relaxing but with Museums and places of interest.. Across the road from our hotel. Contained several museums, statues, special gardens.
Very large lake with boats for hire. A quiet oasis in a busy day

Good place for a walk . Ueno park, which is the biggest in tokyo, is great. And it is near from Tokyo station, and is convenient for tran sportation. I often go to ueno park in sping when we can see sakura every where in ueno park. It is so beautiful that a lot of people even from foreign countries come to see that. In autumn the trees that are full of sakura in sping turn to colored leaves. It also attracts a lot of tourists. It is a lovely place so I never feel bored even if I had been there for many times.

Nice autumn stroll. It's not autumn without a stroll in the park, with the fallen yellow ginko leaves and chill air, and I'd say that Ueno park is one of the loveliest park in Tokyo, with full of surprises. During my stroll, I met with a cartoonist drawing people's close up face for free (and some people queued for this), had a chat with a European cellist player (who spoke perfect japanese) entertained a sleepy baby in her stroller with Brahms's lullaby, watched a baseball practice, window-shopped in a ceramic fest, went to some small shrine and overall, had a lovely afternoon stroll :)
Peaceful and Quiet. Amazing place in the centre of Tokyo. Watch out for some live performance, we saw a guy doing 4-leg trick, it was fun!

I stroked the underbelly of a meerkat!. You never know what Ueno will bring you. A dude was casually walking his meerkat, the charming little animal came up to me and cuddled up to me. I don't know if he was feeling affectionate or whether he smelt the numerous packets of rice crackers I had in my bad but I got a good squeeze. I loved the park. Wandered around the museums and went on the lake in a giant fiberglass swan. Pretty good day. A must visit.

Beutiful Park During Sakura Season. I was at the park during winter, not much to see but another common park in Tokyo. I was told that this park attracts may visitors. Nearby the park was Ameyoko street. I bought jumbo kebab for lunch and have no seat to enjoy the meal thus, ended up at the park. As it was difficult to find a suitable place to take a quick break after tiring walk, the park offers a good place to rest and rejuvenate for visitors.

Beautiful Scenery for Selfie !. It serve lot of place of interest with beautiful scenery ! I'm going to this park on December when the autumn and it's near to winter time. Beautiful yellow tree and nice weather ! The park is very clean , Perfect place to take selfie ;)
Museum land. There are a lot of museums in this park plus a couple of shrine all well worth a vist. Close to the station. Also a fairground for the children.

More than a park. Apart from being obviously beautiful and a great place to relax, the place offers a whole lot more right from starbucks to pandas to lake, there are so much to see around the place and most importantly it is a great picnic or lunch spot and those who have an eye for photography can go crazy clicking shots after shots

good place to visit. I went to there in April with my friend to see sakura?there were many people and sakura was very beautiful?We feed birds by the river ?the birds stopped on my hand?We throwed food into sky?the birds flied to us to catch food?We took a boat into water?and in the middle of water to see the view of sakura?Ueno Park is a beautiful place which is worth to have a look in April?
Beautiful Park. Went during peak Sakura season, and it was absolutely beautiful. The walkways were covered in a canopy of pink and white flowers, and the falling petals looked like snow. Fantastic.
do not miss this. a major window into the city; great walking/running; great museums and restaurants; wonderful shrines and tempes; great gardens.

Beautiful. remember , grab your coffee, book and some snacks. Pay a visit to the national museum and find a bench to sit down. Have a smoke. I regretted not having more time to enjoy the air and atmosphere

Great way to spend an afternoon. A really great space, full of different attractions ranging from a zoo (the oldest in Japan) to shrines and museums. Exceedingly easy to get to and a great way to spend an afternoon. Once you have finished in the park wander into the Ameyoko Market for great shopping and food.
Brought the kids to the zoo. Went to Ueno Park, there's lots to see, protestors on the corner. Police available in the koban. Good lunch options. Ate at Pepper Lunch. Cold in the winter.

Many things to do at the park. There is lots to do at this park. The zoo has Panda bears that can be seen eating. There is a museum close by. There is also a Starbucks in the park. If you feel like walking there is a temple to be seen. The area by the pond is quiet and peaceful. It is easy to get to from the train station. It is basically a walk across the street.
Nice, but it is winter. Convinced it would be absolutely beautiful in all the other three seasons. A bit drab in winter though!

Nice break from town and also free!. This park might be my most favorite in Tokyo. It has it all - shrines to pray at, a zoo, a baseball field yard, a pond with goose boats, various museums, a university, historical landmarks and statues, and best of all, the natural scenery. Seriously, the Sakura trees and bloom look so gorgeous during all seasons, including winter. The park also has Starbucks and several cafes along with musicians sometimes playing and vendors roaming about. A whole day could literally be spent at this park if you wanted to!
Nice place to walk. We can spend avg 2-4 hr, play area for childrens, food counters(including StarBucks coffee) and a really big walk way with lot of trees.

Uplifting. One of the nice things about a 5 am arrival into Tokyo is that you can take the metro to Ueno park. You can watch the sunrise from the train, and walk around the temples in the early morning light. Then go to the Starbucks for a hot drink, and then to the museums. I love this place.

A park for leisure stroll as well as the museums and zoo. This is one of the most famous park in Tokyo. Inside this park there are a few museums namely The Art Museum, National Museum, Science Museum and more. Ueno Zoo is also located within this park. The scenery is magnificent especially during autumn and sakura blossom season. There are also shrines and temples in this park.

A Place for chilling promenade. Big Public Park in city where located two Japanese Shrine inside;
Visitor can walking to see real daily Japnese people life goby.
A baseball sports yard; Sakura tree in spring or colorful leafs tree change in aumtumn.
Plus Ameyokocho (Seafood) and shopping open air tourist market are situated not far from aprk

Pleasant. Worth a wander to escape the busier streets and we were glad of some green space out of the heat. Plenty of things going on and we stopped to watch a children's entertainer tying balloons into amusing shapes. Didn't visit the zoo but saw a crowd of tortoises clambering over each other to eat bread thrown from a bridge by adoring fans.

Beautiful Park and surrounds. We visited this during autumn and it was our first real taste of the autumn leaves. It is a very large park with many things to see, including rowing ponds, shrines, temples, museums and art galleries.
