Visit during new year oshogatsu. This is the place to go if you are in Tokyo during the new year. The park is open all night and many folks come to the temples surrounding Ueno park . You can ring the bell, enjoy tea with a monk, The Shinto temples have small plaques for sale with the animal of the new year on according to the Chinese calendar . These are for prayers but they make great gifts . I collect them because every temple has different art work . They are small cheap , and beautiful. Also very Japanese.
Lots of museums and a zoo. The park was the first public park in Japan. Now hosts several major national museums. Good rail access.
If your a museum person, then go. I think this is Tokyo's main museum area. Lots of different museums scatter throughout the park. Great place to go during the day.

Ultimate cherry blossom day. What an awesome experience. Sitting under the cherry blossoms sharing food, drink and laughs. It was a great afternoon. We were lucky enough to have a friend who is a local so we got to hang out with all his Japanese friends and truely got to experience the cherry blossom festival. He took us around the park and got to see the small food markets which looked yum. Also saw a few temples which were great. It's the ultimate place for cherry blossoms. So many ppl and a few street entertainers who did magic. Loved it.

Sunday in the Park in Ueno. Great place to walk and observe families having fun and relaxing on a Sunday. We visited the shrines nearby but didn't explore the National Museum - it was more fun people watching on a sunny and warm fall day. Lots of food kiosks too (Turkish Shish Kabob in Tokyo?!). Not a "must see" on a short trip, but a good break.
Big park. Great place to walk around in Ueno... there are art galleries and museums, and a zoo.. but even in spring or summer, the trees are very pretty and photo worthy

Great place to explore. This park is quite large and full of shrines and other interesting things. The National Museum is one of the best I have ever seen and well worth the trek through the park to get to. Lots of musicians and market stalls also to enjoy near the museum.

Tokyo's Central Park. Absolutely beautiful park in Ueno district. Tokyo National Museum was, surprisingly, not very impressive. If you want to see the real Japan, head east into the alleyways beyond Ueno station into Taito District. Deafening pachinko parlors, squid, Japanglish T-shirts and some uniquely crazy, truly Japanese items.

There is always something going on. Ueno park is a really nice place to spend a few hours, there seem to be a new event even week...I have see "street performers day", "bonsai exhibition", "live music", "green energy day".
I also highly recommend taking the free tour, it leaves from the Green Salon, it is free, it takes 90mins and the guides are great !

The most beautiful park with cherry blossom. Visited Ueno park during the cherry blossom season, was mersmerized by such beautiful scene that no pictures about the park was able to do justice to the scenic view. So many tourist and locals enjoying the picnic under the sea of cherries, such unique experience at this special season. A must vist for Tokyo in April.

Get ready to spend the full week just visiting the place!. Here you are 2 videos I made of the placeTokyo Ueno Park Part 1 : http://youtu.be/5hn74eROaHATokyo Ueno Park Part 2 : http://youtu.be/L8h_eaMjGisMassive...this is how we could best describe the sheer size (534,000m2) and the many attractions to be found in this park. Established in 1873, Ueno Park is among Japan’s first public parks and home of some major museums like the Tokyo National Museum, National Science Museum, Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum, National Museum of Western Art, Shitamachi Museum, several temples and even a zoo!It would be impossible to cover all aspects of this park in a single day, so we decided to divide our attention on the cultural aspects of this park and its temples with the following:- Kiyomizu Kannon Temple (Part 1)- Hanazono inari Temple (Part 1)- Gojoten Temple (Part 1)- Toshogu Shrine (Part 2)- Ueno Park Pagoda (Part 2)- Bentendo Temple and the Shinobazu Pond (Part 2)While these temples and places are on the Ueno Park “Must See” list, we would also recommend visiting:- Kaneiji Temple- Ueno DaibutsuKiyomizu Kannon Temple:Originally built in 1631 and part of the Kaneji temple, the Kiyomizu Kannon Temple get it’s design and architecture from the famous Kiyomizu-dera temple in Kyoto and is also home to an image of Kosodate Kannon (Goddess of child-rearing) and a figure of Senju Kannon (Thousand Armed Goddess of Mercy).Gojoten and Hanazono inari Temple:A few meters away from the Kiyomizu Kannon you will find both the Gojoten and Hanazono inari Temples, the Fox Temple. Both temples are actually close to each other and can be mistaken for the one and only place of worship.The Gotojen temple is dedicated to the Scholar and poet Sugawara no Michizane (August 1, 845 - March 26, 903) and located close to the Shinobazu Pond, while the Hanazono inari Temple is dedicated to the Inari Okami, or spirit of the foxes, and can be accessed by a gorgeous series of Japanese Torii.-Kiyomizu Kannon Temple (Part 1)-Hanazono inari Temple (Part 1)-Gojoten Temple (Part 1)Toshogu Shrine:Believe it or not, the Toshogu Shrine is one of only a few Edo-Era structures in Tokyo to have survived earthquakes, fires and even wars. Built in 1627, the Toshogu Shrine underwent a major renovation in 1651 on the orders of the Shogun Tokugawa Iemitsu. What’s unique about this shrine, besides being similar in style to the Shrine of Nikko (also called Toshogu) with its gold plated decorations, are its 50 large copper lanterns that guide you through the shrine itself. Usually made from stone, these lanterns were donated to the Shogun by a warlord named Daimyo. Ueno Park Pagoda: Perhaps one of the best parts of the Kaneiji Temple (not covered on these 2 videos), is its pagoda. Separated from its main temple, this 5 storied pagoda can unfortunately only be enjoyed from the Ueno Zoo, and only after spending a few hundred yen. However, the pagoda is not the only beautiful structure to see and enjoy. There are also architectural masterpieces that have for centuries defied the force of Japan’s earthquakes (http://web-japan.org/nipponia/nipponi...)Bentendo Hall Temple and the Shinobazu Pond:Build in the early 17th century by Mizunoya Katsutakathe, the Bentendo Hall Temple is a Benzaiten-type temple located in the middle of the Shinobazu Pond. Unfortunately the actual Bentendo Hall Temple you can see today is not the original, and was in fact rebuilt from the ground up in 1958 after being destroyed in 1945. To be fair this temple is not the most interesting part of Uneo Park, however its pond and the giant lotuses are magnificent and can be fully enjoyed in the summer where they cover the entire surface of the pond.

Artist performance, music, landscaping ambience. Sadly I didn't go into any of the museums or the zoo this trip, but it's a beautiful park. You'll see and hear music, see performances, art, and the temples that are open to enjoy. This is a must visit attraction in Tokyo

Huge green space in the middle of Tokyo. Easy to get to, just outside of Ueno Station and a few subway lines. Many different trails around the lake and forested areas. A few museums and the zoo are in the park.

Ueno Park and Zoo. Easy to get to Zoo (local G16 and H17 stations of the subway line) and Very cheap to enter compared to European Zoos. Costs about 300 to 600 yen dependent on age (170 yen to UK pound). Plenty of usual animals especially Pandas but rather small enclosures for the animals overall in my opinion but excellent way to spend a couple of hours. Plenty of happy children everywhere which is lovely to see. The rest of the park has a super museum and also plenty of musicians and samurai sword demos etc.Recommended.

Beautiful day out.. Stunning cherry blossom scenery. I saw some musicians playing on a massive xylophone. That was really cool. There were also many food stalls with people eating on the pavements (there were sheets laid out). I also saw a female cat and her kitten high up in a tree. That was so cute. This is a good way to spend the last few hours of Japan before flying back.
What a fabulous peaceful garden!. Exquisite planting in a huge garden with a Buddhist temple, a beautiful lake filled with lotus, amazing museums and a hotel!

people watching. In much of Tokyo, you just see suits and serious faces, or else young folks with their eclectic dress and round-the-clock. This is a change of pace. Mostly you'll see couples and families with young kids. Nice place to relax and people watch.
As parks go, it is ok, go for the art and museum. this park has museums, zoo and art gallery. As a park it does not have the charm of the other great arks in Tokyo

Cultural bonanza. If you go out one end of the Ueno station, you reach the Ueno market. Go the other direction, and take the escalators up to the pedestrian overpass, and you can make your way to Ueno Park. This place is chock-full of temples, statues, museums, even a zoo. The Tokyo National Museum is actually a vast repository of Japan's historical, rerligious and artistic artifacts--each with its own building. I spent two days here at Ueno Park, and didn't manage to see even half of what is available. Even at that, I emerged with a much better feel for Japanese art and history. PS, most things are closed on Monday.

A zoo with lots of interesting animals.. A zoo with lots of interesting animals. At metro, go up escalater, go to the right out to exit, go right, not far,to a tree-lined walkway, go right. Go thisway to the zoo, a museum, and a starbucks. The zoo is to the left. First,there is a panda bear. Also, a lake completely covered by water lilies.There is a place to get food and sit at outside tables.

The best. Loved discovering ueno park. I ended up there on a Saturday and found most of Tokyo was there. One of the best places to see the locals enjoying Tokyo.It's a stunning park and has a calmness to it.

lovely and peaceful. this is a beautiful place to visit. after eating an awesome meal to stroll through here- smell the smells of the flowers and hear the birds and difference sounds… it was great. lots of people but didn't feel crowded. in the middle of a busy place there is a serene place to visit.

Sakura Viewing Park. Specifically went to the Ueno Park for viewing Sakura and I was not disappointed as evidenced by the number of photos I took of the place. Ueno Park had a festive atmosphere & a lot of locals & visitors alike were having picnics beneath the trees. It was just too bad because it rained really hard towards late afternoon and the downpour continued till evening., so everybody opted to leave.I would have loved to stay longer if not for the rain. Ueno is a great place for a stroll, meditate & just people watching.

Great place to store act your legs. Nice place to walk around....museums close by....I stopped at the Tokyo National Museum (need 1-2 hours). They also has a flea market going on while I was there (mostly tableware). Lots of places to sit and enjoy the moment.

Past the museums and zoo. The Ueno Park seems to be chiefly known--at least to foreign visitors--as the home of major attractions including the zoo and world-class museums (I've already reviewed one of these, the Tokyo National Museum). There are, however, dozens of other interesting things in the park, well worth taking the time to discover. Here are some:The Tokugawa Shrine is in the center of the park. There is a Chinese wall around it, with a Chinese gate proving access, and a torii gate before the Chinese one. There are avenues lined with stone lanterns. As you get close to the shrine you"ll see 48 bronze lanterns (these were donated by feudal lords to show respect for Yokugawa Ieyasu, the founder of the Tokugawa Shogunate, to whom the shrine was dedicated in 1627.) The torii gate, Chinese gate and wall, bronze lanterns and the shrine itself are all officially designated as important cultural assets. Inside the shrine is a flame which has been burning there for almost 25 years; the flame's sources actually go back to August 1945. A man returned to Hiroshima just after the atomic explosion, looking for his uncle. He never found him, but did find his uncle's house, still smoldering. On impulse he lit something from that flame and carried it back with him to his viilage To honor his uncle, he kept the flame alive. 23 years later, his village lit a torch from the flame, vowing to keep it alive as long as there were nuclear weapons. A second flame was added to the first, one which was generated by rubbing the rough edges of two Hiroshima roof tiles together (the A-bomb had fried the tiles creating the rough surfaces--four such tiles are displayed in the Hiroshima Peace Museum, where visitors are encouraged to stroke them: I did, and it's eerie touching the instant the age of nuclear warfare began). When the Hiroshima flame was brought to Ueno Toshogu, a third flame was added as well, created by the friction of two similar roof tiles from Nagasaki.Close by is an equestrian statue of Imperial Prince Komatsunomiya Akihito, first president of the Japanese Red Cross. If you go up to this statue and walk around to the back end, you'll find a stone walkway leading to a memorial honoring General U,S. Grant. Two years after his retirement from public office, President and Mrs. Grant visited Tokyo and planted trees near the Ueno Toshogu shrine--a cypress and magnolia respectively. In 1929 a memorial was erected on the spot by the Japanese government. Underneath the bronze bas relief of General Grant's face are the famous words he said to General Robert E. Lee at Appomattox, "Let us have peace." 12 years after placing the memorial, the Japanese government ordered the attack on America's Pearl Harbor. 4 years later, America bombed Hiroshima and Nagasaki, generating a flame that now burns a few score meters away from Grant's words.The park has Shinto shrines, a pagoda, a burial mound (look for construction barriers just north of it), a totem pole, a pagoda containing the hair of a famous early-Edo period Buddhist priest, a lake, and a statue of Saigo Takamori, "the last true samurai", to mention just a few of the many interesting things you can discover by exploring Ueno Park. (See photos).

Big beautiful park.. Love going there with my daughter for a stroll around. Lots of trees around so during the sakura season you will be AMAZED !! there is a zoo that you can enjoy and a pond where you can rent a small boat :) it is huge so you can easily get lost. Not the best baby facilities or toilets but will do.

Fabulous for sakura, pleasant other times. We have stayed in Ueno in a room with a view of the park on at least 15 different occasions. We have seen the park in spring, autumn and winter. It is a pleasant park to walk in, in all seasons. At sakura time this is a prime destination: everyone has a camera aimed at the blossoms; hanami parties with lots of groups with piles of food and bottles of sake on blue tarps abound; happy people everywhere. The trees are lovely, the sakura are a real treat. In autumn and winter the park is not crowded and takes on a completely different atmosphere. Joggers, mothers pushing baby carriages, families walking the dog, and yes, homeless people sleeping under those same blue tarps.Shrines, museums, the pond with its migratory birds and swan boats for rent, a zoo, outdoor food stalls - something for everyone. Easy access and free to enter. When you need a break from the pressures of Tokyo, this is a place to visit.

Ueno Park is filled with activities. Visited on a pleasant weekend day, the grounds are lovely and quite relaxing (if weather permits) its directly accessible from the train station, be sure to request a map at the information stall. if enjoying the park scenery and strolling around isn’t enough you can certainly distract yourself with: a moderately sized zoo, museums, fair ( on weekends), temple market stall Also the Park is close enough to an urban town center bustling with activity. Highly recommended for those seeking a pleasent detour from Tokyo's urban jungle.

A Stroll in the Park. Just at the subway station is the entrance. A gentle upward stroll towards the zoo. Beautiful plantings and welcoming Jingu along the way. If you visit during the season of ginkgo, you shall have a fragrance you shall long remember.

A nice day at the park despite the earthquake!. Ueno park is one of Tokyo's famous and popular Western-style public parks. Its quite historic dating back from the Edo period. Its expansive grounds contain museums, temples, shrines, a big pond, and a zoo. The place is quite green with lots of cherry trees. Unfortunately, when I visited, the museums were all closed! So, if you are interested in visiting one such as the National Tokyo Museum or Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Art, make sure and check their schedules. The park is easily accessible and located next to JR Ueno Station. The park has a main plaza that serves as a public square and overlooks the main entrance of the National Tokyo Museum. In the middle sits a large fountain and on both sides of the plaza are places to eat such as Starbucks and Park Side Cafe. I had a very delicious lunch at Park Side Cafe which offers a variety of delicious salads, pasta and sandwiches. The restaurant's patio is a good place for people watching. My relaxing lunch was only interrupted by a "minor earthquake", which by L.A standards (where I come from) was quite frightening. Everyone stopped what they were doing and became very quiet when it occurred. When it stopped, everyone went on with their business as if nothing had happened! I overheard from the people eating next to me that the earthquake was an aftershock from a bigger one that occured in neighboring Ibaraki prefecture.The park's main plaza also connects to a promenade lined with Cherry trees. Here you'll find people relaxing lost in conversations, eating their bentos (box lunches) or enjoying the street performers. I had a chance to see a Kamishibai (paper drama) storyteller and a mime artist who involved their onlookers in their performances. Despite the museum closures and tremor, I had a nice day at the park.

Relaxing place in the middle of the city. UENO is maybe not a japanese garden in traditional meaning, but there is a lot of things to visit during relaxing walk, which can help you to take few easy minutes after always busy Tokyo.
nice place. nice place very close to the subway station. definitely worth a visit of a couple hours if you wanna relax a bit yourself

Lots to do. Beautiful park with a couple of huge ponds at the south end. We like walking along the ponds and watching all the Koi come beg you for food. There are museums and art galleries along with temples and a university, there is something for everyone here

Large busy park with good attractions. The park itself has a number of arrant ions such as a zoo and it would be unfair to judge them on the park itself. I have no doubt in spring the park would be magnificent, but in autumn it is a large busy green space, with a very average fountain, but lots of places to sit without being very scenic. Go if you will do another attraction such as the zoo or the National Museum otherwise it is probably best for jogging through.

Not just a stroll in the park. Tokyo National Museum, Ueno Zoo, Benten Shrine are all within the Park. Entrance to Ueno Park is at a stone throw from Ueno Station (one of the best served train stations in Tokyo). There are a few homeless at Ueno Park but seriously, this is Japan: its not like what you are used to (they just walk around like pigeons posing no threat to anybody).
Lots to see and experience. Ueno Zoo, The National Museum, the Museum of modern art, temples, lot of quiet paths to stroll and shady places to just enjoy the greenery...
Huge and beautiful. There was so much to do besides the zoo such as temples, a tea house, street performers, lovely scenery, and much more. It's an easy day trip right outside the Ueno train station.

Not the best of Tokyos gardens. Ueno Park is easily accessed by train and is close to an amazing market. It has an attractive lake and large temples with good English signage but is crowded and has few tranquil spots to sit. Some may find the stairs difficult. Overall an average garden by Japanese standards. If you want to experience tranquil Japanese gardens, try the Imperial Palace East Gardens (free) or Hamarikyuteien (300yen entry) which is quieter and appears more traditional with a genuine tea house.

Need Whole Day to See All Attractions. You may hear about Ueno Park (上野恩賜公園, Ueno Kōen) every once in a while during the cherry blossoming season in Japan. It located in Ueno-Koen, Taito-ku, Tokyo and is the most favored spot for Japanese people to enjoy the cherry blossoms every year during springtime in the Tokyo area. Hamani (花見, flower viewing) is a traditional Japanese custom of enjoying the transient beauty of flowers. Ueno Park was established in 1873, one year after Yellowstone was established in US. It is also one of the first Japanese public parks. Ueno Park has 538,507 m2 (133 acres) with 8,800 tall trees and Shinobazu Pond in the Tokyo city center. The Shinobazu Pond is populated in the winter by ducks and other migratory birds that fly from as far as Siberia and Alaska.We visited in the morning and found that it is a very large area with so many attractions to see. If you like museums, you may find yourself needing more than one day to see them all, not including the other great attractions in the park. We only visited 2 museums: the National Museum for Western Art, and the Toyokan (Asian Gallery) and Honkan (Japanese Gallery) of Tokyo National Museum. We also visited following temples:*Kiyomizu Kannon-do Temple (清水觀音堂) – Buddhist temple in Ueno Park Tokyo which was completed in 1631 as part of Kaneiji Temple. One of the oldest temples in Tokyo.*Nikko Toshogu Shrine (東照宮) - Established in 1617 and rebuilt in 1636. There are many large copper lanterns on the grounds that are rare seen. Normally the lanterns are made of stone.*Hanazonoinari Shrine (花園稲荷神社) & Gojoten Shrine (五條天神社)We stopped by Starbucks and enjoy our first Starbucks coffee in Japan. It was so crowded that we had to wait for our coffee for about 25 to 30 minutes. We passed by the Shinobazu Pond and did not have time to see the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum and the National Science Museum. The Ueno Zoo is the Japan's first zoological garden, and we skipped this attraction as well. We were too tired to see anymore due to the exhausting museums visits.Ueno Park is right next to JR Ueno Station. It opens from 5am to 11pm year round except during December 29 to January 3. If you want to experience the traditional Japanese Hamani in the cherry blossoms season, prepare yourself for the crowds of visitors. Be aware that this park also attracts homeless. Although the police try to arrest them, they come back as soon as they can.

Very big park. We went there rather early in the morning at 8am as I had some time to kill during my six hour flight transit. The museums or restaurants weren't open yet. There was a big lotus pond filled with lotus leaves/flowers. It was quite remarkable. We also went past a traditional temple and went to the pond where I wanted to take the swan boat. However it wasn't open yet. If I come back here I'd really like to ride the swan boat. Costs 700 yen for 30 minutes.How I got here: Came direct from Haneda Airport using the monorail to Hamamatsucho station and transferred to the JR Yamanote Line to Ueno station. It is just opposite the station at the Park Exit.

Wonderful park. We spent a morning on a free walking tour of the park with a most knowledgable man which was quite helpful, as the park is quite large. It was very busy on that Sunday. We then had lunch at a nice restaurant near the end of our tour.
The most beautiful raining day. With cherry blossoms as pink as babie's cheeks, this place is very lovely even it was raining when we were tthere. I was speechless by its beauty.

Oasis of calm..... Large and peaceful park in the midst of the hustle and bustle of Ueno. Cafe/restaurant facilities and toilets available. Houses a number of museums but they are closed on Mondays unless a public holiday (and then they would probably be extremely busy!). Also allow time to visit Ueno Park zoo.
Nice Park. good place for a walk, where you can find some small temples and the museum, one of the top attractions of the city.

Not a must during non-cherry blossom season under time constraint. We were in Tokyo for 4 days total. Ueno Park is so highly rated that it's hard to miss. We went in May, all the cherry blossoms are gone. The park is very nice and gigantic. It's a good spot for locals to take a break. But for tourists who are on a time constraint during non-sakura viewing season, this park is not a must see. The zoo is nice but nothing to spectacular. I guess my appreciation of the park is very dependent on what I have back home. Compare to all the temples and nature you can see in Kyoto, you can allocate your time to other things in Tokyo.

Well worth a wander on a nice day. This is a good park containing museums, galleries, shrines and temples. You can wander and graze. Very nice in the sun. Currently, you need to watch for mosquitoes because of the dengue fever problem.

A great rest spot.. If you are like me and trying to see Tokyo in less then a week, You will need someplace to rest, relax and regroup while downtown. Ueno park is ideal. Lot of green space, restaurant, stalls and benches. There is a zoo, several museums and other places of interest. It is also used for cultural activities, a Philippine Festival was being held at the time of our visit.
Nice view for cherry blossoms. A place to be for cherry blossoms. The park is huge and there are a lot of spots for cherry blossom viewing. Outside the park are street market where food is cheap!

Nice park. Recommended day to go is Saturday or Sunday lot's of people with lots of events from street performers. If your tired from strolling in Akihabara, I suggest this is your next stop to relax and unwind.

Peaceful and relaxing atmosphere.. Visiting this park in May, unfortunately I could not see the beauty and magic of the cherry blossom tree in the middle of their beauty, if that were the case I would say ... yes, this is the most beautiful place in Tokyo but after this without the beautiful flowers I can admit that Ueno Park is a small park and very normal, nothing to envy to others here in town, by the way is always an attraction to visit.

Beautiful during hanami (Cherry Blossom blooming). Waking up early I figured I would squeeze as much as I could into the day. Waking at six allowed for a big day ahead. I walked through Ueno park, just opposite my hotel. I wandered through the paths lined by sakura (cherry blossom) trees which were all a soft pink blur of beauty. The ponds and vantage points make it a lovely spot to wander or just for a picnic.

Beautiful. The park is beautiful, especially during the cherry blossoms. I was lucky enough to visit when the blossoms were in fully bloom. The park lit up with flowering trees everywhere. There is much to do in and around the park; nearby museums, food vendors, and more.

A lovely park!. It was lovely to explore Ueno park. It's a beautiful park in the middle of the city and is a lovely break from all the buildings. The buskers and street artists are fantastic too, they're so talented!
Big Park, but lots of walking. An excellent and huge inner city park/reserve with lots of museums and landmarks within - just be prepared for a lot of walking - its a big place

Two pandas!. A joy to see close up two pandas eating their breakfast. We arrived early at 9am and were first in so no queues. A very reasonable entrance fee of 600 yen per person. A very well kept zoo.

Cherry trees. This is a large park with lots of cherry trees and other great sights. If you like to hang out and enjoy a quiet time, this is a great park. You will have to walk quiet a bit, so take your time when visiting. Just next to Ueno Park theres a huge street market, which is a must too when you are in this area. I forgot the name, but you cant miss it if you walk back to the train station, its across the street.

Oasis in Tokyo. This is a huge green space within the center of Tokyo. The foliage is so lush and the pathways are well placed. There are amazing 180 degree views of the city skyline from the lake. Shinto shrines and torii gate-lined paths are a delight to explore. The park is also home to a zoo and several of Tokyo's most famous/important museums. A great way to spend several hours - not including time in the museums.

Lovely space to relax. On a hot day this is a lovely place to relax and wander amongst trees. Yes, many think the same thing so it is busy but there is enough space for all of us! There are a couple of cafes (including Starbucks) plus museums, temples, the zoo and fountains.
Get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. It is one of Tokyo's largest parks and has absolutely everything from great museums to wide open spaces.

Huge and pretty. This park is pretty and big! You can definitely spend a whole day just there. Within it, you find museums, the zoo, small lake with paddle boats, a Starbucks, and lots of shady places to rest. Toward the center, in front of the Starbucks, you can enjoy performances by Peruvian musicians, Acrobatic group, etc. Overall, great place to visit.

Lovely Park!. This is a lovely park with temples and shrines dotted around and some pretty gardens too. Unfortunately it draws big crowds so isn't really the quiet haven you might crave in the midst of the madness of Tokyo but is definitely worth a visit.

Tokyo's central park. the title is rather self-esplicative. Probably the biggest and most crowded park in the city, it's a good choice if you want to have some peace in the chaotic Tokyo. Great place for Hanami in the right season.

Tranquil Walk. Went there early one morning during Sakura season and it was a beautiful and peaceful walk, especially around the lake. Other than the cherry blossoms, there were other beautiful flowers blooming. The temple in the middle of the lake has a small lane of vendors leading up to it with some unique offerings. Great place to have a picnic, or just for a nice peaceful walk to clear the head, or if you love taking photos of nature. It is also where you find quite a few attractions like the Ueno Zoo and some museums.
A lot in one place. A great park with many museums and a great zoo. Don't miss the lake with giant lily pads. A nice place to spend a quiet day.

Sneak away and escape. We stayed at a hotel in Ueno and really enjoyed having this park so close. There's a lot to see and do, so choose wisely! It seems to be the park that locals and tourist enjoying equally.
Park with the most. Peaceful walks, paddle boats, a well-used shrine, an outdoor concert venue, just to mention a few attractions. A respite from the Tokyo cacaphony.

Central Park of Tokyo!. This was a large park with multiple attractions built in. From the shrine to the National Museum, this was a half day stop if you can find the time. With a wide array of stops and sights I equate it with the Central Park of Tokyo. Make sure to look for the eternal flame commemorating those lost when the A-bombs fell and lasting peace. It is a bit out of the way but worth the search and the shrine near by was beautiful! It was originally a maybe on our list but became a great day!

Great place to spent some quiet time. Other than the amusement park area of Ueno Park, the rest is rather quiet and green. Best to avoid during hot summer days. But the park is large and is rare finding in Tokyo where space is so limited. Easy access from central Tokyo via JR Trains and several subways. Lots of food stands and some restaurants.

One of the kind. Mostly visitors to tokyo might have forgotten Ueno park outside cherry blossom season. However, i visited there in summer and there are worth to see shrines around the park plus observing the local souls i would suggest this who want to see how Japanese spent their lives. I would say i love this place the most compared to other attractions to tokyo
Cherry blossom season was awesome!. We went during peak cherry blossom period so we saw a sea of people and cherry blossom. Awesome festive mood.

The good, the bad, and the homeless. I didn't spend long here because I marked it as one of my last things to do in Tokyo.Good:-picturesque-crammed with things for tourists to doBad:-many homeless people sleep in the park (I saw a man's bare bottom after he was done going #2)-smelled because of homeless people
Beautiful. My hotel was near the park and I walked past it every day to the station. It was gorgeous in the summer, day and night. The park is clean and offers plenty of great views.

Nice Park. This park is well-groomed, with a few interesting areas. I recommend walking the paths between the various temples and shrines within the grounds of the park. The highlight here is the zoo! For families with young children, there is a mini amusement park right in front of the zoo.

UenoPark this July. We are staying in Nippori for two weeks but have been to Ueno Park a few times. On our second visit we enjoyed a paddle boat on the lake. There are three lakes, two of which are covered in water lilies. The third is open for paddle boats or rowing boats - 700 yen for the three of us! We have enjoyed a picnic there, visited the zoo and have also visited two of the museums in the park. We have found people there extremely friendly and helpful too.

Nice place to chill out, lots of interesting museums. My hotel was next to Ueno park so I came here a couple of times. It's a nice place to chill out if you have extra time in Tokyo, and I can only imagine how great it looks during the sakura. Lots of museums nearby, the science one was great with its 360 degree theater thing!

A BIG TREAT ON SUNDAYS. The carnival like atmosphere attracts Sunday crowds, mostly families with kids who stroll the neat walkways which are punctuated with jugglers, street musicians, magicians, hiphop dancers and other novelty offerings. Fascinating to look at and enjoy considering the park is at the heart of one of the busiest, most crowded cities in the world. Hordes of pigeons can be fed, colorful balloons are on sale and there are small eateries close to the zoo.

nice walk. we go there to see the park but the sakura has left. i mean we go there on may so there is nothing to expect hehehe. but it is good to have breakfast in the park and there is a beautiful frog statue and fountain in the park.

Awesome to walk through knowing how busy it is around and under the park!. It was very pleasant to walk through the beautiful park with its tall and shady trees, beautiful maples and flowers. There is a zoo, museum and restaurants and snacks available. A nice oasis in a very busy area.
Expansive park. Large park filled with museums. There are some great street vendors at the bottom corner near the lily pond selling masks, beads, scrolls, jewelry, etc.
Best park. We ate inside, sat on a half-wall/bench. It was extremely peaceful. It made me smile. We didn't have the occasion, the time, to explore a little bit, but it was a great lunchtime.

Plenty to see and do. Leave Ueno station by either the Panda or park entrance and within 100m you are there a massive open space right in the centre of the city. There are plenty of museums and galleries and of course the zoo within the park, the park is itself free. At the entrance there is an info kiosk with maps and English speaking staff. Lots of shade and places to sit and about 1000 rest rooms you certainly won't get caught short. I went twice once in the day and once at night. If you go at night it's nice to see the shrines lit up but use bug screen. I had had no problems with bites in Japan until Ueno at night, I was bitten to death. Worth a visit for a break from the city without even leaving the city. It feels very safe both day and night.

So much to see!. You can spend an entire day in Ueno Park. It's just off the train station and has tons of museums, a zoo, a botanical garden, and just lovely plant life all about. It's a peaceful place just to stroll through, if you like that sort of thing. The Tokyo National Museum is at one end of the park, but make sure you get there early!

Nice park to visit - museums nearby. Ueno Park is one of the large landmark parks in Tokyo. Location wise it's excellent being right beside the JR Ueno station as well as the Keisei Ueno station, so is easily accessible. The park is large and has multiple museums and attractions dotted about. Even without these it is a nice park to explore in good weather. It's worth spending at least half a day, if not a full day to explore all that there is to see in this location. If time pressed you can easily browse the park and see the National Museum in a few hours. Recommended to visit if you are in Tokyo.
Dont miss it!. Lovey park that could easily rival New York's Central Park. Lots of shrine and temples, museums, and has a lake and the zoo.

Quite cool and very pretty. You can use your JR Pass to train out to Ueno Park and most things in there are free - payment is required for things like the Science Museum and the Ueno Zoo - which is meant to be the oldest zoo in Japan. There's a beautiful lake which you can pay to row/paddle in as well. We spent a few good hours just strolling around, enjoying the sights and buskers and then headed into the Science Museum.
Lots to see. Good location to see lots of museums in the area... Nice chill out area.Everything does close at around 5.30 so get there early ish!
Worth a visit. Close to train station and hotel, was a festival that day, very crowded, still a nice place to walk after a very long plane ride.

spend a week!. Honestly, each time I take students to Japan I wish we had more time here. There is something for everyone. Ueno Zoo is fun and of course has both the Giant Pandas and "Lesser Panda" (Red Panda), which is perhaps even cuter, as well as Capybara and other rather unusual cuties. I love the National Museum and the Museum of Modern Art (the outdoor Rodin garden! Great photos ops!), though many other museums are nearly as grand in scope and rarities. History, Art, Science, Animals, Sakura (cherry blossoms; no place equals Ueno for "hanami", sakura viewing parties!). IF you can bear to leave the park and still have some time, head down the hill (do not cross back to the train station) for the fun food court (on the right, at the end of the block) then Ameyoko cho, the old black market scene. Be careful; prices are not always great here... but it is interesting and very unique.

Tokyo's Central Park with an Asian charcter. It's sort of another temple tour which I am never tired of. Toshogu Shrine was rather impressive with its golden gate and copper lanterns. Good place to walk, jog and cycle and spend a morning.
Beautiful Park. Amazing massive park, with nice old trees and some temples. Wonderful to walk in on a hot day. Make sure to go to the water-lily pond, see the temples and the koy :)

Quiet during the Winter Holidays. If you decide to go to Ueno Park in the last 2 weeks of December, check to see if anything is open. Many of the museums and sites in the park close during this time. At that time of year, my recommendation is to call ahead or have your hotel call for opening hours as the websites aren't always up-to-date. At other times of the year, there are so many things to do in a small area: museums, gardens, a zoo, small shops.

The Central Park of Tokyo. Ueno Park is extremely easy to get to by subway. After you exit the subway, the park is across the street. Just follow the hoards of people exiting the station if you're a bit lost. Entrance to the park is free but entrance into the zoo has a fee. The park is filled with Street Performers, families picnicking, bikes, kids, and snack carts. There are a few museums, temples, and the zoo. I suggest packing a lunch because the nearby coffee shops are usually packed with people. There are a few restaurants (mostly Japanese food but there is an Italian cafe) located inside of Ueno Station if you're hungry, but it it's better to sit outside under the gorgeous cherry blossoms.

Lovely, well-used urban park. Walking through the park after visiting the Tokyo National Museum, we found a sea of picnickers gathered under the Sakura trees. Family groups and friends sitting on tarps, with only inches between the groups, blossoms drifting all around them, clearly having a wonderful time. Walkways and paths were crowded with visitors.

A lot to do. This was a pretty large park right near public transportation. There was a zoo, coffee shops, street performers, temples, gardens, a lake, and museums in the area. I spent half a day wandering and relaxing in the park.

A little bit of everything in a small area. I had heard wonderful things about Ueno Park so we took the train from Tokyo center. It was only three stops for us and we crossed the street, climbed the stairs and found ourselves in the park. It isn't marked well at all so ask if you aren't sure you are in the right place. Only one entrance had a guard station and maps so we started out a bit in the dark. There are numerous wonderful museums in the park: the National museum, the Science Museum, the Metropolitan Art museum and the Museum of Western Art. There is a small zoo, amusement rides for kids,and a lake. The lake was so overgrown with lilies that a boat could not even find water! The entire park, except around the museums , seemed to be in need of upkeep. There were not a lot of places for sitting except around the museum area. The Tosho-gu Shrine was wonderful and had a lovely setting not far from the five story 17th C pagoda which is situated in the zoo. There are several restaurants near the museum area, the largest being Starbucks, where there are also restrooms. There was some sort of a parade when we were there and a lot of families enjoying the day.It is a great place to bring children as it gives them the option to explore in a nice area.

Nice to escape from the crowd. Although it is located in the very busy Ueno district, the Ueno Park is a nice park to enjoy a bit of silence and of peace. There are a couple of museums within the park, and a zoo as well, so you can easily spend two or three hours there.

Pretty park to walk around. It was really nice to walk in the gardens, even though we were too late for the main cherry blossom season. There were still some late varieties in mid- April. Great to walk around the lake. Very relaxing.

Nice park but far from mindblowing. It's a nice littlee park where locals go to enjoy the weekend. Tourists also congregate there for some reason probably because of the zoo. While its nice, it's really nothing fantastic outside the sakura season. Sometimes you do have street musicians and bands playing and those are really good! Nothing beats a leisurely stroll coupled with soothing music. The shopping district around ueno park is really good though! Many cheap and quality products around here, and there are also a few very good sashimi don chain restaurants here that are really the cheapest in town.

Lovely park, Scorching hot. Try to go early in the morning or later in the evening. Otherwise, get there in the middle of the day and be prepared to burn. It was sooooo hot when I was there. Good thing that the Tokyo National Museum was at the northern end of the park and I dashed in as quickly as I could.
Great Park. Mid April is a great time to visit here as the Locals have picnics and festivals to celebrate the Cherry Blossom season

Great Time @ Ueno Park. This place was great & worth to spend a day if really have enough time as during our visit in May14, the weather was so good which will make u feel so relaxed & the park is so clean.. Lots of museum in this park such as National Museum, Art Museum, Science Musem & also got zoo too.. Do mark this place in your itinerary ^^
Most goo. The sakuras are beautiful during the spring and even if is not spring it's a enjoyable place with a few temples. The zoo and the museums

Beautiful in cherry blossom season. We visited Ueno park towards the end of the cherry blossom season, the trees were still in bloom and the park was extremely busy. It didn't take away from the experience though. We rented a swan boat for a trip around the lake which was lovely. Street performers were on the main thoroughfare which was cool. Would definitely recommend a visit to Ueno Park. It's a really nice place to hang out!

So much to do and discover at Ueno Park. One can spend the whole day exploring, but if you've had your fill of zoos, museums, shrines, and galleries, and you just don't want to exert the effort on pedal boats, a quiet bench facing the lake may just do the trick. The park's food stalls are nearby in case you need an instant picnic.

Great time @ a great park. It was a weekend we spent @ ueno . Rented a boat ,had a great time paddling .Stalls at the park gave an opportunity to try some local delicacies .Its a place one can spend an entire day .there is a museum & zoo so art enthusiasts & kids too have a gud time .Watched a dance show which was fun

Great place to spend a day. I love visiting Ueno Park. There is so much to see and do here, it's a great place to spend a day, especially a sunny day in the summer. It's nice to sit and relax, picnic in the park, or sightsee around the park. In the summer, I paid for the swan pedal-boat ride and had a lot of fun. It was relaxing and fun. There are also so many museums that you can visit within the park (recommend the Tokyo National Museum and National Museum of Nature and Science, but there are many others too). The Ueno Zoo is also located here. There is so much to do at the park -- I recommend it.
Perfect. I was really surprised about everything in Japan. All very clear and amazing. People, parques and culture. At Ueno park I saw for the first time a panda!!!

Still interesting !. We were here two years ago at the peak of the Cherry Blossoms season and it had been one of the highlights of our trip in Japan ! This year, unfortunately , the season was ending and the spectacle was not as glamorous ! We still spent a lot of time in this lovely park , this time walking along the lake , visiting museums and taking the free guided walking tour of the Park . Again the tour was not as interesting as the last time probably because it was a different guide and his itinerary was not as good ! Nevertheless it was still a lovely way to spend a day in Tokyo !
Beautiful Park. A place that I would sit there do nothing but enjoy the beauty of nature, the cherry blossom under cool daylight.

Where we first saw Sakura in Japan. My friend and I were in the Ueno area late night but we didn't get to Ameyoko on time. So we were tired and walking around until I spotted sakura! It was our first time to see them and we were really awed, like our exhaustion melted and we were very happy and accomplished because we timed our visit to view the sakura. We visited last week of March and we really hoped for it. We didn't mind that all the trees weren't in full bloom, when we saw this it's enough. We went back in the morning to take pictures.

During Cherry Blossoms. Do this! If you are here for Cherry Blossoms (I use capatals out of respect!), don't miss this park. It's magical to wander under these trees ~ I will remember this among all our travels ~

Lake Temple. Such a beautiful park to spend a lazy morning walking around. Closest metro station is Keisei Ueno or the huge JR Ueno. There's a number of ticketed attractions in the park, notably the Zoo and the highly recommended Tokyo National Museum. For free though it is just as pleasant wandering about the park with all the other Japanese. The lake is particularly nice to walk around. Half the lake is choked with lotus flowers, the other half is a boating lake. A path lined with snack vendors leads to a small temple in the middle of the lake.

Relax city park~. although i went it after full Sakura full blossom season which it just after few days~ but is fortunately still can saw the Sakura as well~ is a very nice gathering or walk in the park it is very it full of Japanese relaxing under the Sakura tree~ the park is very near Metro/JR station as well at Ueno Station ~ it also have provided locker for traveller/visitor ~

Beautiful Park. The park is large. Take a leisurely stroll and look for the amazing museums, zoo, pond, and picnic areas. It's awesome during cherry blossom season! To see it in pictures is nice, to see the trees in full bloom is serene. Take your bentos and drinks and enjoy!
It's a park, it's nice. It's beautiful but not something to write home about.There are some interesting things inside though, like the zoo (Pandas!)

Ok park. Probably incredible in march. Walking down the paths filled with cherry trees I can just assume how once dible it would have been to seem them in full bloom. But NOPE. I came in may and the trees are just green. Still a nice park to stroll through with performed and lots of museums and shrines. Recommend the Tokyo national museum
Must visit.. Besides shopping, Ueno park is a great place to visit even off-sakura season. The trees, the shrine, the temple are always comforting.

Excellent hanami!. The best and most enjoyable hanami, almost a party, in Japan.. I had it at Ueno Park...if you want to enjoy the cherry blossom, try to be late March beginning April in the country...
Sakuras. A must during cherry blossom season. People camp out with food and games. Very scenic area as the pink leaves are all around you.

A great spot for cherry blossoms. Lovely park, great cherry blossoms through a pond. Seeing families having all kinds of fun, either stretched out on blue tarps, or paddling around the pond on swan boats.

Beautiful park. We loved it here.. Ueno Park is beautifully landscaped with walk ways and small streams throughout. We happened to be there in early April 2014. The cherry blossoms were in full bloom. All the grassy areas were covered in blue tarp. People were sitting on the the tarps picnicking and visiting. It was very crowded yet the atmosphere was joyous. We walked to a small temple that had an overlook down a hill, across a street to a long row of vendors. At the end of that row was another temple and a lake that was edged in more cherry blossoms. Another part of the park had a beautiful reflecting pond that put on a spraying water show every 15 minutes or so. There were musicians here and there. Past the reflecting pond they had a zoo, an art museum and a historical museum. We didn't go into the zoo or museums so I don't know if they had a fees. We really loved visiting Ueno Park and we hope to come back again some day.

Just ok. If you are keen on cultural pursuits you will enjoy this park but as a place for a stroll a sit down and a cup of coffee it leaves alot to be desired. Compared to the East Garden it is a disappointment but if you are not expecting too much its ok. It was a dull day and a park can and should lift the spirits but apart from the very cool saxophone player there was nothing to appeal to my senses.

Arts, Culture and open space!. Ueno is a beautiful park not far from Ueno Station. In the grounds there are many attractions including the Tokyo National Museum, the National Museum for Western Art, the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum and the National Science Museum. It is also has the Ueno Zoo.We began our exploration at Shinobazu Pond, and visited the Shitamachi Museum to see original houses and shops from the turn of the century. English guides are offered free of charge. We also visited the Toshugu Shrine and the National Museum of Western Art, in a beautiful building designed by Corbusier.The grounds are beautiful, and although it was after cherry blossom time, there were still late-flowering remnants.

Best park to go for Cherry Blossom. Ueno is huge park and have so many cherry blossom trees along the walking path. It was very crowding and alot of Japanese people sit on side with their friends and drink alot of alcohols. I really enjoy going there to enjoy view of Cherry Blossom trees and eating foods from vendor booth. They have a pond where you can rent either a row boat or foot paddle boat. I rented a row boat with my girlfriend and she loved it! It romantic for her and she felt like she is the captain of the boat haha! Just be aware that you might encounter with monk who aggressive tried to give you a blessing card or a beads bracelet. If you take it, he will demand you to pay for it. Just say no thank and keep on walking.

Crowded but fun... a very popular spot for cherry blossoms parties or Hana-mi, as they say in Japanese, it was crowded, but we joined the crowd, and enjoyed the sakura or cherry blossoms. Endless cherry trees, and during that period we were there, cherry trees were all lit at night. Although very crowded, we enjoyed every moment and had a taste of sake under the cherry tree with some friendly young Japanese group!
Great day out. Ueno park is a great place to visit with kids.Nice Zoo, great cherry blossom viewing and heaps more we didn't get time to see
Relaxing and good for wildlife. Plenty of wildlife, including Herons hunting in the reeds and a great atmosphere when the Japanese hold their Cherry blossom parties.

Great Place to see Cherry Blossom. The park is an excellent place to view the cherry blossoms lining the pathways but its main attraction has to be people watching. On the first Sunday in April, when I visited, the place was crowded with Tokyoites and some foreign tourists (like me) all enjoying the spring weather and blossoms. This is one of the main places for traditional Hanami parties under the cherry trees and there was not an inch spare. Everyone was enjoying themselves which was completely infectious.
Cherry blossom!. Love the park esp the cherry blossoms! Nice spot for picnics. Surrounding areas have nice eateries and shops

Very typical of Tokyo, must be seen if you are there. I like Ueno park since it is really for Tokyo what Central Park is for NY City: the place where the inhabitants go to relax and meet.The area around the park is also very interesting

Cherry blossom season. Came here during the evening on a weekday to look at the cherry blossoms. Beautiful park, full of families and businessmen having picnics on their blue tarps. The orange-red lanterns were beautiful, illuminating the white and pinkish cherry blossoms. There were also a lot of food vendors as well as games for children. We ate some smoked fish, corn, yakitori, and takoyakis during our stroll through the park.
A nice part of Tokyo. This place is very large, with many gardens, lake, temples... Ueno was on of my favorite place in Tokyo, I recommand it.

Visited for Sakura- Totally worth it!. Though we slightly missed the full bloom here by just couple days, we were not disappointed!!We got to see some hanami parties & were able to photograph some really beautiful flowers! No wonder it is one of the most visited and photographed location for Sakura!

Sakura Trees Everywhere.... Visited Ueno Park on a weekend and i don't think i have seen so many people in the one place. The cherry blossoms were beautiful and were everywhere you looked. Lots of people were on tarps and having picnics and it looked very inviting. The park is just a little walk across Ueno station too!
Skip it .... ... if it isn't cherry blossom season. Visited mid-afternoon on a week day 2 weeks after Sakura and found it unremarkable at best.

Hanami - Cherry Blossom. I've done the Hanami (cherry blossom viewing) with my bestie at Ueno park on 6th April, when the Sakura have its full bloom! So lucky we are. We went for the weekday so there is not so crowded. Their government has all the picnic carpeted set up with sufficient facilities such as toilets and waste dustbin everywhere,. Food stalls next to the park are full of traditional and tasty Japanese streets food. we enjoy so much on the fried noodle, tori yaki (basically all grill food), crepe and of course do not forget the Japanese Beer!

Best time to come here is during Hanami!. One of the best places in Tokyo to experience Hanami, or the madness of cherry blossom viewing. A frenetic but happy mix of people drinking, eating and socialising on blue tarps under the beautiful cherry trees. There are many food stalls selling everything from barbequed corn cobs on a stick to noodles to tempura prawns, there are many shrines to visit and pay your respects, and a lake lined with more cherry trees to take a ride in the swan-shaped peddle boats. We were here on April 2, and the place was packed with people which gave it an exciting atmosphere. The only thing to be aware of was a man dressed as a buddhist monk scouring the crowd for foreign tourists and trying to extract yen out of you by giving you a wooden bead bracelet and a prayer card, then demanding you give him money for these items, then asking for more to give blessings to your family and children.Ueno Park is easily accessed by train, and also within the park area is the Ueno Zoo and other cultural buildings.

Cherry Blossoms and Swan Boats. We visited just at the end of the Cherry Blossom season but there were still some to see. Everyone was out in the sun, drinking and eating. There were food stands that sold everything like oysters, corn, mochi and ice cream. Make sure you go down to the lake and rent one of the paddle boats, it was so much fun to do!

Cherryblossom in Tokyo. Ueno park is a great spot if you want to check out some cherryblossom in spring.The atmosphere is great especially in the eveing when lanterns light up the park.If you really want to enjoy I suggest you to grab a Bento box and some sake and spend some time for a pick nic in the park.

Beautiful cherry tree lined pathways. We visited at the end of March in the peak of the Sakura season and there were thousands and thousands of people doing the same thing. It was incredibly busy but all in good nature. There were lots of people having picnics and there were also food stalls near the zoo entrance where you could get anything from corn on the cob to squid rings to noodles etc.Part of the fun of this place was seeing the sakura and all the Japanese people who have also come to see the sakura. It is a real cultural experience to watch.
Awesome attraction during Spring Season. Visit this park between late March to early April and behold the beauty of the Cherry Blossoms (Sakura)

blissfilled spring day. We had the best (cheapest) day in Ueno Park, yes, we were very lucky to have wonderful weather but enjoyed every minute from the moment we arrived in Ueno station and strolled up the blossom lined avenues - eventually shopping for coffee around the middle of the park. We ate lunch and found ourselves at the boating lake where our kids 4 & 7 enjoyed the peddleoes

Excellent use of a morning in Tokyo. Ueno Park is an gorgeous park full of shrines and temples, and it has an interesting history to boot! Our guide was knowledgeable and friendly and told us the history of the park, where to visit when the tour completed, and how to act at the shrines and temples. I wasn't sold on Ueno when my guidebook recommended it, but I'll recommend it (along with this tour) to all my friends who visit Tokyo from now on.

Cherry blossoms and picnics. Ueno Park was a lovely place to view the cherry blossoms and experience the culture of "hanami". While it was quite crowded - with pedestrians viewing the trees and picnickers enjoying their lunches - it was nice to be able to walk right up to the trees and really see the blossoms. I also went to the Imperial Palace to see the cherry blossoms and the trees were roped off there - though admittedly the crowds were huge and I'm sure they wanted to protect the trees, as well as the Palace. In Ueno Park, there are over 1000 trees and they are of different varieties - so you will see different types and colors of blossoms. The park itself is a nice place to spend a day - after viewing the cherry blossoms, I went to the Tokyo National Museum which is located within the park. Friends from the US, who also travel to Tokyo on business have mentioned enjoying the zoo, as well. The park is right across the street from the Ueno Station so very easy to access.
Excellent place. In Spring cherry trees are wonderful in this park! There is full of people enjoying the park. You can't miss it!
Great park. It is a great park with many cherry trees that were in full bloom at end of March. A bit crowded but understandable cause so beautiful.

One of the best places to view Sakura flowers blooming.. One of the best places to view Sakura Trees bloom. It's up there with Iwakuni, Kyoto's Maruyama Park and Kyoto's Philosopher's walk.
The trees here were so tall the branches overlapped each other and made this gorgeous arch of blooms above you as you walked. Lovely park right outside the Ueno Zoo.
Beautiful park. Big beautiful park was full of cherry blossoms blooming when I was there plenty of tourist stuff around too zoo is here tokyo national museum across the street plus lots more
Cherry blossom. A very good place for cherry blossom viewing and lots of other things to do as well. Family activities as well

The right place for "hanami"/sakura viewing. We went to this park end of March for "hanami" or sakura viewing. The park is gorgeous with sakura blossom almost at its every corner. Take a stroll inside the park to enjoy the beautiful scenery. Those with children can enter Ueno zoo which located at the end of the park. Entrance fee is applicable for the zoo. Street vendors selling local food such as takoyaki, grilled fish, squids and noodle can be easily found near the zoo. Try the squid fried with soy sauce, it's pretty tasty.There're some small temples inside the park one of them has Buddha face or Daibutsu nestled on top of the hill. Shinobazu Pond, a natural lake is located at the southern part of the park. You may need to cross the street from the park. It was said the pond full with lotus but we didn't find one when we visited the pond. Sakura blossom by the pond is fabulous. This is in fact a better place to take pictures as the trees are low so you can just stand next to beautiful sakura. Just be patient to get your turn to strike a pose as so many people won't easily be satisfied to take two or three pictures in one spot. Those in romantic mood may canoeing the pond. Ueno park is at it's busiest time end of March or early April. Thousands of people may visit the park since early morning to evening. The amazing thing is that the park remains clean regardless the crowd.

Not just a park. This is a large popular park and has many things to offer. At the moment it seems that all of Tokyo is there to see the cherry blossom which is in full bloom, creating a tunnel of white where the hundreds of trees line the avenue walkways. Although it was crowded it was very safe and offered great people watching .... watching the locals watching the blossom was amazing. Try to go during the day and then come back at night to get two very different perspectives of the blossom. Whilst there we also got to see the enormous bronze statue of Saigo Takamori, the red lacquered Kiyomizu-kannon-do temple, the wild life sanctuary which is the Shinobazu Pond and Tokugawas shrine. Near by are many famous museums and a short walk will get you to the Yanaka cemetery which is certainly worth a look.

Cherry blossom and crowds. Upon a tip from the concierge at our hotel we went to Ueno park to watch the cherry blossoms. A very beautiful and special experience, yet thousands other visitors had decided to do the same thing. So, be prepared for very crowded passage ways. Personally I felt that seeing the cherry blossoms in the Shinjuku park was a far more romantic and pleasant (and beautiful) experience. However, at a Ueno park you'll see how locals picnic out in great crowds on the lawns and public areas. Lots of fun and noise. Seemed like a place for people watching and to be watched

Cherry blossom is approaching. A few trees already blooming and it looks like the rest are in not to many days. Also noticed the area was prepped with large quantities of garbage disposals. Ueno was nice at this point but i am guessing it will be much grander in a few days

Will be beautiful during sakura time. I was there in the middle of March and only two or three trees had sakura or cherry blossoms on them. With temple, shrine, zoo, museums and other small attractions, This place is perfect for everyone of all ages.

Lovely Park and Museums. Pretty part with Shrines to visit as well as the National Art Museum (1400 yen), National Science Museum (600 yen), and National Tokyo museum (which unfortunately we didn't get to visit).
Beautiful. It was the perfect way to spend my last day in Japan, strolling through Ueno Park. I wish I knew the name of the big plants there in the lake, but they are amazing.

Ueno Park. While I enjoyed the park I was not in Tokyo the right time of year to truly enjoy it all. It has Rodin sculptures which was nice to see given I have seen the ones in Paris as well. I did get into an art gallery which was also nice. The grounds are large and takes in a lot of area to walk around. Some nice memorials to see as well as a temple and pagoda. Would love to return in the spring for the cherry blossoms and sunshine. Sadly I was too late in the day for the National Museum but will try next trip.

Ueno Park, Tokyo's cultural heart!. If you only have a few days to spend in Tokyo, perhaps as a result of a layover, consider getting accommodation near Ueno Park. It has museums, galleries, concert halls, shrines, history, temples, and quiet places for reading and contemplation. It offers in a relatively small area, much of what Japanese culture has to offer. Ueno Train Station is also the terminal for the express train from the airport.
Cool park. Lots of shrines and lakes to see. Also next door to the zoo if that is on your list. Would be good for kids as they have little swan boats you can take out.

Big park, nothing spectacular. I visited Ueno Park this January, and I thought it was just OK. I liked the fountain, the museums and the Toshogu Shrine. Kiyomizu Kannon and the statues of Dr. Nagoya and the Imperial Prince were also pretty neat. To me, the rest of the park didn't seem all that spectacular... I think maybe I went into it expecting a lot more. For me, Bentendo was a bit disappointing, and the park itself wasn't as nice as I was expecting, though I did go in winter so that might have something to do with it. While I probably wouldn't go back if I went to Tokyo again, I would recommend visiting both the Tokyo National Museum, and the National Science Museum, which are both located inside the park.

Good for a walk. If you are looking for a place to have a walk and to relax, you can visit this park. I bet this is good to visit in spring. The time we went there is still winter time and most trees have no leaves. Though finding food is not a problem coz there are lot of food stalls inside and it has starbucks inside the park. You can also find museum, zoo and others. This Park is also accessible by JR line and easy to find. If you are getting a tokunai pass, you can definitely drop by on this park for a visit.

Better in summer than winter!. I loved Ueno Park when I visited a few years ago in summer, in particular the beautiful lily ponds. In winter it's not quite as impressive, and it seems they are removing a lot of the grass/natural walkways and replacing them with cement, but Ueno Park is still a great place for a walk and the fountain linking the Park with the Art Museum is impressive.

Nice walk in the park. This place is good for relax. There is a lake where you can rent a boat, it is full of green. I had the privilege to visit this place at the time of Sakura season with festivities. Lots of people visit this place in the evening for drinks and very nice food which you can get in almost any stand in the park.

The first park in Japan!. Ueno Park is the first official park that Japan has ever had, and wow it's so beautiful!We visited Tokyo during summer, but my call is to visit in during spring, so you'll be amazed by the cherry tree in blossom...of which Ueno Park is full.What you'll notice as soon as you're near the park is the welcoming never-ending call of the cicalas scattered on every trees, but you'll get used to it soon. The park itself is really beautiful, houses the Bell of Time and 2 museums (Tokyo nationa museum and National Museum of Nature and Science) and it's a good place to eat a bento during lunch time :)

A park with performances. As a park the park at Ueno in Tokyo isn't so spectacular. It is more of a walk through park than a sit down park if you ask me. But there is som extra park life to it that could be worth the visit, at least in the weekends. Because then there is this different performances in the park, for example music, and that is really great I think. So if your going to any of the museums in the area at an weekend, maybe weekdays as well, take som extra time and see if you can find any performances going down in the park!

most excellent adventure. Everytime I visited this park I found something new to do. From the real life like looking people statues at the museum to the zoo, to the dome theatre to the expansive walking areas to the quaint and popular starbucks to the restaurant. coolest park I've been to so far. The street artists that pop up are always such a sight. They do amazing things. I would recommend this to anybody and everyone. No matter who you are this is another world within a park.

Lots of temples and a Starbucks. A great place to see some temples and people watch for free. The park is about a 5 min walk from the train station. I will admit there isn't anything amazing but it does let you see sample old Japan.

typical area. lot of temples and really lovely park.
Apart from the park this area is full of typical restaurants and shops (follow train rails because good and typicals restaurants are often below)
Relaxing. Nice place to sit and walk through. Nothing stunning, but a nice walk nontheless. Surprisingly peaceful.

Just a public park. We went there early morning. Very big park, but nothing special. Maybe it was a bad season to go there. The pond were full of dead lotus, very ugly. There were many homeless people in the park. just a bit disappointed.

Public park with many attractions. Ueno Park is one of the Japan most famous site to view cherry blossoms in April every year. However, the autumn scenery view is quite beautiful as well. The area also houses three museums with Tokyo National Museum being the prominent one, The National Science Museum and The Museum of Western Art. Besides that, Ueno Zoo is also located within Ueno Park compound. This area is quite popular tourist attraction area and recreation area for both Japanese and foreigners. Great view for free.

Large park, lots to do. I would give the entire area and all attractions a 4/5 even though I didn't get to visit many of the individual attractions and the area is definitely worth a visit. The park itself is still worth visiting though it is very much a standard park, albeit with great Japanese landscaping and that's why I give it a 3/5.The park is located close to Ueno Station so it was quite convenient to get to. There are numerous attractions located in the park - numerous museums, a zoo, a few restaurants, shrines, water fountains, and more. Unfortunately, we went to the park on a Monday, so many attractions were closed. The Tokyo National Museum was closed as well as the zoo. So the first thing to know is make sure you don't go on a Monday. The most picturesque area, IMHO, is near the lake/ponds near the southwest/west area of the park. You can rent boats there and there is also a small pond there to feed some hungry fish. You can also see a nice view of Taito in this area.There is also some small shrines in the park area, though the one I visited - Ueno Toshogu Shrine - is a smaller, average run of the mill shrine that's really not worth a separate visit and can be skipped.

Large but not that Scenic. Its an enormous park right next to the Ueno subway station. Houses a small zoo suitable for so families with kids. Good place to walk dogs or cycle but not very scenic i.e. flower gardens, water features etc. Nevertheless, a nice relaxing walk thru to the National, Science and Technology Museums. I was there on a weekend mid afternoon and was treated to a street performer stunt show with stacked chairs. Really surprised to see something like that in the middle of a Japanese park.

Nice park within Tokyo. I spent half a day at the park. It is an easy subway ride. Even in November there were lots of trees still in full color. The lotus ponds and cherry trees must be very beautiful in the spring. The park was full of locals including several school groups. I went to two of the 5 museums. Shitamachi Museum is small but very interesting as has a reconstruction of several wooden homes and shops from the early 20th century. The upstairs is full of day-to-day cultural items from the period. A volunteer, English speaking guide added a lot to the visit. Also went to the National Museum which is a very impressive collection of Japanese artwork. The Park Side Cafe is a nice stop for lunch. The Ameyoko Shopping district is across the street from the park and next to Ueno subway stop. Fascinating to wander the streets to see the fish and dry good market along with all kinds of clothing and other vendors. The park itself is free, but there are small charges for the museums and zoo.

AWESOME!. It's the most beautiful park and ueno zoo is there too... It's great to spend a day here and see everything park is amazing with shrines and monument statues it's really a nice place I highly recommend to visit :-)

Not the Prettiest Park in Tokyo. This park is huge, but when we were here there were a lot of homeless men. The park also had a foul smell to it, maybe due to the former? Maybe a good place to walk and get some exercise. It is right across from Ueno Station and a great, local farmers market called Ameyoko Shopping Street. I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come here.

So much to see but best get there early on the weekend. This is a very large park which includes several museums, Tokyo zoo, a temple and a shrine. You could easily spend an entire day here.
The added bonus is the people watching. Not as crazy as Harajuku but still quite interesting.

Great place to chill out. Uneo park is a great place to go and relax if you're getting sick and tired of the hussle and bussle of Tokyo. There's planty to see there with the zoo, museum and art gallery so its also an essential place to go for sight seeing needs.

Ueno Park and Zoo. I went here before I went to the zoo and we were just walking around enjoying how big the park was and how it was not full of hustle and bustle like it seemed everywhere else in the city was. There are all sorts of things to see here apart from the park; there is a zoo and an art gallery. I would recommend a visit to here before you enter the zoo.

For a quiet moment in Tokyo. Ueno Park is a breather from the bustle of rest of Tokyo. Was passing by the station and had an impulsive moment to visit. Time well spent ;)Recommended for the autumn view, but will not have visited if was not along my route, believe there are even grander parks.

Lovely Area of Tokyo. We come to Tokyo every other year or so and usually stay near Ueno Park, which beckons to me during each visit, especially during cherry blossom time. The myriad cherry trees flank a long, wide walkway and the view of the blossoms during a stroll here is stunning. Locals spread blankets beneath the trees, where they enjoy food, drink and conversation. I have been to all the areas of Tokyo that feature cherry blossoms and Ueno Park remains my favorite place to see them.But the park also offers attractions year-round. It holds the zoo (home to two pandas) and the following museums: Tokyo National Museum, National Science Museum, National Museum of Western Art, Shitamachi Museum and the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Art, where I have attended some excellent exhibitions. Just yesterday, I saw one there focused on Turner. It featured 110 watercolors and paintings by the artist. Other stops for wanderers include temples, shrines and a huge pond, where paddle boats and rowboats can be rented.Sometimes it is nice to go to the park just to amble, away from the city's frenetic pace. Though lots of people are always there, the huge park accommodates them easily. There are many places to stop for a bite to eat or a hot or cold drink, including a very popular Starbucks. Ueno Park is easily accessed by the JR Yamamota line and via the metro Hibiya and Ginza lines.

Worth a visit. If you've ran out of things to do in the busy city or would like to just stroll around somewhere more quiet, then this place is worth the visit. Unfortunately i don't remember any specific rare animals. The park itself is quite big which would most likely benefit the animals and also give your mind some time to digest everything around you.

green oasis to recover from busy tokyo. nice and generously arranged park with a lot of gingko trees and a cherry tree tree alley which must be stunning during the cherry blossom time (I was only there in October/November). in ueno park you can find all sorts of tokyoties from punks to business men, from school kids to old ladies painting with water colors, young and old families, ladies in kimonos... a bit hidden you can find the "flame of Hiroshima". a big American coffee franchise has its restaurant in the middle of the park, zoo (not visited) is also located within the park and some museums. worth a visit any time!

Great experience. The park is rather big, but not huge. It's pretty cozy, but I wouldn't spend a whole day there. On some of the benches, people were sleeping, but it didn't bother me. People were walking their dogs there and it seemed to be a pretty chill place where normal Japanese people would go to hang out. Inside the park is also Ueno Zoo which was nice!

Lovely!. I loved this park!! I travelled solo to Japan and I just loved to just sit down by the water fountain in Ueno Park and enjoy the cool autumn weather.Nothing over-the-top here but this makes it even more perfect. Worth dropping by if you're in Taito!
Nice park. It was ok to walk around after visiting National museum. I can't say it's a must, but if you have time and the weather is good, then why not.
Breath-taking. This place is huge! We didn't get to explore all parts of the park. But it's definitely worth it if you visit here. Very beautiful park indeed!

上野公園 (Ueno-kōen) – A lovely park with an engaging mix of leisure with culture!. One can exit from Ueno JR station turn right and walk up a fleet of steps to reach Ueno Park. This is Tokyo oldest public park and also part of the historical Shitamachi neighborhood. It is normal that people throng it’s fairly wide pavements with trees on either side, especially famed for its growth of cherry trees.
