The park is big for one to spend close to a full day exploring around if you go and visit the slew of attractions – from museums to shrines/temples to even a zoo.! . This is definitely a welcome respite from the maddening crowds of Tokyo’s other attractions like Harajuku and Shibuya – a pleasant city escape! Here you'll find the National Museum of Western Art, National Museum of Nature and Science (Tokyo's version of the Smithsonian), Tokyo Metro Art Museum, Shitamachi Museum as well as the Tokyo National Museum. Other not-to-be-missed are the Ueno Zoo, “flame of Nagasaki” and statue of Komatsu Akihito. Not to mention the beautiful and scenic Shinobazu pond (不忍池 ) and the ‘mother-of-meeting place’ – the steps below Saigo Takamori.. There are also food and souvenir stands around the park to replenish the tired-hunger soul...And another ‘attractions’ – the 2 (or more) little cats nesting comfortably at a tree branch.. It is always packed with visitors attracted by them and taking photographs of them..! I am not exactly a ‘Park’ person but Ueno Park make me feel relax and instantly in a holiday mood (a similar feel I had years back in Hyde Park).Definitely a sure visit for me when in Tokyo.

Hanami Time. I visited Ueno park in late march. Right in the middle of Hanami. Stunning really :) Al you need is good weather and you can easy spend 1 - 2 days here. Lots of museums if the weather is bad. Like National, nature and science Museums. Bring a blanket and a basket of beer, sake and some snacks and you are all set :)
Ragged-around-the-edges public space. It's looking a bit tired - could do with a little maintenance. There are some cafes, however, if you need a little refreshment.

good. A sprawling area that houses the Ueno Park has Ueno Zoo, Ueno Lake and several museums; National Museum of Western Art, National Museum of Science and Nature and the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum; all of which are within walking distance and makes it a pleasant day out. The National Museum of Sciecne and Nature is very educational for young children, with many exhibits and basic translation in English. Entrance for children is free.

great place for walking. We walked though this park each night for a week, and enjoyed it the more we got to know it. We watched snippets of a baseball game, saw school girls dancing, admired the waterlilies and temples. There were lots of different walkways to explore. It's not so much designed for tourists as it is for those who live and go to school there.

Just a way to relax. Traveling and visiting sites, and there is a lot to see in Tokyo and around, it can be tiredness sometime. Ueno Park is a nice way to spend some relaxing time walking around with a few temples, ponds, zoo for the children (free under 12), and what's left of the lake to walk around or to paddle on; because most of it is cover with high lotus plant.You have a easy access from the Ueno subway station (280Y/1 way or 600Y for a day pass)
Cool place. Lots to see in here, temples, zoo, baseball, fair and not too big that you can't see it all. Nice atmosphere.
Visit during your extra days in Tokyo. Very nice, but if it is not the blossoming time, it will be just another park, very nice, but nothing extraordinary.

Popular spot for Japanese families. Ueno Park is one of the most popular places in Tokyo for Japanese families to spend the day. The largest city park in Japan, Ueno contains a zoo, historic monuments, and museums including the Tokyo National Museum. Be aware that on Mondays most of the museums will be closed. It's a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours and I would definitely do it on a day when you can visit the National Museum.

Cherry Blossoms. If you want to experience the real cherry blossoms,this is the park to visit! The first time we entered the park we were amazed how beautiful the trees with all the flowers surrounding us. Everywhere you walk you can truly feel Japan's cherry blossoms at its finest! A must to see when visiting Tokyo.

A nice park for a walk. My friend and I went here to kill some time.
The park was huge and nice.
There was some local performance event held on the day I passed there.
On the night, when we walked around, there were some people doing wotagei.
Just a heads up, there are many homeless in the area.
ok. it was ok, but when we went most of the museums, interesting place was shut. but a good place to relax

Beautiful park. Directly from the train station a beautiful park featuring temples, a zoo, and beautiful gardens. We spent a happy Morning wondering before going to the zoo then going off for some shopping.
Visited almost every day!. This huge park boasts museums, cafes, boat rides and lots of places to walk and relax. It's the perfect getaway in a downtown situation.

Visit it more for a glimpse of Tokyoites enjoying a day out. Nothing of particular note stands out here (although the incredibly large leaves and beautiful, pink flowers of the plants which grow in Shinobazu Pond certainly catch the eye).There is a small shrine, Bentando, on a strip of land which crosses the pond and there is Kiyomizu Kannondo, a smallish temple. Neither of them, were they on their own in the middle of the city, would qualify as something going out of your way to see though.The Tokyo National Museum, Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum, Western Art Muesum and National Science Museum (with its seemingly life-sized whale rising some three or four stories into the air) are not reviewed here because they are sights unto themselves.What you would come to the park to see, however, is Tokyoites relaxing on a day out with their families. It is a people-watching place. Many visit the Zoo (which I did not visit and which is not reviewed here either). The park is lined with cherry trees (not in bloom when I was there) which I'd imagine would change the appeal of the park in spring.If your purpose for visiting other countries is to observe other cultures and ways of life and not simply to tick off sights gleaned from guide books or picked up from conversations with friends or family who have visited, this should be on your list of places to visit. There’s no shortage of places to see Tokyoites at work throughout the city but this is one of a handful that will give you a window into how they spend their off time with their families.

Nature. I went here often because its near to my bf office. The park is in the center of the city, lot of Japanese & foreigner goes here cause its public park that also have small temple. I always practice to ride my bicycle here before & I love to sat on the bench after I rode my bicycle, I've just look at the duck in the river & watch sunset... If your hungry you can eat in restaurant inside the park or near by restaurant they have lot of restaurant near by like mcdo, Fridays & so on...

Nice Park - Best combine it with the National Museum or the Zoo!. It's not the most beautiful/biggest/tidiest/... Park I've seen (even in Tokyo), but its worth a visit if you are already in Ueno. It provides a peaceful place with some attractions like temples, shrines and even a small amusement park for kids. !!!! BUT BEWARE OF THOSE FAKE MONKS !!!!The two times we were there we had been approached by old men in brown robes and white hats with little Buddha-pictures in their hands. The first time we listened - as naive as we were - but when he "asked" (or better pushed) for a donation of 20000 Yen (yep, the number is correct) at the entrance of a Shinto shrine (yep, that's not his religion) we smelled that something must be fishy. WE REPORTED IT ALREADY TO THE POLICE (their box is between the Zoo entrance and the main gate), who was pretty surprised by those unwanted pests in "their" park. So if you see one/talk to one (we even saw one in Akihabara), report it to the nearest Police station, since they seem to operate Tokyo wide. They had some problems with understanding simple English first, but drawing and an English speaking operator on the phone did the job quite well.

lots of things to do. there is a zoo in ueno park which one can enter for 600yen, which is really affordable! there are also many shrines, temples and museums in and around ueno park, so those who are looking to learn more about japanese culture can be richly rewarded by a visit there too.
Lots to offer. Ueno Park has much to offer. It's HUGE and it includes the Ueno Zoo, Shinobazu Pond, various museums, and sightseeing landmarks. I've never seen so much green in a city before.

A beautiful stroll. It felt like we stumbled into a locals only park. A beauitful park, strolling down the street. Getting coffee by the pond. A great place to refresh from the big city. An easy train ride to and from the park.

nice escape from crowded urban setting like central park. We enjoyed our stroll through Ueno Park. Nice shade and trees. Escaping the heat and urban surroundings. This is where we saw the largest contingency of homeless people in Tokyo. But we were not approached or felt unsafe. We went to the Zoo . Not fancy but inexpensive around 600 yen / person ( $ 6.00 ) . Lots of vending machines with cold drinks. Cute tram ride for the little ones. We were there around 15:00 . So they were feeding a lot of the animals .

Nice park for a pit stop. This is good park to take a break in while looking at all the surrounding attractions/museums. There's a Starbucks and a cafe and plenty of places to sit in the shade and watch the world go by if its a ridiculously hot and humid day in August. The lake is worth a detour to and there's another cafe down there.
Nice to walk around, with beautiful shrines. Worth a visit for a walk, walk up from the shopping district under the railway lines, well worth a wander around! There's a beautiful lotus pond

Nice spot, unbearable heat. Cherry Blossom or autumn can give you a better experience. When the heat is so explosive you might simply hope to enter a museum or a mall instead.Being in the middle of Tokyo, with lotus flowers in a great pond, among old trees and tall buildings, though, is very impressive.
Must see!. Very nice garden with a lot of activities and shows. There are signers and groups every where. Also the park is adjacent to so many museums which gives a good couple of hours here.

Worth a wander. There is a volunteer run guided tour around the park, which includes a brief summary of the history of the site, this is a great way to fully appreciate the significance of this lovely park. Thanks to Fuji San for his time and guidance

Huge park in Tokyo. Nice park but August is a hot season to visit that place. Sweat a lot. Make sure you carry an umbrella or use sun lotion as sun burn will be quite common. Worst will be if there's a heat wave. Though there are lots of trees but some areas can be scorching when standing under a direct sun light. I recommend to visit the Park in the later part of the day.

clean and fresh. There are zoo, shrines, museum, restaurants,... So many thing to see and to do, and they are for free. The park was clean and the atmosphere was good, It's far away from busy and noisy streets. This place is beautiful. I love sitting under the trees, chatting with friends or reading a book. Should visit here when you come to Tokyo!

Peace and prayers in a park. I lofed my visit here. It was just going to be a walk around, but it turned into so much more. I lofed the shrines and a sweet man taught me how to pray. He made it so special.

Lovely scenic park with Shrines, Zoo and museum nearby.. If you only have day in Tokyo, this is a definite place to visit during the day. Lovely scenery with shrines and museum close by. The Tokyo zoo is also there and entry price is very reasonable too. If you do go to the Zoo, bring your passport, there is a 20 per cent discount for visitors.
Just Beautiful. Was a really pleasant day spent at he park including the Zoo. If you are in the area, definitely worth a visit.

WOW!. Awesome place with plenty for everyone to do and I highly recommend the natural science museum, the kids loved it and so did the big kid in me. I have always wanted to visit a large museum like that. It is huge, large is an understatement. Be prepared to walk a lot. Highly recommended if you have kids and make a day of it.

Ueno Park makes me wanna live here.. Ueno Park is a great central location right above the Ueno Station, filled with museums, temples, shrines, gorgeous old trees, and lots of interesting people. If I lived nearby I'd visit daily if I could. Don't miss this excellent urban park!

Urban park with urban "issues". I visited only the park (and not the zoo or museums) on an extremely hot and humid day, so this affects my opinion. Large park with large pond, with coi if you like to feed them, but the water was dirty. Negatives: Park was littered with trash, and there were visible homeless-looking people on many of the benches. Bathrooms were dirty. Positives: lots of people strolling the park, good/very good street performers (reminding me of Washington Square Park in NYC). The food looked great - there was a variety of vendors. I had ice cream, which was refreshing.

Worth visiting. 5 minutes walk from Ueno station. 10 minute walk from Ueno-Okachimachi station. Very picturisque during Sakura season. However, the most interesting thing about the park are the food-stalls located there. Had the best charcoal grilled salmons there. Everything is priced at 500 yen.

Huge Park with many museums. If you have limited time to see Tokyo, a visit to this park would save you time and give you a good selection of things to see and do, since many museums and attractions are in it. Ueno station, close by is also probably the first station a visitor from Narita Airport will get off at if you take one of the Keisei Line trains from the airport.Here you'll find the Ueno Zoo, the National Museum of Western Art, National Museum of Nature and Science (Tokyo's version of the Smithsonian), Tokyo Metro Art Museum as well as the Tokyo National Museum (there are more, but I can't list them all here)Even if you don't have much funds and don't want to pay admission fees, it's also a good place to just hang around and people watch (especially on a weekend or Sunday). You'll find a variety of people here, from one act entertainers, families with kids frolicking in the fountain on a hot summer day, and even a group of young folks doing the twist (???) in `50's attire (complete with leather jackets in 90F degree weather) all afternoon.Unlike some parks in other countries, the place is very safe and clean. (No drunks on benches or that kind of sort)

Great park to walk through, huge with lots of attracions.. Has a zoo, kids area, shrines, restaurants, museums. Had an ice sculpture contest going on in 90 degree heat. Very cool ice sculptures. Lots of locals spending their Sunday afternoon with family. Right off the Ueno stop on the Ginza line. The lake was overgrown with Jurassic park looking lily pads. A little bit of homeless population up in the trees, first time to see that in Tokyo, but no one bothered me.
Very relaxing. Great little park near the university and the museums. Very relaxing place to get away from all the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.
Great place to spend an afternoon. Great park, great place to have coffee and people watch. They have a great fountain as well as great tree canopies and ponds.

Must see when in Tokyo!. There are 3 reasons why you should check out Ueno Park when you can. 1.) Its beautiful 2.) Its free admission 3. ) Please see previous. What I lot about this park is that its big and there a lot of things to do. You can check the Bentendo Tempole, ride a duck at the lake, walk around, or if you just want to sit and watch people go by you can certainly do. Also, there are many statues and monuments that can be found in the park. If you’re not convinced yet see the photos posted :)
Museum. Tip: Starbucks with comfy seats and good views (big).We walked along the park to go to the museum. It's a nice walk. The park is a pleasant place but a little busy.

Absolutely Beautiful. And Crammed With Things To Do!. I went to the park on my second day in Tokyo as it was extremely near where I was staying. I primarily went to go to the Zoo (and see the panda), but this park is an attraction in its own right. Its absolute enormous with a good 10+ routes of walk to choose from. Go at the right time of year and the cherry blossoms are in full bloom and its absolutely breathtaking. There's a few small typically Japanese style pagodas dotted around the centre of the park to look at as well as a bit of peace and quiet which can be hard to find in Tokyo. The park is literally on the doorstep of the exit of Ueno station so it is very easy to find. There's not particularly anywhere you can eat in the park but there is in the surrounding areas. If you are going to the zoo add extra time to have a look around this park, you wont regret it!
Big. Arive there in the subway and then walk around or rent a bike and see the area museums and the zoo, an ancient pagoda, and a life-size sculpture of a whale.

Cherry Blossom, Picnic, Zoo...all in one. It's the perfect spot for cherry blossoms. We went there on March 27th and was absolutely amazing. One of the highlights of our trip. There were lots of people, mainly Japanese, the weather was superb, a warm breeze made the petals of blossoms fly over you....breathtaking!This park is also perfect if you want to have a picnic. It's set with plastic mats under the trees and rubbish bins strategically placed.You can also visit a Japanese temple and even the zoo. What else you want to escape from the noisy city? It's simply p e r f e c t!!!!
Great walk in the city. Lots to see, A great escape from the city. the only problem is we visited on a Monday when the Zoo and amusement area was closed.

Great park for getting away from the hustle-bustle of the city. We were renting an apartment about 1/2 mile from Ueno Park, and visited the park several times during our 2-week stay. It is very pretty and quiet, but can seem "crowded" on a busy day. Be sure to visit the area around the lakes/ponds on the west side.

a very lovely area. We were in Ueno Park in early June. It is a very lovely area that is great for strolling and relaxing (especially after intense 5 days of sightseeing: o)) Ueno Park has a very easy access to various museums, shrines, and zoo. Besides, it is right next to the Ueno station, which makes it very convenient. We enjoyed walking through the park and making pictures. It was a perfect getaway from the busy and noisy streets.

A fun way to spend an afternoon. On a Sunday we walked a big circle in the park along with lots of Japanese families and couples. There were traditional Japanese group dances going on and musicians elsewhere. We visited the temple in the middle of the pond and enjoyed the food that lined the path to it. The food in broth (oden?) such as hot dogs, stuffed cabbage, tofu was very tasty; as were the grilled squid and fried chicken. The crepe vendor near Ueno zoo and the carnival rides was a hit, and they serve soft-serve ice cream, too.

A huge park where the National Museum is. Don't miss this because this is where the National Museum is. It would have been better if we had the entire morning for this. It has a nice park of sakura trees and a long stretch of walking. The museum in itself is a good stop for a crash course of Japanese history. I was also happy to note they had Christian artifacts in one of the galleries.

A nice, clean park. Great little pagodas, shrines, Lilly ponds and statues throughout as well as the zoo. I would highly recommend sitting on a bench after a long stroll through and people watching here

Not sure what the big highlight is about Ueno Park. Not sure why everyone says that you need to go to Ueno Park. When we went it was dirty and actually filled with a lot of homeless people. We left quite quickly as we felt a little uneasy.

Side trip to Ueno Park. Arrived from Haneda and landed straight to the museum since it's free and it only happens twice per year. The park itselfs is near the zoo and can see pack of queues prior opening. Happen to chance upon a bazzar serving local produce. Spend a couple of hundreds of Yen and certainly fill your stomach. The park is huge and we only spend a couple of hours since cherry blossom is over.

Huge!. We walked around this area hoping to kill some time before the zoo opened and boy are we glad we did. It's amazing! There is so much to see! If you get tired it is also a great place to sit and people watch.

Nice park, lots of museums. You'll be spoilt for choice for museums. We went to the museum of Western art - there was a very long line at the entrance, but most people were in line for the special exhibit, so after waiting for around 20 mins in line, it wasn't actually that crowded in the permanent exhibit. Check opening times ahead of time - I believe it was closed on Mondays when we visited.
A great day trip. The park was beautiful. Loved the walk through the park and visiting the zoo. There were entertainers performing. The local market next to the park and subway was also a must see.

An all day adventure. Ueno Park has so many things to see and do that its an all day affair. Between the various museums, interesting attractions and beautiful walks between breath taking trees, you'll have a ton of great memories.

Great Park for Museums. The park houses several museums.but what's interesting are those miniature temples (imitation of those kyoto temples and shrines).Highly recommended to go to visitor center office for free guided walking tour.After visiting park, nice to walk and shop along the wet market and bazaar (along the train station).

Wonderful Big City Park. Ueno Park is wonderful. There is a big lake with water lilies and lotuses, a boat pond with rental boats, some of the best museums in Tokyo, a zoo, shrines, and lots of open space. It's comparable to Central Park and the Museum Mile in New York City. Relax and enjoy.

Garden in Heaven. We have visited Japan many times but have always missed its best cherry blossum season. This time we use the Good Friday Holiday on 28 Mar to visit Tokyo hoping to catch the full bloom cherry blossum. Before departure we thought we might have miss the full bloom again as this year's season started earlier than its average. We reached Tokyo on 28 Mar night and stay at Mitsui Garden Ueno. Next morning we stroll to Ueno Park and was pleasantly surprise by the sight. Almost all the trees were in full bloom and there were falling petals which make the scenery even more enchanting. Better still the weather was a perfect 17 degree Centigrade, no sun and no rain. Its was not crowded and we can walk for hours around the whole park (including the beautiful man made lake) without getting tired.

It's huge with lots to see. This park houses everything from the zoo, to large ponds, multiple large museums (Nat'l, Western Art, Science museums, etc), and shrines. Upon entering, the noise of the city disappears!Just walking the park and not visiting any museums will take an hour or two. The park, and its attractions can be an all day affair. It is directly behind the Ueno train station.

Visit or pass through. My friend and I went there just to relax after a hard work. Still some sakura blossom in the park. Another day I went there again just to use it as a passage to Ueno station. Along the way there are so many things to see, the zoo, the temple, or street fair. My friend also said it is another popular dating spot lol.

Nice park if you are in the area.. Lovely park around Cherry Blossom time, Nice to walk around.. It's great it's near the zoo, and asakusa Temple, and all the musiums and cheap shops. I don't know why though, I prefer Yoyogi. Perhaps it's the homeless that are in the area, and the fact Ueno is kind of a cheap area in general. Still there is a lot to do in the area,

Interesting. My friend and I walked here because we were told there was good shopping at Ueno station. The park is nice, and clean. There are several museums and art galleries in the area along with a zoo. Great place for kids to run around, or to experience a little bit of outdoors and culture.

Wander round here on a sunny Sunday afternoon. There's always something to look at on a nice Sunday in Ueno Park. Teenage boys showing off on skateboards, teen girls showing the latest in fashion (er, yes, girls, very nice). Older ladies and gentlemen doing their exercises. Just DON'T visit the zoo

Nice city escape. This park is very big, with a lot of place, but it's crowded as well. We were there during the cherryblossom, so it was really amazing to see it there. There is a lake that have a nice view and bunch of small shops selling good smelling food.They have places for picnik, small places you can buy a food there and eat next to it on nice tables.There is Ueno zoo inside the park and it' sbasically made of 2 parks which are connected by a pathwalk between them.They have a big variety of animals and nice walking paths.

Delightful. A green lung with pleasant walks. Delightful in spring and cherry blossom. Has a couple of good restaurants situated inside the park. Not worth a special trip but if nearby (as in our case) a pleasant stroll to get away from the hectic pace of the city.
Nice walk. Nice place for a walk - but nothing was open around 9 AM. Relatively safe park, as big cities go. Strange to see a Starbucks in the middle.

The Best Place to Sightseeing. I visit the park in Summer, August 2011.The park is very big. i very recommended this place to visit. So many things you can capture from this place. So many things to do for free.There are many building around this Park that you can sightseeing, like museum ( Tokyo National Museum, the National Museum for Western Art, the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum and the National Science Museum), temple (Kaneiji Temple,Kiyomizu Kannon Temple, Toshogu Shrine, Bentendo) and Uneo zoo.Ueno Park is one of Tokyo's most popular and lively cherry blossom spots with more than 1000 cherry trees lining its central pathway. The cherry blossoms are usually in bloom during late March and early April and attract large numbers of hanami (cherry blossom viewing) parties.Unlucky me go there at summer :(
End of season for cherry blossoms but... A good place to go for a break from the city. Ameyoko is just nearby for food etc. buy something and have a nice picnic under the trees!

Lovely Park, but Just Missed Sakura. This is a lovely, spacious park and a great place for a picnic. Unfortunately, we just missed cherry blossom season; we were here the first week in April and the petals had mostly fallen off the trees due to warm temperatures and rain. The park still had plenty of beauty to see and there is a certain charm in watching the petals float to the ground. Nice place to relax and get away from the crush of people in Tokyo. On a side note, like most public places in Tokyo, there are public toilet facilities to use that are very clean.

Best site for sakura viewing.. It is one of the biggest and beautiful attractions to view Sakura during spring. There are different kinds of food cooked outside and view is simply amazing. Park is clean and peaceful.

The viewing area for Sakura blooming season. The park is one of the biggest in Tokyo and is the best viewing park for Sakura season. Throngs of locals and foreigner packs the park for a view or to spend the noon with friends and family members for picnic. Come here if you ae planning for a view of the Sakura, you won't want to leave

Good for leisure stroll. Very art-oriented place. Have some ice-cream from one of the carts along the way, they're pretty decent. The walk to and around Ueno-koen has some old architectural Japanese buildings that can't be found in the city, a very pleasant sight.The route to the station becomes more crowded. We were here during sakura season and it was a sight to behold, especially the fountain area.If not visiting any museums, allocate about 2 hours to properly walk and explore at a leisurely pace.

Great Experience. We were lucky enough to visit Ueno Park on 29 March 2013, when the cherry blossom was in full bloom. One of the best parks in the area, this park is great for walking and observing cherry blossoms, something Tokyo/Japan is famous for and can be very proud. More than 1000 cherry trees lining its central pathway. This is a wonderful location to hang out for the day with a picnic and just take in the beauty of the city. Ueno Park is also famous for the many museums found on its grounds, especially the Tokyo National Museum, the National Museum for Western Art, the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum and the National Science Museum. It is also home to Ueno Zoo, Japan's first zoological garden.If you visit Tokyo in late March, Ueno Park - definitely must see. Great experience ....Soooooooo beautifullllllllllll.

Pleasant Surprises. We were hoping to visit during cherry blossom season but since it came a few weeks earlier this year versus last year, they were unfortunately just past bloom. If you're planning a trip, I would aim for the date of first bloom the previous year, not full bloom (risk of being too late). Despite this, the park, shrines, statues and scenery were all amazing. We decided to try out the Zoo and were glad we did - it was world class. It had a full range of animals and was massive in scale, it took 3 hours to go through and even then we skipped a few areas. Zoo admission was pretty reasonable as well at 600Y/adult.

Fun at the zoo. I first thought Ueno had only a park. Of course, I was wrong. I had a park, a zoo, and several museums. And this is accessed thru their JR line. We arrived at Ueno mid-morning and rain was drizzling since the day before. Foreigners get a 20% discount to enter the zoo. What surprised me was that it had pandas, polar bears, tigers, monkeys, zebras, etc but no reptiles. They had a great bird collection.

Excellent. I'm a little bias as I was here during Sakura blooming season, perfect little park with access to all the museums and zoo. The way through the lake was good, also on the way to it and the temple there, there were many little food stalls selling nearly anything you'd like to try to eat.

Not only park but also place to see art. We were lucky enough to visit Ueno Park on 23 March 2013, when the cherry blossom (sakura) was in full bloom (mankai). Great opportunity not only to see the wonderful blossoms, but also to observe hanami, as groups of friends, colleagues and families gathered on tarpaulins under the trees to picnic and celebrate.We were there in the late afternoon, as the sun was setting and the red paper lanterns for night-viewing (yozakura) were beginning to illuminate - magical!Not surprisingly it was very crowded when we visited, but it was all the more exciting to be part of this informal festival. At one point, a temple procession made its way through the crowd, drums beating, contributing to the amazing atmosphere of celebration. We definitely look forward to returning, maybe next visiting at a different time of year to discover the park's many other attractions.
Wow!. Ueno Park in peak Sakura (Cherry Tree) time. This and the Kannon Shrine are a must see! Park was full a tourists and there were many food vendors to choose from. Great experience!

Great park and museums. Our family of four (kids 14 and 8) had a lovely day in early March. Ueno Park provided a big, efficient and varied dose of culture for our two day visit to Tokyo. We enjoyed the people watching and managed to visit three sites in just a few hours. We went to the zoo, where we enjoyed a nice long observation of the pandas despite the attendants trying to move us along, to the art museum, where the second floor galleries provided an excellent survey of Japanese art and artifacts, and to the "old house" museum, which was friendly, small and educational. We had a tour of the old house by one of the museum staff and then enjoyed the toy and city history exhibit upstairs. We then went to the nearby bazaar streets and the lovely education shrine for the plum blossom festival.

Great place to see the cherry blossoms. If you're lucky enough to visit Tokyo whilst the cherries are in blossom you MUST visit Ueno park.The cherry blossoms are very beautiful and seem to have a spiritual effect on the Japanese. During the week office workers are selected to reserve a tree, you will see them sitting there on a tarpaulin with food and beer waiting for their colleagues who come along after work to watch the blossom, eat and make merry. It is an interesting cultural experience.The weekend changes the dynamic slightly in that friends go and sit under trees on tarpaulins with food and drinks.We say again if you're in Tokyo in cherry blossom season go to Ueno.

Excellent hanami spot!. If you are in Tokyo during the cherry blossom season then Ueno park is not to miss!! This park is one of the best place to see the beautiful cherry blossoms but make sure it is in full bloom to really get the glory. There are also a lot of traditional food stalls open during this season. It's a lot of fun and extremely beautiful. Check out the sakura at day and night as they give a different feel and you get to see or join the japanese have a nice picnic under the trees :)

Great Park for Sakura. We really enjoyed our afternoon stroll and picnic under the Sakura in the Ueno Park. They have a straight path full with Sakura. Such a lovely sight. Should not be missed during Cherry Blossoms. For those planning to have picnic in the park just make sure to come to the park early morning say around 930-10am to be able to reserve a place under the cherry trees. Just make sure you bring your own mat or tatami then just write your name, date and time of reservation on the mat. Reserving a space for picnic is For FREE! We really enjoyed our picnic. And when the wind blows, the white petals on the trees fall and it feels like its snowing. Wow! Definitely nice to come back to Japan again for cherry blossoms. Check also the Ueno Zoo inside the Ueno Park.

Great place to see Cherry Blossoms. One of my favourite parks in Tokyo & a fantastic place to see the cherry blossoms. The park is large but can easily be walked around in a couple of hours, or longer if you stop to go in the zoo or museums. There is a small Shinto shrine to be found through a series of red torii gates down some stone steps, as well as a Buddhist pagoda on top of a small mound, which are both interesting to go look at.
Great for Hanami. Had gone there during Mankai (full bloom) and it was beautiful. Some great snaps!Very crowded, but all Hanami's are. A must visit for Cherry blossom viewing

great place to view cherry blossoms. I went on a sunny day during cherry blossoms, and seeing the blossoms was just as interesting as watching the parties enjoying their time together for their picnics.

The Cherry Blossoms were spectacular. But the park would be great to visit any time. There are delicious food carts along some of the paths, a pond where one can take out a rowboat, a large shinto shrine, and a fascinating temple the focus of which is fertility. We had a wonderful day here-- both my 13-year old son and my 70-year old mother really enjoyed it.

Cherry Blossom in full bloom. visit this place from Last week of March to the first 2 wks of April, then you might catch it at full bloom, and when you do, definitely, its one for the portrait. its what every garden should have to make it ZEN/serenely beautiful. warning though, every japanese knows when it blooms, so expect a lot of people! still its a very beautiful place to be with your loved one. by the way this park is free, no entrance fee.

Go during cherry blossom season. Definitely worth seeing during Sakura season. Otherwise it's just a regular park. Right next to the Ueno station, which makes it convenient - I was able to take a quick jaunt through the park and see the cherry blossoms while waiting for my train, and it was really beautiful.

Cherry tree heaven. We have both seen Ueno Park with the lights at night and during the day and both is simply magnificent, we were so lucky that the trees were in full bloom. If was fun to see the locals having picnics under the trees and it was amazing to see how many garbage disposal were filled at night and the all cleaned the next morning - very impressive how clean the park is with all those people having picnics and taking pictures.It is the most beautiful hanami spot we have seen so far.

Timing is everything. Visited Tokyo and happened to be there on exactly the correct time. Had a long stroll around the pathways at night on friday 22nd March. The cherries were almost in full bloom, according to locals the high point would have been the next day. All along the pathways there were people sitting on picnic, and the trees were just amazing. We were there around 8-10 PM, there were food stalls down by the lakes, and generally a very nice atmosphere. Quite crowded, there were thousands of people having a picnic, or just strolling around.

Ueno Park is spectacular during Sakura season. Spent a day in Ueno Park admiring the cherry blossoms 19th March. I understand that only 50% of the blossoms have flowered, but it was still amazing. Can only imagine that it must be incredible when all the blossoms are in full bloom.

Ueno park and zoo. this was where the cherry blossom row of trees are budding in the spring, so we missed that as we went in february. but the zoo is great, and you get 100 yen off for showing your passport when you get your ticket.

The cherry blossoms were amazing. We didn't go into any of the museums or the zoo but my older kids loved this place. They enjoyed walking around and just people watching. In the middle of the park some kids were doing a LARP of Dragonball Z that was so funny and really well done. The main walkway is lined with cherry trees that were just starting to bloom- it was beautiful. It's a tranquil spot to just rest and enjoy some peace after the general hubbub of Tokyo.

This Park has something for everyone!. Ueno Park is a must see attraction in Tokyo and offers something for all ages and interests. I have now been 3 times to Ueno and each visit has had a different focus. Ueno is very large in scale and within Ueno's grounds are numerous museums and shrines. The Park houses the Tokyo National Museum (which comprises several large buildings of stunning and varying architecture), The National Museum of Western Art, The National Science Museum (which cant be missed because it has a sculpture of a blue whale out the front) and the small and intimate Shimtamachi History Museum down by the lake. For those less interested in museums and art galleries, there is also a Zoo, the Toshogu Shrine and a lake where in the middle of the lake is Benten-do Temple. In winter this lake is full of water lillies. In spring and summer there are paddle boats shaped like giant swans that are available to paddle around the lake, as well as rowboats.The lake and Benten-do temple are set down from the rest of the park and you access it by going down stairs adjacent to the Shrine. Make sure you do a full circuit of the park and find the very small Shrine that that is circular which a dome on top and spire. Next to it is the large scale face of a buddha- it is all that remains of a giant buddha statue followed the great earthquake in 1923. On the weekends you can also encounter buskers entertaining the crowds as well as rockabillies dancing in the large square near Starbucks cafe. And whilst I have yet to experience cherry blossom viewing at Ueno, I understand it is one of THE most popular spots to view cherry blossoms and is crowded by picnickers during this time.The Park is easily accessible from Ueno station. There are some restaurants and cafes within the Park. Outside the park there are many cafes and restaurants within easy walking distance. The park is also very close to Ameyoko Aracade so I would suggest a day trip to visit both attractions.

So much to see, so much to do.. I went to Ueno Park in late November so I was there for the end of autumn so I wasn't going to see amazing cherry blossoms but there were still some very nice red and yellow ones. The main reason I went was to see the zoo and museums whilst walking around an amazing park. There's so much to see my camera's battery died and I had to use my phone to take photos, luckily it has a decent camera. It is also extremely easy to find as it's only a 2 minute walk from Ueno station (if you get out of the right exit).Like most Japanese parks, there's wonderful nature and temples to see so if you just want to walk around, this park has you covered. There were swan shaped boats you could hire to ride around the water but as I was alone, I didn't think it'd work out well. I wondered about on my planned route to the main museum I wanted to see. I was extremely lucky that there was a chocolate exhibition on so I paid for a bundle ticket which gave me more than I realised, not only access to the chocolate exhibition, but also to the 3 other natural history and science exhibitions that were all connected. They were all fun as I am a bit of a animal/science museum lover so my views may be skewed. I did feel a little weird being a lone 21 year old with school kids running around but the chocolate exhibition was full of fellow adult chocolate lovers. After the museum, I went to starbucks to get a hot chocolate and continued to the main reason I had come to Ueno Park, Ueno Zoo. It was like most zoos but had animals I had never seen in real life due to living in Australia. I looked like a nice zoo, the animals seemed to be taken care of and all the animals were there to be seen. The highlights were seeing an elephant pee like a fire hydrant and the hippo's famous helicopter pooing, I am a child at heart. The food in the zoo is like any normal attraction in Japan, mutli-cultural but can taste the bulk cooking but still very nice. When I bought my ticket to the zoo, I didn't realise that some areas gave you discounts if you show your passports, the lady was nice enough to give me a book for tourists where you get discounts for showing your passport (I got away with showing a photo copy of mine). I give it 5 stars because I loved the things I came to see and I know there are plenty of other places to go to that others would love. I can imagine it being beautiful in spring and probably 10x better.

UENO PARK FOR SAKURA WATCHING. UENO PARK is one of the first places where the sakura, the famous japanese cherry blossom, begins in tokyo. It also contains the japanese museum of art, where you can find a vast collection of old japanese art. The part is 2 minutes walk from ueno station, or even less than a minute if walking fast Not so far from it can find the old temple of asakusa, and akihabara, a shopping area for elecrtonics.

see the cherry blossoms. Take a walk through Ueno park in the spring during the cherry blossom season. There are many restaurants in the area and cafes inside the park, on the side of Tokyo National Museum. Around the park there are several museums and Ueno Zoo.

Feed the birds. I stayed here whilst i was waiting to check in to the hotel. A homeless man just came up to me and sad down near me and I was a little nervous. Then he spoke and proved to be a wonderful and knowledgable man. i mention him because there are MANY homeless people here, you can't avoif them. This guy knew english quite well (i think he had been a teacher) and had been alive for World War 2. He had the most unflinching and accurate views on the all the places I plan to see (told me where I could find good shopping), all the locals and the attitudes of the government plus gave a great history lesson. He was amazing. The park has fish you can feed and a great place to relax.

Nice park with a nice zoo too!. Nice place to relax and stroll. It was good especially during winter or cold period as the place is big and you might be walking in open air so it will be very hot during summer time.

Sundays. Here families gather on Sundays. It is a lovely park and you have stalls serving all sorts of food and drink. There can also be music, dancing and other entertainment. Great fun to just walk round and free of charge.

construction for 2020. there is construction going on right now for the bid for the olympics 2020 which made walking really difficult because the park is still just as crowded as normal. there is plenty of museums there, the zoo is there, and there are plenty of monuments there as well, so its still nice.
LOVE IT!. You must visit this place to admire the Cherry Blossom Trees, the view is wonderfull no doubt is the best of the park

Nice walk. Went on a hot day so that was nice. It's fun to walk around, but there was a lot of construction when we went so in that area it smelled kind of bad. But away from the construction, it was nice to get a breath of fresh air
Nice place for a walk. This was a great park to walk around and clear your head before hitting the streets again. The even have small stalls at certain times where you can buy odd bits

Magic walk.... It was a sunny day, we just loved walking in the park, seeing some temples and shrines while walking... till we reached first the National Museum and then the Yanaka Cemetery...such an evocking magic place!!!

quiet park, beautiful scenery. I was lucky enough to be in the area March and April 2012, when the cherry blossoms were blooming. There may be not much grass, but the park is big enough to be walking around and exploring the area for at least a few hours (if you go to the museums, zoo, and other sights). There are food and souvenir stands around the park, with many closer to the zoo. And it's right across from the Ueno station, you can't miss it!
Loved this park!. I loved that this large park has so much to offer, and I got to do some one stop shopping- Zoo, Museum, lovely & large park and easy train station!

A pretty stroll in the park. I decided to walk through Ueno Park en route to find some lunch after a friend told me that it is very pretty. Did not visit any of the museums, temples or the zoo within the park but it was a very pleasant stroll on a sunny winter's day. It was pleasant enough and I enjoyed simply walking through the park and snapping photos of it. It is well-laid out and there's lots to see there - a couple of museums, the Ueno zoo and some temples, so it's worth a visit if you're in Tokyo and a welcome respite from the maddening crowds of Harajuku and Shibuya.
Beautiful Area. Lots to see and do, be sure to take a camera as there is lots of monuments and stuff to see in the park. As well the zoo is there and the kids play area and the museums.

Huge Park. Even if you're just strolling through it on the way to the museum or other sites, Ueno Park is worth a look. On our first day, we didn't realize just how big it was until we walked down it's opposite side the next day and made a cut through. It's grounds are very nice and clean.One word of warning, though; at night the homeless people tend to congregate around it's edges. Stay to the main paths and you'll be fine.
beautiful park. this is a great park for relaxing and visiting the many museums within. don't miss the paddle boat swans on the lake.
Nice Park. At first the park looked nice but after walking around it, I found it needed some upkeep and improvement. The paddleboats were old and not really attractive.. Will not vistt there again.

not my idea of a park but.... Ueno park has more concrete than grass though it still qualifies as a lovely walk. In our case we walked across the park to get to the National museum from our hotel which I guess is nicer than walking alongside traffic. We didn't really have time or interest in the zoo and the park 'highlights'. After watching a few japanese films and Oshin where Ueno park seems to be the meeting place, we were just ecstatic to be there.

A park not to be missed. I cannot imagine how many things one can see, do and visit in this park... It was simply beautiful in the winter morning. The buskers were delightfully entertaining and the zoo, it was a brilliant gem in the middle of busy Tokyo. I will sure visit the place again.

Big pathways, with trees but no grass. It's not really a park. There are few if no areas of grass that you can run around on or relax on. It's fairly wide pavements with trees either side. Locals sit on this hard pavement during the cherry blossom viewing season - for me it is crazy to try and sit in such a place. There's a nice pagoda in the middle of the lotus leaf lake. There is also a nice temple there. There are a lot of homeless in the park. Ideally, they should move them on to somewhere else as they spoil an already mediocre "park" even further.

Great musuem choices in Tokyo. Consider spending an afternoon in Tokyo at one of the splendid museums at the Ueno Museum Park. It's kinda like a little Smithsonian area, there are 8 different museums to choose from, all situated in a green park that's perfect for picnicking. If you're not really a museum person, but you don't mind learning a little bit, consider the fine Tokyo National Museum. In the Honkan building, on the 2nd floor, there is a "Highlights of Japanese Art" circuit you can do in about an hour. It's the Reader's Digest version of Japanese art, with one room dedicated to each genre (silk screens, pottery, armor, calligraphy, etc). Each room has a small but exquisite selection, just enough to see and enjoy without getting museum overload.

A place to relax in a busy city. Ueno Park has a lot to offer. An excellent performance facility (Bunka Kaikan), a zoo, gardens and museums. We recently played a baseball game there against our colleagues of the Tokyo Philharmonic. The ballpark was nicely maintained and nicely laid out. They do love baseball there as when we started playing, all the gardeners who working on keeping the park shipshape, downed their tools to sit and watch us. BTW, we won - 23 to 3!
big park. it have few museum inside,restaurant and beautiful garden.a performing art by street artist.very relax atmosphere

Trip to wonders. There is so much in this park and it is beautiful. I think everyone who goes to Tokyo needs to take a trip here and enjoy the sights. I saw some 1950s style dancers and they were having a blast. I love watching people and this was a great place to do so.

Pandas, Polar Bears and more!. I went to Ueno zoo just to see the pandas but got much more. The animals are well cared for and the habitats are beautifully done. The landscape of the zoo is beautiful and give you great 360degree views of the animals. As the zoo is part of the huge Ueno park which houses the museums you get to visit many attractions at once. Ueno park entry is free but the zoo has a cheap entry fee and if you show your passport you get a discount. The food at the zoo is good and the park has a large Starbucks. There are some great souvinere shops where the proceeds go to maintaining the zoo and the animals so make sure you buy something :) Great attraction for animal lovers of all ages.

A Day Well Spent. We started our day at Nippori Station and working our way through the Yanaka district of old Tokyo. This area is filled with many temples and contains the large and interesting Yanaka cemetery. Eventually we came to the Ueno park where we entered the zoo and spent a couple of hours viewing the panda bear exhibit and some of the excellent displays of larger mammals. Then we walked through the rest of the park stopping at a few shrines and temples. It was 4:30 PM by the time we left the park. A day well spent.

Perfect. Perfect place to chill out, date... the park is peaceful / tranquil. I enjoy it in sakura season, the park is full of street food and ppl having nice time with their friends/families Perfect for pictures!.

Refreshing, colorful and spacious, a great place to relax and get over the crowdedness of Tokyo. Besides being the best place to view Sakura in spring, Ueno park is still a great place to get over the crowdedness of Tokyo. The various shrines in the park are still wonderful to visit. One can easily spend a relaxing half day in that park.
wonderful. A green oasis in this busy city with wonderful musuems, lanes, shrines, pagoda and even a zoo. definately in my Tokyo top 5 must see places.

Worth a visit on the weekend. It was a lovely day when we went, so it was nice just to wander around and people watch. I didn't go into any of the museums, but would be a must visit for anyone who is into museums. Make sure you go for a wander along Shinobazu Pond to see all the water plants.

Great park. With an amazing amount of greeery in Tokyo this was a great thing. There is a large pond with lillies and several other things around the park to do. We went during the off season I guess but this place was beautiful and clean.

Missed the cherry blossoms. Go here when the cherry blossoms are in bloom because its paves the park roads. Temples and gardens and a lake are found here. Many Japanese have family walks and dates here. Bring your best walking shoes. You can eat at hawker stalls or in nearby cafes. Don't forget your sunblock.

Excellent way to spend your day. We spent several hours wandering around this very large park, stopping at a number of shrines and eventually visiting the Tokyo National Museum. This is a lovely space to spend a morning and then dive into any number of cultural and scientific exhibitions at the many museums accessed from this park.
Good walk or jog near the hotel. Fed the fish and turtles in the lake. Kids played in the playground and we enjoyed the walk. Temple in the middle of the lake worth a visit.

Great Park. We strolled through here early in the morning (7am). Wasn't very busy. Very nice park dotted with shrines and temples. Seemed to be frequented by mostly locals. There is also a museum and zoo on the grounds.
No costs and is a nice 1-2hr walk.

I am not an art buff but it's nice. A good break from the constant period art that you see everywhere. They do have some valuable prints but it is all the same to me. I am not an art historian so all i can say is I liked it but that is that.

Nice city park. Nice gardens, some temples and water features in the middle of a very built up city. You get a glimpse of the locals who hang out - i.e. offering to draw your portrait or sell different wares.
A nice to walk around especially if you're in the area.
Lovely. Beautiful gardens, usually street performers as well. Nice paths to walk and stroll. Food available as well

A great city park. Ueno Park is very nice to stroll around in. Watch some people playing baseball, visit the museums, go to the zoo or sit by the fountains. We visited just as the refurbishments on the fountains were complete, very nice and a pleasant place to soak up afternoon sun.

Best When Cherry Blossoms Are In Bloom. This urban park is popular with the locals, and is a great spot to unwind in the city. The park houses several museums. If you are in Tokyo when the cherry blossoms are in bloom, you are in for a treat.

great place to see lots of things. Ueno Park is Tokyo's oldest public park here you can visit a Zoo, Temples. Museums, Galleries.Its a good place to see lots of attractions. I visited the Zoo where you can see Pandas, Tiger, Giraffes, Elephants, Hippos the list is long. The Temples are well worth a visit you start by wandering through the Temples Street market where you can pick up your Souvenirs, you can enter one of the temples and make a wish. The outside grounds are filled with shrines and lovely scenery, carp fish swimming under a picturesque bridge. We visited the Tokyo National Museum some of the buildings were closed we got to see the Gallery of Treasures, Japanese Art, Japanese Archaeology. Its well worth a visit.

Beautiful park. We Spent a number of hours here one Saturday afternoon, along with thousands of other Japanese people. Despite it being quite busy, it seemed to be a local hang out, rather than a tourist spot, which gave it a lovely family atmosphere. There are some lovely fountains and temples along the way (we particularly liked the Toshogu shrine), and there were numerous signs in English, which wasn't expected but very welcome!If you are heading to any of the museums you could easily spend a day in this whole area. It's a lovely place to just wonder around.
Nice park. Lovely place for people watching with a picnic...lots of museums and sites to visit inside the park also.

A glimpse of the Japanese true life. If you want to taste the unique, chaotic and schizophrenic atmosphere of Tokyo in one only place, please go to Ueno. Exit at the underground station of the Ginza line; look over your head and listen to the continuous clanking of the Japan Railways Yamanote Line; let yourself go following the flow of that sea of people, leave the road, just a few steps and you’ll enter Ueno-Koen (Ueno hill) a park that is at its best during the Hanami, the cherry blossom period (1st decade of April). No cars nor trains noise, now you are in the kingdom of the nature and you walk without a specific destination, phagocytized by a joyous crowd. The main path of the park is a true tunnel created by the cherries and their branches full of flowers, seem to brave the force of gravity. Here meets every kind of people, or the entire staff of a firm or office as well, from the chief to the last employee, all dressed with the same, black pinstripe suit, for a picnic, or a dinner, certainly for one beer, seating on the typical large green plastic sheets, rented by enterprising youth. For Sakura, Ueno in Tokyo is the counterpart of the Maruyama-koen in Kyoto, the latter at its best one week later than in Tokyo, just because of the small differences of their climates.

Wonderful place~. July, 2011. Great for an afternoon's walk, so close to the bustle of the city and yet so far removed! Greenery, statuary, superb sanctuary. It was a perfect place to relax for a few hours!

Check the dates you visit. I visted the park in Dec 2012 expecting to check out the museums, zoo and the boating pond as well as the temples.Sadly the museums and zoo were shut due to it being new year and the boating pond overgrown with weeds.The temples are very nice but you can see many better examples around Tokyo. The park contains a small theme park carnival with loads of childrens rides which many people seemed to enjoy (not sure if this is open all year or not)

Beautiful Cherry Blossoms. Prepare for the crowds. Unbelievable how many people were out on the weekend. Thousands. But still worth while just for that alone. If you don't like crowds go during the week.The food and cherry blossoms were wonderful.

Hanami. Beautiful park, but even more amazing during hanami. (Cherry viewing festival) In April 2010 I went with friends to Ueno Park and experience hanami for myself. I'd never done it and it was the most amazing event. If you come during cherry blossom season, I'd highly recommend coming here to experience it. It's extremely busy but orderly. I can't even think of an instance where anyone around us was a bother to anyone else. Everyone stayed in their marked area, and we even had some Japanese folks who spoke a bit of English drop by and say hi and hit on one of the people I was with, haha! He had a guitar with him and even played some songs for us. The people there are amazing and really in the spirit. Though I'm betting the alcohol helps, it's just an experience one must go through to understand.You're also bound to see some crazy things. On our hanami trip there, we saw someone dressed up as Pikachu appear once or twice. The park itself, with all the cherry blossoms, some even falling on you, is beautiful. I love hanami in Japan. It's my favorite part of spring. Pink snow in the spring.(Date of visit was April 2010.)

Wonderful. This place is absolutely amazing. The park is beautiful with it's shrines, museums, nature and of course the huge pond that is full of waterlilies. Great place to go to! Very peaceful, especially after having seen the busy, crowded and commercial neighborhoods in Tokyo.

Two Very Different Experiences. We traveled to Japan in April 2012 hoping to catch the cherry blossoms in full bloom. Since they were early in Washington DC, we thought we might have missed them, but Japan had an unseasonably cold winter, so the cherry blossoms were actually late. We planned to spend the first two days and the last two days of our trip in Tokyo and boy are we glad we did that. On our very first day, we went to Ueno Park, but none of the trees were in bloom. Not only that, but the entire park was empty. It was like a ghost town, but a very clean one. We still enjoyed walking around and seeing the shrines and temples. 10 days later when we came back to Tokyo, it was completely different. The cherry trees were suddenly in full bloom and Ueno was packed. Unlike the DC Cherry Blossom festival, Ueno Park was very orderly. The crowds kept moving and if you wanted to stop for a picnic, there were roped off sections for that. If you are able to catch the blossoms, I also recommend going back to Ueno at night. In April, it gets dark in Japan around 7pm, so you can be out in the dark before it gets too late. The lit lanterns among the cherry trees was one of the most beautiful sites we saw on the whole trip!
Peace in Taito. A tranquil area of ueno where many locals go to simply chill from the madness around.Nice walks with a couple of temples/shrines and a zoo if that takes your fancy.

Go swan cruising on the lake. We were travelling with small kids so some days didn't want to stray far from the hotel & this park was perfect! Tree lined paths, cool shady spots, temple with amazing food stalls on the weekend, the cutest zoo with such a huge range of animals and the highlight of my whole family - the swan paddle boats on the lake. We went out on them 3 out of the 5 days we had in Tokyo. So much fun!
A nice oasis. Cherry trees all around. Shrines and sculptures. Just by Ueno station. Nice park for strolling and enjoying cherry blossoms. The zoo is very nice and worth a visit.

Some good & some poor. We visited the Tokyo National museum and a peaceful, smaller Inari shrine (Gojo Tenjin?) with red Torii and fox statues. There are also larger, busier shrines in the area. I particularly like the whale statue and locomotive outside the Science Museum. Some homeless in the park, but maybe not as many as you would get in the US.
The Ueno Park. Ueno park is a great place to go for a walk. It is full of Shrines, Temples and Museums and it also has a zoo

Hanami viewing. From Ueno Station, it is a short walk to Ueno Park across the road. It was April when my wife and I visited the park for hanami. Cherry blossoms were in full bloom then.Crowds of tourists and locals thronged the park. Many locals were enjoying their cherry blossom parties as they sat on blue coloured ground sheets laid beneath the trees. They chatted. Played board games. Some ate from simple lunch boxes while others came prepared with pots and dishes of hot meals. Some laid down as cherry blossom petals floated down with each breeze. They were all involved in their own merrymaking. There was an air of festivity.We walked to Shinobazu Pond and the walkways around the pond were equally crowded. Only the migratory birds on the marshland in the middle of the pond had all the space to themselves.Hanami at Ueno Park was an opportunity to share in the lifestyle of locals. We learnt later that the tsunami and ensuing tragedies last year took away the joy of hanami for the country. For us to visit Japan and see the resilience of locals and their joy of hanami celebrations was a bitter-sweet experience.
Strolling with the Family. Enjoyed walking in the park because there were so many thing to do there. Museums were located there as well as the Zoo.
Alot to do here. Has many museums and the zoo...Disliked nothing..there is so much to see..cant do it all in one day..!

good place to relax and walk... just nearby my hotel. very near to the Ueno Station. Here you can see the Ken Watanabe sculpture, some other sculptures, old tombs, houses, etc. my guess is the best time to visit is during spring (sakura time)the scenery must be very beautiful and interesting..

Nice art gallery and ok zoo. A lovely park and lots to do.I only rate the zoo as ok as it's great, by japanese standards, and bad by my standards but I do live in Perth Australia and our zoo works really hard at recreating habitats and caring for the mental as well as physical health of the animals.A fun day out.

A beautiful park for viewing Cherry Blossoms. We were fortunate enough to visit Tokyo right on time for viewing Cherry Blossoms in April. Ueno Park was packed with thousands set up having hanami parties under the trees. The facilities are good with lavatories throughout, a shrine, zoo and museum. You can easily spend an entire day at this park and not be bored as there is something for everyone. The food from the hawker street is fantastic although I am not sure if this is a fixed attraction or pop up for the hanami season.

An oasis in a huge city.. I have been here summer and winter and it is always great. You can spend half a day here if you are in a leisurely mood, just strolling, getting an ice-cream and watching the Japanese enjoy themselves in their very restrained way. There are a lot of temples, so you can really get the sense of being in Japan without having to go too far.

Relaxing place. We walked to Ueno park from Ueno Mitsui garden hotel. It is very near and the weather made it pleasant to walk. Since it was during weekends, there were several performers which was very entertaining. Lots of families there with dogs to chill out. Ueno park during the cherry blossom is excellent but can be very crowded. Starbucks at Ueno park has been opened and the concept was nice and spacious. However it is always crowded that we didn't manage to have a cuppa there. If you walk further, it is connected to the art museum section. Worth a visit.

Wonderful sightseeing and touring .. We visited the Ueno Park on a Friday at the peak of the blossom period and we cannot imagine how crowdy it would have been on a Saturday . The locals and other Japanese tourists really enjoy this quiet area in the middle of noisy Tokyo . The park is simply beautiful . It is a mix of temples , shrines , museums , monuments ., statues , academic facilities ,stores and recreational facilities to fulfill every interest .  We were lucky to find that a free volunteer Guided Tour in English was available under the sponsorship of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government . The guide was excellent and the tour lasted around 2 hours . The tour starts at 10:30 a.m. or 1;30 p.m on Wednesday , Friday and Sunday and it can be joined in the hall of the Green salon of Ueno Park . The guide told us that there was a similar tour of Asakusa during the week-ends .

Ueno Park after Cherry blossoms. Ueno Park is an oasis in the midst of a bustling city. Located just outside the subway station, the park is a restful place to commune with nature. Trees, plants and shrubs well landscaped surrounding, one can breathe and have the space to just be silent. An attraction of course is the zoo where you can see amazing creatures and animals.......from huge, monstrous big black bears to Harry Potter's white owl.........from slithereens to birds, from tigers to huggable pandas. Sad that the cherry blossoms have all fallen out and only the green leaves are visible or the brown empty branches of the tree. Nonetheless, there are still other enjoyable things.........the walk........the greenery......the animals. One will also see the teenagers drinking soda and sharing knick knack foods in groups huddled under a tree in a picnic mat. Such is life!!
Sakura. Simply a an outstandingly beautiful experience to see the Sakura in full bloom-a memory to treasure for always!

Nice and relaxing. This is a great park to get out of the busy rithm of Tokyo, there are shrines and temples inside and a rose garden thats worth a visit. If you want to meet the pandas you can also go to the Zoo.
Great for hanami. We were here in april, at the peak of cherry blossom. Very nice here. Lots of people too but that expected. I think ueno park is the best place for hanami in tokyo.

Blossoms. We went in April right in the peek of the cherry blossoms season and the atmosphere in the park was awesome, people having picnics and a good time. Plenty of street food and drink to be consumed as well.

Nice cherry blossom viewing park. I went there in April for sakura viewing:Pro- close to JR station and easy to find- very pretty sakura- food stalls with yummy choicesCon- nothing special if you are not coming for sakura season, no other attractions- extremely croweded during sakura season- small

Amazing during Cherry Blossoms!. We visited in mid April just after the peak of Cherry blossoms. It was lovely to see so many friends and family gathering to celebrate. We ventured toward the Temple in the park but it is under construction right now. The zoo also looked great, but we ran out of time to go there as we were headed to the airport that day. The zoo has pandas and is cheap to enter (600 yen, I think).There was also a small market nearby with a random assortment of food, socks, etc. We were there on a Sunday and there was a street performer with a monkey who had the monkey playing along with her skit and jumping between two sets of stairs. I think the skit was a comedy, but we don't know Japanese.

A good example of a Japanese park. Great in April (when we went) as you can see the cherry blossoms being enjoyed by the locals and very close to the Zoo and museums.It also has a quaint, older theme park with rides for the under 10s.

An oasis in the urban desert. I enjoyed the walk in the park around the cherry blossom tree lined paths which are visually stunning,this is a very popular event in April judging by the huge numbers of people doing this, picnicing and partying under the trees. The park lake is also very pleasant to walk around and is well stocked with koi carp regularly coming to the surface and a magnet for wildfowl and other birds. There are also plenty of people sitting painting and doing other art work. Boating is available and the boats are shaped like ducks. Nothing at all to dislike in this park.
Beautiful Sakura Blossoms. It's a nice park inside the cities. Good for jogging and walking. Good for people who wants to experience cool shades of sakura trees. You can find the museums nearby.

Just like in the Ads. When you see the advertisement for Japan you see cherry blossom, you see a street lined with cherry blossom trees and when the flower is in full bloom and the wind blows you experience a shower of cherry blossom petals. This is such a magnificent sight and one place to experience this is at Ueno Park.

Beautiful During Hanami. There is reputed to be over 1000 cherry trees in this park and you can see it all in its glory during Hanami - it's also a very popular place for locals to celebrate with a picnic (or a few beers) under the cherry blossoms.

MUST VISIT in Spring. One of the famous location for Cherry Blossoms viewing in Japan. Must visit early Spring. I went mid-April and the Cherry Blossoms.... well most of them had gone, but even with little Cherry Blossoms around, it's still beautiful. Can't imagine it in the perfect Blossom season. Must be beyond beautiful!

Hanami or just another reason to get drunk?. Ueno Park is often referred as the most popular hanami place for Sakura, but what i saw was people more than flowers. Anyhow, the sakura was amazing, stretching along both sides of the walking path, just that i wish it was monkai (full bloom), due to the drastic weather change, the flowers were only 50~60% bloomed at first week of April. While under the beautiful sakura trees, there were these people who came with the name for hanami, but were already drunk early in the afternoon. And there were also those pitiful freshmen, who were normally the greenhorns from their companies, were appointed to sit and guard the ground by themselves the whole day, just to wait until their bosses and colleagues to join in after they finished work at the evening.Anyway, it's a good season to celebrate, so go get yourself a beer and join the crowd!!
Great spot for viewing Sakura full blossom.. Although the park was too crowded but it's a great spot to view Sakura full blossom.

Beautiful Cherry Blossoms in Bloom. We were very lucky to be in Tokyo when the Cherry Blossoms were 60-70% bloomed. . . . SO Beautiful. We took the metro system to Ueno station and then a short walk to the park. The pond was lined with blooming cherry blossom trees and also food vendors. It was an easy relaxing walk around the waterfront and we stopped many times for photo opportunities
Awesome way to spend the morning!. The petting zoo was my favorite! And the curry set in the zoo restaurant was delicious, too! :)

Cherry Blossoms at Ueno Park. Got a chance to see the beauty of the Sakura Festival where the whole promenade was lined by cherry blossoms and families and friends picnic under their shade. A definite must do when you visit Japan in springtime!
Ueno Park. It's a very nice place, where you can visit different points of interest - Zoo, national museum and etc.

Very nice but not the best Sakura viewing. We were travelling to during the Sakura cherry blossoms and were told Ueno park had the best sakura viewing and that we must stop by. It is a park with lovely walkways lined with Sakura trees but out of the many places we visited Ueno park was simply okay, viewing was better at Chidorigafuchi and the walkway into Hachimangu. We did not see the zoo. the park was very close to the train station so was convenient. Right outside of the station there is a big crossing with dozens of small Japanese stores and restaurants, great food! We visited a small ramen restaurant on a side street and was one of the best ramen's I've ever had!

very big park with lots of museums, a zoo and a couple of shrines. it's so big and so many options dat it's impossible to complete all in one day (quote one of the tourist sayin he got lost in the park lol).. there's around 4 museums, 1 zoo, 1 pond for boat rowing, a Benten Shrine, a Toshogu Temple (under renovation) and the Kannon Temple. Food stalls cluster along the path to the Benten and behind the Benten is Shinobazu Pond where i enjoyed the hanafubuki... it's also near to Ameyoko for a quick shopping & sight seeing
Beautiful but very crowded during cherry blossom season. Visited in Apr 2011 - worth the experience, if only once.
Go for picnic at Sakura. It was a lovely place to have a picnic under the cherry blossoms. The toilets are not great.

a good park for cherry blossoms. We were there around 5pm for the cherry blossom festival week and the lanterns were lit, I was shocked of how generally quite Japanese, were rushing to get a spot under the trees for a picnic with alcohol and LOTS of people it was noisy that evening, but got to see men in suits and young girls dressed for work and older men all on picnic mats lots of food. we observed what an important festival it is for them ,welcoming the spring!so choose when you go .the trees were definitely very beautiful, the lanterns simply paper lanterns lining the trees

Fantastic when the cherry blossoms are blooming - but probably not worth the trip at other times. I was lucky enough to visit when the cherry blossoms were blooming - they were incredible, stretching as far as the eye can see! - and Tokyoites were picnicking under them, unusually relaxed.The park is cut in half by a road lined with fairly tall buildings, do see both halves - one is full of cherry blossom trees and contains several museums, the other contains a lake with a temple in the middle.Note that this area is a long way from Shinjuku/Harajuku/Shibuya (the metro iPhone app says 30mins, but it doesn't take into account how long you will inevitably - Tokyo being Tokyo - spend lost!).

Quiet Park. Ueno Park was just down from where we were staying, its a nice place to just go and sit and look out over the lake....you can take a row boat out on the lake if you want, and there are plenty of food stalls if ur hungry..
Cherry Blossoms in Spring!. A "must see" in April.. the cherry blossoms are beautiful, both during the day and night. Lots of people have picnics here under the cherry blossom trees.

Good for an afternoon. We were there in the cherry blossom bloom so it was just serene to walk around under the pink and white canopy. We visited all the statues and it kept the kids entertained for the afternoon,didnt get time for the museum but will catch it next time.

A Slice of Tokyo Family Life. The Park on a Sunday give you a good look at family life for people in Tokyo. It is quite interesting in its own right, but nothing special per se. The edge nearest the main road has quite a few homeless people living rough there, and while they are harmless enough and keep to themselves, they do have a 'special' odour!
Sakura. If you love sakura....go there.......spring is the best time to visit

Wonderful FREE walking tours. Spent a lovely morning with Jun and Masa, volunteer guides with the Tokyo SGG Club, a group sponsored by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government. Tours are Wed., Fri. and Sun at 10:30am and 1:30pm and leave from the Ueno Green Salon located between JR Ueno Station and the National Museum of Western Art. The tours are approx. 90 minutes. The guides are very knowledgeable and told many interesting stories of the museums, shrines, temples, and historical monuments that fill Ueno Park. And its FREE! I highly recommend them! What a wonderful way to spend a few hours in Tokyo.
Nice Park. Nice place to people watch. There's always something unexpected here. It's a low stress place in a high stress city.

Get off the train from Narita airport and stretch your legs. Winter gardens in Japan are often a bit dull. The pond in the garden is choked with bamboo weed but this is a very safe and quiet park, where locals practice tai chi. The paths are good and there is a manned police station on the corner which keeps it safe. Many homeless people live here but they work during the day cleaning the park and never beg or intrude. Their shelters are immaculate and worth seeing just to appreciate that even in adversity it is possible to retain pride.

A perfect walk. The park is large - with lots of visitors, things to do, street performers, and a temple. I went in mid-Feb, and this was the highlight of my trip, as I saw the first sakura (cherry) blossom at the park!!
Lovely and atmospheric.. Great place for a dusk stroll; some pretty shrines, and the streets nearby are very lively and atmospheric
nice park..... its a breath of fresh air in the middle of all the hustle and bustle. ;-)

A surprusing amount. There is a lot in one park: the big museums (but also some smaller specialist ones), a whole lot of temples (the highlight is the shrine to Benten on an island in the pond - take the causeway), cherry blossom (in season), food stalls and an antique market on weekends. Enjoy.
watch a baseball game. Big and peaceful park, which contains the zoo and muesum and a some baseball diamonds where high scholladed kids play ball.
Lovely natural park. It is loveley both at daytime and nightime.There are many walks around the large lakes and the zoo is adjoining
