Worth wile. Strolling through the trees on a warm summer day, Cicadas humming in the background, It doesn't get better than this. An Arsenal of Museums, Galleries, a Zoo and more to keep one more than occupied, even sitting and enjoying the crowds of Japanese enjoying their time of on a Saturday with families makes the visit worthwhile.

Worth your time. If you like parks, natures, cultural learning, or great art, Ueno Park is a must for your trip to Tokyo. Not only is it a huge open space in the world's lagrest city, but it also houses several art and culture museums, and a shrine to Tokugawa Ieyasu (Toshogu shrine). The shrine, as of Nov. 2011, is undergoing a reconstruction, but the approach and the brass lanterns are still worth the trouble. It is a beautiful park with dozens of reasons to visit including the shrine, Ueno Park Zoo, and several museums of many descriptions.

a beautiful park, and easy walking. A beautiful park, although the end of winter when we visited, so no leaves on the trees, there was lots to see and observe. I think our favourite was watching the Junior Baseball Teams play.
Nice park, but not best in Tokyo. Very large sprawling park. Interesting to see the huge soup kitchen including barber set up for the homeless.

best park in tokyo. Metropolitan museum is a classic, lots of other smaller museums/galleries dotted around, little zoo good for small children, archery centre, and people watching people watching people watching! Much more real, downtown, ornery folks park than you'll see anywhere else.
Ueno park. Lots of construction in the park at the time of the visit. Tokyo maps available at the hotel had discounts for the musuems in the park though.

A PEACEFUL PLACE IN TOKYO. I lived near this area and it is very unique with the peace and quiet I found in this area. Only twice a year do the people in Ueno get to witness Cherry Blossom season.PROS************************************************************** It is literally right next to Ueno Train Station* Free of charge* Sometimes has events to go visit on the weekend* Sometime has a market to purchase from* Ueno Art Museum is nearby *You can ride a swan boat* The famous cherry blossom event is held in Ueno - there are pictures on the sewers that indicate this.* There are at least 3-4 temples and places of interest in Ueno ParkCONS************************************************************** Long walk* If you go when it is too hot or cold you do not get to see the lotus pond. I believe you need to come at night to see the lotuses.* Cherry blossom season is only for two weeks a year.* No toilets from what I saw*Homeless people have their own area in the park
A pleasant park. A good place for a picnic and a rest from the noise of Tokyo
Catch a local school baseball game!?. It's a large park, nice for morning walk and near the zoo and museum.
Awesome Park!. Great to walk there, it's nice, calm, like an island of peace inside of Tokyo

Lovely. We came out of season and so there were no cherry blossom and also the temple and grand fountain were under construction. Despite this we were still very glad that we took the time to look around the park as it is very beautiful. We didn't visit the zoo but we stopped for a snow cone near there (which was delicious) and then took some time wandering around admiring the park. I would particularly recommend the park during cherry blossom season but even outside of it on a lovely day it is well worth seeing. I imagine when the temple and fountain are fully refurbished it will be even more lovely.

lovely. after a trek on the underground we arrived at U-en-o park. It has really stunning Japanese buildings and strangely enough gorgeous drain covers! You can walk for miles here and not feel you are in the middle of Tokyo. The ponds are nothing to write home about and in fact we were only passing through the park on our way to the old town where we got to see the real Japan. If you are only in Tokyo for a short time make the effort as the buildings are beautiful and you get to wander through old streets and meet the locals and buy the odd niknak.

Space to relax in bustling Tokyo. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Ueno Park. There weren't too many people (I guess because it was outside the popular spring season), it was lush with greenery, dotted with a few shrines and cultural monuments, with a few street performances here and there. Accessible to other Ueno attractions, such as the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum. Perfect place for a leisurely stroll away from the large crowds.

Nice Green space easily accesible from Ueno station. In a city which is almost void of green spaces Ueno park is a large green area just to the north of central Tokyo and easily accesible by the Yanomote JR line.Yes, its a public space which does mean its popular with the locals and as already mentioned its great for people watching, especially at the weekend. If you go on a Sunday the local camera clubs are all out with more kit than you see in the average camera shop in the UK, and they usually hire a model in traditional dress to stand by the lakes and flower beds whilst they snap away. And they don't mind if you sneak in and take a couple of snaps along with them.There are two largeish lakes , which are good to walk round, a smattering of shrines hidden away and it is home to Tokyo Zoo and Museums.To confirm other reviewers , this is more of a municiple park, so does not have the feeling and serenity of other Japanese Garden areas, but if you want to escape the concrete density of the City for a short while, this is a good spot.And if you do visit during Cherry Blossom season Ueno park is a fantastic place to visit to see the Cherry trees in all their splendour.It is traditional for the Tokyo workers to have after-work Cherry Blossom parties by picnicking underneath the Cherry trees. And to do this they send the office juniors out very early in the morning with their plastic sheets to bag a spot and sit under the tree all day until the rest of the office come early evening.

The Museums' Park. This is a park for commoners. It does not boast a beautiful Japanese garden. The idea was to create a public park under the patronage of the Imperial family based on Western ideas of enlightment on the former properties of Tokugawa Shogunate damaged by the civil war. Don't expect anything amazing here, although It is spectacular with cherry blossoms in Spring. Some historic temples related to the Shogunate are here. But the main reason people come here is that this park hosts many attractions, including the National Museum, Ueno Zoo, Museum of Western Arts, The Teiten Museum of Modern Japanese Art, etc.A quick visit to old and commoner's Tokyo can be enjoyed around Ueno-Asakusa area. Ameyoko is Like Camden Town in London.

Huge Park with Culture. I have been to Ueno Park a number of times but not one visit is the same. It is true, this park is a popular place to view cherry blossom but you can find nice places if you walk attentively. I can recommend three historical places: Kiyomizu Kannondo Temple, which has the minor version of Kiyomizu Temple stage. Ueno Toshogu Shrine close to the five-storied pagoda( note: Pagoda is in the Ueno Zoo) and The Great Buddha of Ueno. I hope you enjoy the park enough to find General Grant's Monument.

Must visit during cherry blossom season. We visited Ueno park early April and it's the time when cherry blosom season. When we walked in to the park, GOD, we were amazed with the scene. We were all covered by the cherry trees! All we can see is white cherry flowers on our top and from far, like no end of it. On the road sides, you can people making reservation on a spot for hanami (cherry blosom viewing and picnic) after work. We went there during evening time and the trees were lit up. The views were just amazing. Everyone was so busy with taking the photographs, finding the best angle to take the shot of the flowers and views, and chatting. I thought I have prepared myself to be amazed by the sakura, but when I reached there, I couldn't comprehend myself! Don't worry about going there with empty stomach, there are food stalls around. You can easily choose any foods you like on the stalls. We visited there again on our last day to view the scene again. This time we were day early morning and it was sunny. The scene still amazed me. Ueno park is huge - easily can spend a day there. This is the hot spot for cherry viewing and not to miss during cherry blossom season.

Lovely place for early cherry blossoms. Ueno park is very easy to get to, the entrance is right outside Ueno station. While there was hardly a bloom in the rest of Tokyo Ueno park was already out in full. The park is very pretty with lots of interesting nooks and crannies. Allow at least 2 hours to walk around and admire the flowers and the locals enjoying the party. This was the only place in Tokyo that we saw homeless people but they were no threat at all.

Great place to people watch.. Most tourists pass through Ueno Park on their way to another attraction, maybe the Zoo or excellent Tokyo National Museum. I found the park to be interesting in its own right largely due to the variety of people around. In many ways I think walking through here gave me a snapshot of the "real Tokyo" as much (or more) than spending three hours in a museum did, and the memories were certainly more lasting. Entertainers, food stands, people with pets, etc. were all in abundance and, as with most things in Tokyo, everything was turned up a notch.Worth the trip!

A Gem within Ueno Park. Compared to other parks in Tokyo, this one was not my favorite. I guess in the spring the cherry blossoms are nice. We visited in July. If you like people watching, this might be your place because this large public park is bustling with activity. It did not feel serene like other parks we visited. It is interesting historically because of the temples and a historical statue near the park entrance. There were ALOT of homeless people hanging out in the park and one man dropped his drawers and urinated on the sidewalk right in front of us. We were pretty put off by this sort of behavior. The park felt seedy. The best part was a little shrine tucked away in the park near the zoo entrance. It felt like we were in another world. It was very interesting and quiet. We were the only ones there. Near the shrine is a peace flame. The flame is said to have been kept burning from the original flames of the atomic bombs that were dropped on Japan in the 1940s. The flame survives as a monument to peace and forgiveness. It was incredibly moving to see and was, to me, unexpectedly, the highlight of Ueno Park.

Be Buried Under A Sea Of Cherry Blossoms!. We went to the Ueno Park during late March to view the cherry blossoms, and man was it spectacular! You'd be amazed by the sheer size of the sakura bloom. Everywhere you go, there will be white seas of sakuras welcoming you into their bossoms. Nice! It's a pity we could not catch the falling of the sakuras, another famous sight in Tokyo.You can visit http://3dudesintokyo.com to see more great shots and read our experiences in Ueno Park.

Nice area with lots to do. Ueno park is basically Tokyo's version of Central Park; lots of museums, a zoo, and attractions within the park grounds itself. The main part of the park fronts the JR Ueno Station which is the focal point of the Ueno district area. Overall, each museum within Ueno has its own category so I wont get into that. The park grounds are not exactly spectacular to look at but wide open space in itself within Tokyo is a rare situation so just that factor alone brings about a degree of satisfaction to visit Ueno park. If you're a jogger and looking for a good place to work out some continuous miles, Ueno is good for that especially in the evenings when the park becomes much less crowded and eerily quiet. It's also very safe, I did runs at 2am and never felt uneasy about the surroundings at all -- can't say the same for a lot of inner city parks in the US at that time of day!

Average park to stroll though. Not bad; not amazing.. My experience, at least, was just average. Granted I didn't visit any of the museums, and it wasn't cherry blossom season. If you have a week or more in Tokyo, then go spend an hour or two relaxing here. I expected to see some homeless people here, as mentioned in some travel books. There were none in the areas I walked. The pond and tree covered paths are nice breath of green among the towering concrete, glass, and steel that is Tokyo. The small temples/shrines are ok, but not the best looking ones in the city. Overall, there is nothing bad about the park.

Picnics under the blossoms. In Cherry blossom time Japanese people spread plastic sheets on the ground beneath the flowering trees and have picnics - men in business suits sitting cross leggedcon the ground drinking whisky and eating with chopsticks, while thousands of people walk past enjoying the brief blossom season! Amazing sights.
